content:
Posted: September 13, 2013
												I love DM of M&M so much. It is a fantastic action RPG that had a rough release due to glitches and bugs and it never got the love it deserved. I really am saddened a bit that a ton of gamers out there missed out on this game because of all the bad PR over issues that have been fixed through patches. The game still holds up even today. The combat is so satisfying and puts other 1st person RPGs to shame. The use of physics is amazing and really alows you to approach fights how you want, as a fighter, mage, archer or a mix. If you're looking for a hidden gem, then this is the game for you. It'll be bitter sweet when you end up having so much fin with it, and then you realise how you missed out on the multiplayer that the game offered. But at least you got to experience the single player.5/5

Posted: November 5, 2014
												One of the best games I (re)played this year.In fact, if not for what Valve did to VTMB, I'd be happy to sing GABEN's praises for Valves creation of the source engine.++Deep and well thought out melee combat system, that rewards players that look to use their surroundings to their           advantage.++Interesting story that's not the usual save the world because you have to business.++ Excellent level design that doesn't force you to fight everything in the game if you're the stealthy type (Although with the kick function, I'm not sure if anyone wants to play stealth anyway)++ High replay value to see the different endings and the different choices available to you in the story as well as the different play styles.++ Demon for a conscience and guide.- Short, so very short. (Although I assume 14-15 hours is ok these days...)- limited RPG leveling system.Overall this is an excellent game well worth the asking price.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												I started this game up expecting something along the lines of Oblivion, seeing as I recall them being released around the same time, but I got something entirely different, but not unwanted. Despite putting you on a linear path, there are just so many different ways you can go about handling yourself along the path, and I personally enjoy that. In addition, there are plenty of awesome secrets that leave me looking around for any kind of secret buttons or breakable walls along the way, and I just love how this game rewards you for it. Upon launching, I noticed this game is run on Source Engine, which had me delightfully surprised. DMMM Utilizes the technology wonderfully and the combat alone would leave me thinking it was a different engine entirely.Downsides consist of crashes, which are long beyond being worked on due to the game's age. However, if you're able to fix those loading crashes, then I guarantee that a great game waits for you on the other side of those loading screens, however cheesy some of the characters and dialogue are.Basically, I'm giving this a 10 outta 10, because I haven't had this much fun with a singleplayer RPG since Oblivion and Skyrim. Definitely on par, and plenty of variety to keep you going.

number of helpful: 87 of 91 people (96%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												I've heard about this game before. It was probably the first fantasy FPS I've seen. Got it on a sale and boy was I pleasantly surprised. I've played the whole game through in one sitting.Despite the story, characters and voice acting being rather generic and the game being very linear, the combat and mechanics of the game are really good.The game features multiple weapon types such as swords, daggers, bows, axes, staffs and shields. Tools such as hammers and pickaxes can be used as weapons too.The game has 3 (small) skill trees that all can be leveled independently (though it is recommended to stick to one at the beginning) and unlock new combat moves, spells or increase your basic stats.Combat is pretty simple but can be approached in different ways. You can throw props at enemies and kick them into hazards. Use a frost spell to freeze the ground and watch them slip off into a pit. Priceless.Because it runs on the Source engine you can expect decent physics. The game has a lot of destructible objects lying around that you can use to throw at your enemies. The game even has half life 2's gravity gun (reskined into a telekinesis spell) that you can use to mess around with.Another thing worth mentioning is that you can grab and climb up ledges, ropes and chains. Later in the game you also get a rope bow that lets you attach ropes to wooden surfaces and climb up them.I'm not arachnophobic but god damn the spiders in this game. The game seems to have a serious spider fetish. In fact the whole story is linked to spiders.Speaking about spiders, they are absolutely terrifying. Reason being that the character and npc design in terms of models and textures is great. Stuff looks interesting and quite believable. From dull gray castle guards and bald necromancers to sexy demon ladies. All really well made.When specing into the stealth build the game suffers from the same problem Skyrim does. You can stand in darkness or crouch in semi dark areas and just backstab enemies one by one as others come to check what happened. It becomes ridiculously easy to kill enemies. Not to mention just shoot your bow from a hidden spot and enemies will not know what hit them. If you get spotted however you'll have a hard time as the game is pretty darn hard. I started on the hard difficulty and had to start over because it was too hard, especially because I didn't spec the right skills at the start.TL;DR:Pros:-Fun, diverse combat-Good physics-Kicking things-Great npc design in terms of models and textures-Kicking things into other things-Optional quests that change certain story aspects and the final outcome; multiple endings-Kicking things off things-Rope bow-Kicking things into other things-Gravity gun-Replay value-Source engine; runs great on old pcs while looking relatively good-Multiple routes in some cases-Lots of worthwhile secrets.Cons:-Generic characters-Predictable story-Boring voice actors-Linear levels-Little RPG elements; no stores, no open world, no backtracking-No mod tools (considering it's the source engine); dead multiplayer as a result-Conveniently placed spiky plates to kick enemies into everywhereGreat game overall. Really underrated. Definitely gets a must play recommendation from me.

number of helpful: 79 of 84 people (94%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												I'm confused as to how this game received mixed reviews. This is simply one of the best videogames I've ever played. Sure it's story is generic but it is executed pretty darn well. What really stands out in this game is it's combat mechanics and I love games with an in-depth combat system. In all my experiences with combat mechanics in games, nothing tops this masterpiece of a game. It it truly satisfying to pull off different moves and have variation in what you do all of which affect your enemies in the slightest but most unique ways. Harness the potential power of your environment with throwable objects and traps to use against your enemies which is the most enjoyable part of this game. All of this is made possible with the SOURCE ENGINE! So not only do these abilities and such sound good but are executed equally as good!What I also admire is it's Immense replayablility for a game that seems so linear. The game presents you these three playstyles that you can go full out on one or try and experiment between them and create cool hybrids. There are no boundaries, no "choose your class" type ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, it just gives you the game and goes "go nuts". And the repayability that this creates is awesome! Speaking of replayability, you can also find secret areas along your travels and the game also sports multiple endings!All of this is played in FPS which adds onto the immersion. Not many fantasy games play out in FPS which makes this game pretty unique in that sense.The game is more feature rich than you would think. But my only gripe about this game is the voice acting. TERRIBLE TERRIBLE VOICE ACTING...at least from the main protagonist. If you can get past it like I did, you'll have a bomb of a time.Note: Do not buy this game for the multiplayer, I've tried it and absolutely NOBODY plays it.9/10

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Dark Messiah of Might & Magic puts players in a first-person perspective, allowing them to immerse themselves in the legendary Might and Magic universe as never before. It is also the world's first fantasy action game to feature a complete first-person combat system. It takes full advantage of the Source Engine's exceptional technological enhancements in areas such as character animation, advanced AI, real-world physics and shader-based rendering. - UbisoftI have played this game during my early childhood and I must admit that once I started playing this game I felt stuck to it and completed it over and over again multiple times.A game that despite being released in 2006, it’s yet fully capable of taking down some modern games within the same genres.A fine example of what a good adventure and a first-person action game should be, Dark Messiah of Might & Magic is a remarkable example at its finest.Overall aspects of Dark Messiah of Might & MagicAdventure combined with the storyline: The adventure that this game is capable of, is reasonable with the addition of secret places that contributes to a careful exploration of each area players find themselves in. Despite being strictly locked only to its main quest and some other minor side quests, it also contains a short amount of role-playing and key decisions throughout the game.The storyline isn’t the best, it lacks a strong backbone or a base to begin from, and it is based mostly in surprise elements and new elements that will always shape players way of thinking and seeing things as they progress further in the game.Graphics and game play mechanics: The graphics Dark Messiah is capable of projecting with its Source Engine, despite not being the best for its time, are still pretty good and well-balanced with the game play mechanics and user interface.About the game mechanics, it is focused not only to give players a very pleasant first person melee/ranged combat experience with many different styles and opponents, but also a strong presence of the use of the surrounding game atmosphere and items during all sorts of conflict.Combat: Despite the rich game combat moves the game allows players to execute, you might feel that most conflicts you face will be ultimately resolved by the use of front kicks combined with the use of the game surroundings and objects around to terminate your enemies.This can be easily a 'Pro' for most players since it is quite enjoyable to watch enemies being kicked off to spikes or to be kicked off against fragile wooden crates, but maybe a 'Con' for some.User interface: The user interface in this game is simple, clean and again, it does match well with everything else giving players a very good gaming experience.There is only one way to access your character info, skill points, and quick toolbar which is located at the right top side of your inventory that offers a very simple and easy way to access everything you want.Music and the voice acting: Despite this game containing more sounds related to the atmosphere of each part of the game than music itself, both are pretty much reasonable in the end I would say.The voice acting is decent I believe, but sometimes it just feels that it doesn’t fit whenever there is music being played during a cut scene and voice simultaneously.Game difficulty: The game difficulty is very well balanced to meet the tastes of those who wish a enjoyable adventure without struggling that much, to those who want it hardcore with difficult opponents.Price: The game price that has also been the same for the last few years is incredibly worth it, with or without sales, the content and adventure this game has to offer is totally worth its base price.ConclusionI would rate this game 79 out of 100 or 3.9 out of 5.0 stars. An enjoyable adventure with a fair amount of content and a vast adventure with decent graphics and game play for a very good price.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												Dark Messiah of Might and Magic is hands down one of the most entertaining games I have ever played in my life. To be honest, the story is lame, the levels are pretty linear, and after one or two playthroughs you aren't likely to find any new hiding spots for super-secret treasure(though there are quite a few of them).But this game's combat makes up for all of its flaws, story or otherwise. I have never played a game with more engaging, interesting, or balanced combat than this one. It's the only reason I come back to this game, and as you can see from my logged hours, I have come back to this game time and time again.The combat is fairly basic to begin with, you can hit things hard or not so hard, you can block with a shield or parry with a one-handed weapon, you can shoot enemies from far away with a bow. However, as you progress into the game and start earning skill points, combat very quickly becomes a deep experience. The game carries three classic releplaying game archetypes: the mage, the rogue, and the warrior. But the part that makes it so wonderful is the complete freedom you have to spend your skill points in any way you please. You can be sneaking up on your opponents wearing heavy armor and slinging fireballs if you want to.Just play the game, that's really all there is to it. It's well worth the meager investment.

												Played this bloddy thing like 3 times, in 3 different styles, and I also got the extended port for Xbox360. After that much time playing this game, I can safely tell you, it's worth it on a sale. Here's why:Ever wanted a game with a story as good as the first Half Life, that's as linear, but more RPG-Like? Then, this is your game. The only difference, is that the main character speaks, and you have legs as your crowbar.Made with the source engine, the graphics of the game still look great today. The story, even though not being a f#cking master-piece, it's decent and entertaining, and the gameplay...Well, ♥♥♥♥ing love it.You can be, whatever you want to be. You want to be like Havel from Dark Souls, a huge armored rock that slays everthing in one hit, but it's slow as progress with Half Life 3? Want to be a camping sniper who can trickshot someone in the balls in slow motion? Want to be the medieval Adan Jensen, and use stealth to the max, executing people from the back? Or just want to be Leonidas, and kick everyone on the balls, and throw them to the pits of hell? I'm not kidding, I did that already, even sended the video to a famous channel long time ago.


YouTube™ Video: Game Fails: Dark Messiah of Might and Magic "I know there's a pattern here... " 

			Views: 58,867		

			For more Game Fails visit http://www.youtube.com/gamefails Got something funnier? Submit your clips now at http://ahuploads.com Fails from all games accepted! Submitted by: KiraSama		

You also have offensive and defensive magic, and they're also fun to use...But I always end up taking stealth. The game has a few endings, and counting that this is as linear as modern FPS's (but with four times thework on the actual game), it's good!The game also has multiplayer. Now, I don't know if the multiplayer comes already with the full game, or you buy it stand-alone, but sadly, it's almost dead. You have to understand, the game is really old...But there are still a few servers, most of them russian servers. And if you're able to play without getting banned by "hacking" (turns out, I'm superior, must be the afro hair), you'll have fun. The matches are team-based with 5 classes, mostly being the Spy-backstabbing-son-of-a-wh#re, the archer-sniping-MLG-kid, the SUPERIOR-REAL-SOVIET-DAMAGING-Black Mage, the White-Medic-Mage, and the generic Melee-HOLDMOUSE1TOWIN-Knight. You win XP in the matches, to get extra skills and stuff, and each match is entertaining...Even though some stuff is a bit over-powered. There's variety, though. Just think, for example: Healing magic also damages enemies, and you can set how much you want it to heal, and how much to damage!This game is, like I said, like a RPG-Half Life. And a good one, at that. Since the multiplayer is almost deserted, I'd say it's worth 5-8€ at max, but the money will be well spent.AND DON'T BE A ♥♥♥♥♥ IN MULTIPLAYER, SPAMMING THE GOD-DAMN RAISE ON WHITE MAGES. THIS IS NOT GOD-DAMN FINAL FANTASY, YOU KNOW!Edit: Forgot to put this here, made this video a few months ago, me trying to go through most of the game glitching sh#t and mainly using kicks. content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												In a nutshell: a very good (and different than the mainstream) game, with some flaws. Highly recommended, and the price is very low; give it some initial love, and you will be rewarded by several hours of enjoyable gameplay.Want details? Read below.When I first heard about this game, I thought "Come on, melee fighting in... first-person view only? Ridiculous." It turns out it is way better than I thought. The game actually manages to be very enjoyable, despite the fact it has its flaws. Yes, the first-person view is a major flaw because you can't see much, as a big part of the screen is covered by your shield, your daggers, or even your own hands when using some spells. However, in practice it is not as bad as it sounds, and in some ways first-person view makes things more interesting, provided you get used to the hitboxes of your weapons.The learning curve is rather steep in the beginning, but it gets better soon. The game is not an RPG really, but has some RPG elements. There is no experience or stats; you earn skill points as you complete your objectives, and you can use those skill points to learn some abilities or spells; neat and simple. There are no classes; instead, there are three skill trees, somehow representing the typical fighter, rogue/archer, and mage classes. However, the player is free to distibute skill points as he/she pleases, so it is quite possible to be a warrior with some magical or stealth abilities, and such combinations actually work very well in practice. I personally found the sword fighter + archer combo quite enjoyable, and probably the easiest way to play this game. A "thief" build is also interesting, and it is actually quite possible to go stealth for the most part of the game.Melee fighting is probably the most interesting aspect of Dark Messiah. You have some fighting moves, and using them you can make your opponent walking lame, or you can decapitate him. Fighting is far from being the usual, boring click fest. It needs player's skills instead.As usual in similar PC games, the controls are clunky, and some players will probably quit playing early because of this. For example, hold left mouse button "for a second" to activate power attack; hold direction keys while holding down the left mouse key to activate alternative power attacks; additionally, hold space bar for a jump attack. All that when you have a bunch of enemies in front of you. Seriously, if that's not clunky controls, I don't know what "clunky controls" means. Things would be way better if you could use a controller instead of mouse and keyboard. Nevertheless, once you get used of the controls, melee fighting is really enjoyable. It has not the nice controls of Dark Souls, but it is still quite enjoyable. Most players will probably pick a warrior combo because of this, despite the controls.As in Half-Life 2, you can use the environment to get rid of your enemies. Shoot a loose supporting beam so that the barrels above fall on a bunch of bad guys; cut a rope so that a rock pendulum hits a mighty cyclops that blocks your way; kick your enemy so that he falls off a cliff, etc. Physics reminds Half-Life 2, and that's not a coincidence, as Dark Messiah uses the same game engine. Using the environment is just another nice aspect of the game.The plot is nothing innovative, but it is certainly interesting. You are a guy, trying to get an ancient artifact from the bad guys. Nothing new so far; however, there are two hot girls hitting on you. Leanna is the "good girl" who will fight on your side in many cases, and eventually falls in love with you, although she is too shy to admit it openly. Xana is some kind of a succubus, a demonic creature that lives inside you, gives you useful information depending on the situation and, most importantly, comments on what's going on. Xana's commentary is actually the funniest part of this game: she is jealous about Leanna, and always has some ironic and quite funny comments about her.A spice of humor is spread all over the game. It's not only Xana's comments mentioned above, but also NPCs talk to eachother, quite often in a funny way: enemy soldiers talking about their boss ironically, goblins discussing if they should eat the orc they just killed, and several other things that will make you smile.There are some nice cutscenes, but luckily the developers didn't overuse them. I am really tired of today's ridiculous "AAA" games with a cutscene every few seconds and zero gameplay. Dark Messiah is definitely not one of them, and I am quite happy with that.Eventually, you will have to take decisions, which leads to a few different endings of the game. However, the game is basically linear; personally, I prefer that instead of the chaotic gameplay of Elder Scrolls, for example - although a lttle more non-linearity in Dark Messiah would be nice. Not to mention fighting in Dark Messiah is actually way better than the simplistic fighting in Elder Scrolls. Hard to remember a similar, but non-linear game, that managed to keep me playing till its end.Graphics are typical for the Source engine used. Although not that realistic as in modern games, graphics certainly serve their purpose very well. I also liked the music of the game, and in general sound does its job: no complaints, no awards. Voice actors also do their job, with Moon Dailly performing very well as Xana.There is also a multiplayer mode for Dark Messiah. I imagine this would be quite fun, but sadly it is non-existant in practice. Official server is down, probably because this game was first released 9 years ago. Unless you have friends interested to play, forget about multiplayer.I read some people had techinical issues with this game. This was not the case for me; no issues in a mediocre laptop running Windows 7 64 bit. No FPS drops, no tearing, with maximum quality settings on - very good performance, typical for the Source engine used in the game. I had a few game crashes, especially when running other programs in the background, but nothing really serious, and probably caused by the laptop's low RAM.The game is rather easy in "normal" mode - provided you pass the steep initial learning curve. There are some annoyingly hard enemies, but in general you won't have serious problems beating the game, including bosses. Expect a 20-30 hours of gameplay in your first playthrough, if you want to explore everything and find all secret places in the game. Replayability is rather low: once I beated the game, I started over using a stealth build and tried a different ending but, other than that, there is no more replayability to talk of.Final verdict: I don't give a positive review easily, but Dark Messiah definitely desrves it, despite the flaws mentioned.  Taking into account its price, I'd say it's a bargain, and highly recommended.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												NOTE: I bought it on retail, played and finished this game BEFORE I had a Steam Account. I only recently Activated it on Steam. As usual, SEE CONCLUSION if you find this review too long.INTRO:Set in the UBISOFT world of Ashan (Heroes V world), you play an adventurer named Sareth who sets out on a quest to stop the "Dark Messiah" from releasing the imprisoned Demon Lord who was prophesied to return.Dark Messiah of Might and Magic is one of the earlier first person magic/melee games of Arkane Studios who would later go on to make Dishonored. This game has a completley different game mechanic from the original Might and Magic games of 3DO and New World Computing.PROS:+ Decent Graphics: - This game utilizes the Source Engine. Although, It may not be the most graphically advanced game, it brings, a decent enough atmosphere and pretty environments with a commendable quality texture work.+ Combat Mechanic: - Also a CONS (See Below). This game has a good blend of magic, melee and ranged combat. Dealing with different kinds of foes may require you to adopt different tactic to efficiently dispose of your target. Stealth mechanic works fairly well. (Not even close to Thief or Dishonored, but enough to satisfy a more stealthy approach on the missions.)+ Story: - I personally liked the story which is directly related to the Heroes of Might and Magic universe that I'm a fan of. The plot twists and conflicts are well delivered along with some interesting characters. As usual, this is my own opinion and some people might disagree with me.+ Lengthy Campaign: -Long enough to deliver the story in a satisfying manner. This game also features  multiple ending scenario where your actions would directly impact the game's ending. It Suffers from the Mass Effect 3 Syndrome though. (Feel free to ask me on what the ME3 Syndrome is.)CONS:- Combat Mechanic: - Also a PRO (See Above). Despite the availability of different items, magics and tactics, they are all trumped by your might BOOT. Kicking your target either to stun them or send them to spikes (which are conveniently placed) defeats the purpose of having different kinds of weapons, magic and equipment. It becomes repetitive at times.- Unnecessary Multiplayer: - There are games that were meant for Singleplayer, this is one such game. Unfortunately, for us, a poorly implemented multiplayer is present which most likely diverted some of the developer's money which would have been better spent on advancing the Singleplayer experience.- Cheesy Voice Acting: - I did enjoy the voice acting but that's me, most people will probably get annoyed with it and so I place it here as a CON.CONCLUSION:Though I generally RECOMMEND this game, I, however, think that new players or people new to the Might and Magic lore may not be able to fully appreciate its true value. This is best played by people already familar with Might and Magic. This game is underrated in my honest opinion.NOT RECOMMENDED if you're looking for an old school Might and Magic (VI to VIII) experience. For that, check out Might and Magic X or Legend of Grimrock. Also not for people looking for an Elder Scrolls experience.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Like my Reviews? Follow my Curator's Page:http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861651-Miyumi%27s-Review-Corner/

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												A cult classic from the creators of Dishonored, Dark Messiah is an interesting game.  It's listed as an RPG but that's misleading; it's like calling Dishonored an RPG.  Both have skill trees, both have a very small amount of decision making which results in low chaos vs high chaos in Dishonored.  Without spoiling anything, Dark Messiah is similar in that regard.  It's not truly an RPG, you don't have control over your character's physical and personality attributes and there are no dialogue choices or anything like that.  There are simply three major plot decisions.One particularly interesting aspect in this game is that you don't necessarily play as the good guy.  I'll just leave it at that without spoiling much.This game is known primarily for its gameplay mechanics, combat in particular.  It's a first person action game that has separate skill trees for melee combat, magic, archery, as well as some miscellaneous skill trees.  Furthermore, there are different types of melee weapons to choose from: twin daggers, swords, and staves.  Each has different properties, pros, cons, and combat animations.  One of the best features of this game's melee combat is that you have different swings/strokes depending on your movement.  Holding W and releasing a power attack for example delivers a different attack than holding A + power strike.  This is something I've demanded for years, and this is one of few games that offers it.Most spells are offensive and elemental based but there are some exceptions.  The player is expected to go down every weapon skill tree apparently, since archery is too useful in boss fights.This being a source game, it's almost entirely physics based.  Arkane Studios took advantage of this and emphasized using the environment to kill your opponents.  Knock down a bunch of heavy debris on them, kick them off of a cliff, impale them on spikes, you name it.  Combined with the ability to chain spell effects and other things together (e.g., spill oil on an area and light it on fire with a fire spell or arrow, or shoot a lightning spell into water to electrify it), Dark Messiah seems to provide more ways to kill opponents than any other game, and you can see from my library that I've played a lot.  Even more ways to kill people than Dishonored, which lacks the environmental emphasis.People often say that The Elder Scrolls games should have this game's combat.  They are absolutely right.  Conceptually, this game has the best combat mechanics of any action game.  However, despite everything I just said, the gameplay/combat is riddled with flaws/oversights, the game lacks an engaging story/plot (RotFodder's pizza analogy is spot on), and it may be a bit too long for its own good.  The combat is fantastic on paper but has flawed execution.  First of all, the game is quite rough around the edges and clipping issues are fairly common which is extremely annoying.  There are some stupid delays when blocking attacks and counter attacking, or using daggers, and other situational things like that.  Also, unlike most first person action games, you actually have to be very precise with your swings.  It seems like the player's hitbox with melee weapons is actually the weapon itself; this makes sense, however it's not good in practice.  This type of thing only works in a game with very precise swinging and more fluidity, like Shadow Warrior and Dark Souls games.  Reach/range is really wonky in this game.  Goblins seem to have the same reach as humans and orcs.   At the end of the day this game comes across as quite clunky by modern standards, but by 2006 standards it must have been a gift from God (I didn't play it in 2006 but I've played plenty of 2006 games in 2006, Red Steel was the best action game I had played at the time).  Because of it's clunkiness I find it less enjoyable than Dishonored as an action game.  Dishonored's mix of advanced action mechanics and unbelievable, flawless fluidity is only matched by Shadow Warrior and Shadow Warrior 2 as far as first person action games go.  But then Dark Messiah has so many advantages like the environmental uses, spell/effect combos, and more varied melee attacks than Dishonored.  As usual, we'll never get it all.Dark Messiah is known to be challenging, but it has that old school unbalanced challenge where if you raise the difficulty, enemies just deal far more damage than you even when using the same attack.  It will take around ten flame arrow spells to kill a regular human opponent for example, but they can kill you in four (and that's with upgraded max health).  If you like unbalanced no holds barred difficulty then perhaps you'll like this, otherwise I recommend sticking to Normal mode which is more balanced.  I favor balanced difficulty with smart AI.  This game's AI is functional enough although hilariously bad at times.Dishonored is known for its stealth, and that's one area where this game lacks.  It's far more linear than Dishonored, the climbing system is awfully clunky and barely works (clunkier than Thief Gold's even), and you're generally unable to one hit kill enemies from behind even with backstab.  This game is clearly meant to be an action game first, stealth game secondary. Dishonored and Deus Ex: Mankind Divided are the only games I've played that are equally proficient at both.In terms of atmosphere, this game bears an uncanny resemblence to Thief at times.  Some sections even tricked me into pressing Thief's key bindings!  The resemblence is so strong at times, particularly in crypts.  This game also has a Rope Bow for shooting rope arrows into wooden surfaces... sound familiar?  Although Thief's rope arrows are less restricted and work more often.It's no secret that this game relies entirely on its combat.  The plot and all of the dialogue are pure cheese.  It's cliche after cliche.  Character development is mostly non existent.  This is all intentional though, the game is not meant to have an enthralling story or serve as a drama of any sort.  It's just meant to provide a challenging but very fun killing experience.  It mostly does that, although its clunkiness and lack of polish makes it frustrating at times.  Plenty of times this game would get tiresome and repetitive, but then I'd unlock a new ability and all of a sudden it's fun again until I use that ability many times.TL:DR - This game is all about killing things and it has very good killing mechanics overall, the best on paper as far as action games go but the fact that it's somewhat clunky and very unpolished can make it annoying.  It's meant to be fun and challenging, and it mostly succeeds but with a number of hitches.  It drags on a bit and gets tiresome toward the end.  Decent game, I'd love a sequel on Source 2.I did not proofread this review.

												imagine the perfect game with the perfect gameplay, world and lore from the might and magic series (Heroes of Might and Magic V) physics engine using the Source Engine, this Hack and Slash FPS is the eqivelent of half life 2 as a childhood masterpiece of game criminally under-rated (FU gamespot) and the spritual predecessor of Dishonored this game hits all the spots from a gaming perspective too bad it's a tad bit short, but has IMMENSE replayvalue i've finished this game 15 times on the elements version on console and now i've finished it on the 16th on the steam version and my god, what a nostalgia trip! i wish i could erase my memory and replay this gem again and again... this game has 4 main styles of gameplay, with the PC version you can mix em up on console you're stuck with whatever you started with so you have:Strength and Endurance -Sword and Shield with heavy armor playstyle Stealth and burgerly - use of daggers, allows to 1-hit kill from behind while undetected, also to open doors and chests without keys (via automatic lockpicking) Magic and Mana:spells spells spells! get yer spells here, don't bother with staves, they're boring and unispring i personally perfer the "utility" magic over the elemental magic, because you have the "Charm" ability which makes enemies allies for a period of time, very helpful and you can get it pretty early on last but not least... marksmanship and critial hits: bow gameplay, essentially turning this game into a medivil FPS, i don't like this playstyle because it relies on you camping from a distance and aiming for the head, if you want this playstyle mix with a couple levels of stealth i personally went with the dishonored build a lot of stealth and crit, a bunch of magic, some endurance and a bit of strength (on hardmode enemies can definitely take a beating) and i would DEFINITELY recommend you to play this game on at least hard (normal is the EZ mode of the game) ask me what to level up first if you're in a bind and if you're really into the story,i'ed recommend watching the story of Heroes of might and magic V and it's expansions on youtube (i can link you to a channel) Dark Messiah concludes the might and magic series before Ubisoft went to milk the "past" of the series with terrible sequels as of now this is the last year of the seventh dragon (989), meaning this game was the planned to end the series (either giving Ashan eternal peace, or unleashing all Shough upon it) TLDR: this is a great game and i would recommend you to play it.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												Even being as old as it is, Dark Messiah still has, hands down, one of the best combat systems I have ever seen in a video game. Few other medieval fantasy games have the amount of fluidity and control over a character's actions as DM does. Your character takes into account whether you are moving quickly, what direction you have moved your mouse, and how long you have pressed the attack button in determining what attack will be done. The physics in the game are great as well. Ever wanted to kill a horde of orcs by only throwing crates and barrels at them a la Donkey Kong style? In this game, you can! Ever wanted to mess around for a while watching Necromancers play slip and slide on ice traps you've laid down? In this game, you can! Want to fight dirty and kick an enemy  off a cliff? In this game, you can!Other games such as Morrowind/Oblivion/Skyrim may have an open world with a more developed lore surrounding it, but they absolutely pale when it comes to their combat systems. Any person who has played Dark Messiah will agree. On another note, this is still one of the few games in which you can enjoy a full view of your character's body when looking downwards. Games being made today still don't have this option, which is somewhat embarassing since this game had it implemented perfectly since 2006.Lastly, this is one of the few games that genuinely feels as though you have actually taken down something massive and dangerous. The colossal size of some of the creatures, such as the wyverns and cyclops in this game, are genuinely huge, and require out-of-the-box strategizing to take down. For comparison's sake, I'll use Skyrim. Let's be honest, Skyrim's dragons are somewhat pathetic, if they seem to have trouble even dealing with common folk and can be taken down by common every-day arrows and fire spells. In DM, these creatures are actually quite dangerous, even towards the end of the game, and when you've killed a boss creature, you feel like you've earned it; it's an actual accomplishment that you look back on with pride. You owe it to yourself to play this game.

												I cannot count the amount of playthroughs I have done with this game, but to date one of the best RPG's ever made. The review scores really baffle me. While the story is generic and the voice acting sort of meh the combat and campaign are incredible. Imagine an RPG where skill progression doesnt just give you number increases, but tangible abilities, spells, moves and perks. Every encounter is like a battle arena sandbox with ledges, spikes, stairs, objects, oil jars, traps, and other things to exploit, you can play this game however you want, because xp (skill points) is awarded through progress rather than kill count, so stealth is viable. content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												This is such a great game.  Everything about it is so cool!  I'd place it near the pinnacle of first-person fantasy combat in all three archetypes: melee combat, stealth combat, and wizardry.  The movement is rather unique among fps games in that your character has weight that you can see and feel, and it makes you have to think as you move through combat.  Also, YOU CAN SEE YOURSELF; your body is rendered, and your choice of armor and equipment show.  It looks nice for an older game, and, since it is older, it runs beutifully on a new system.  The atmosphere is excellent, and the story is clever and well paced too.  You even have story changing choices!  Player agency!  I can go on and on about how much I love this game!  The environment is interactive.  The character progression is great, picking perks in the different archetypes: melee sword and sometimes board, Legolas archery, ninja stealth, and powerful sorcery.  You can specialize or mix and match to suit your playstyle.  This adds so much replayability.  I'm playing through again as a Wizard after a cool run as a Warrior type, and I'll go again.   It's such a great game!  Buy it!  Play it!  10/10  Two enthusiastic thumbs up!This is a gem of fantasy fps gaming.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												This review is for the single player, might try the multi-player once I return to land of good internets.Great game, it might be a bit dated, the physics might be ridiculous at times but it is still well worth playing. And if you are wondering about my hours this is a retail version that I will go for yet another playthrough of soon but I only started using steam properly in the last 2 years and I have this game 8 years or so.A little history, this is, in essence, the predecessor to dishonored. Yes they are completely different game worlds but it is made by arkane stuidos, the company who also made dishonored and arx fatalis. They don't make many games and there is one thing in common with all of them, the environment is great <--- this is coming from a guy who will rarely even notice, nevermind applaud environment.If you havent played any of these games then let me give you a quick breakdown.You play sareth, midevil apprentice to old wizard man who goes on a wonderful adventure filled with swords and spiders and undead creatures playing tag. The story is predicatable and cliché but not badly told.You being the standard multi-talented rpg character can choose to become the most powerful (headless) warrior/mage/assasin of your time.So why is the environment so good? Why would I reccomend this at least as much as the much smoother and more polished dishorored? Because you have one of the first games to try realistic physics and while it failed magnificently in some ways, it is still one of the best attempts going. Sure you kick someone within ten yards of a cliff/spikes and they go flying over it after tumbling forever and ever. But alot of objects can be played on both by you and the enemy, even combining in interesting ways with certain spells.One of the nicest things that is so rare in games is that you REALLY feel different depending on what skills you choose. Stealth is ridiculously OP to the point of breaking the game at stealth 3, while magic only playthroughs are as challenging sub 10 deaths in super meat boy 106%.The game is completely linear (which I like), even when you make a choice it barely affects any outcomes. Save this guy or not, heres a potion, or a sword, or a chance to kill the annoying one. The most significat differences are the 4 different endings and even there the actual difference is nothing at all, not even really worth exploring.The enemies are one of the nicer parts, every enemy plays differently. Bigger, smaller, stronger, weaker, come in groups, come alone, have certain elemental weaknesses or can only be hurt in one spot. On the counter side the AI is stupidly exploitable, (this can be fun), but the hardcore player might be very dissapointed.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												Dark Messiah of Might & Magic is not a complicated or ambitious game, but what it sets out to do, it does very well... more or less. First, it should be said that like Crusaders of Might & Magic, this is not part of either of the two Might & Magic series (The strategy games and the classic RPGs). While it does take place within that continuity, it plays nothing like them. It does have a level progression system and character building, but more than anything it is a first person corridor shooter, just with swords, bows and magic instead of guns. In fact, the closest thing I can think of is Hexen. However, while the idea of a melee-oriented FPS may sound questionable (Although consider that Condemned: Criminal Origins came out around the same time), Dark Messiah's combat system is nothing short of fantastic, at least when swords are involved. I highly recommend that any potential players spec melee with just a bit of magic, as the sword fighting system is easily the best part of the game and is what the environments are designed for. Magic, particularly healing, is a nice addition, but focusing on it gets dull. Stealth is just tacked on and serves little purpose. In addition to a number of melee moves, Dark Messiah also features the fantasy version of Duke Nukem's mighty boot, and to be honest, this gets way more use than it should. This is because the levels are liberally covered with spike traps, long falls, fire, and so on that you can punt the enemies into. It's an absolute blast to send an orc falling to his death with nothing but a swift kick, but it does tend to be used far too much. This is because it kicking enemies quickly becomes the most efficient method of dispatching enemies, particularly when fighting a number of enemies in a closed environment.Overall, the level design is fine, if linear. At certain points, in fact, it could even be called inspired. Like the later Mirror's Edge, platforming is incorporated liberally, and also like that game, you can see the main character's body to help. Rope arrows help you scale the environments and contribute to the sheer numbers of ways you can dispatch your enemies. Towards the end, however, the action moves underground. At this point, most of the environments become incredibly boring, and due to the darkness, most of the game will be played through one of the most obnoxious night vision shaders I've ever seen. Also, while the combat shines when fighting humanoid enemies, this game is way overfond of spider levels, and these bounce between annoying and tedious, depending on how many poison curatives you have. No number of potions, however, can make these sections fun.The story is entirely forgettable, with absolutely no outstanding characters. While there are multiple endings based on a particular choice, the logic of this choice is simply pathetic. The protagonist, Sareth, is accompanied by two female characters, a young mage and a succubus that lives in his mind, and his persona bounces between boy scout and creepy edgelord depending on which one happens to be the focus of a particular level. Literally no character in this game is particularly interesting or well developed, and the story simply serves to move the action forward.Dark Messiah is far from perfect, but it has one reason to exist, and that's the combat. At times, the game feels like a spiritual successor to Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast, and that's nothing but a good thing. It isn't as good as Jedi Outcast, but its as close as you'll come. Despite its many flaws, as a combat sandbox Dark Messiah justifies a place in any action gamer's library. However, it should be avoided if you want a well-constructed story, non-linear or open levels, or deep RPG mechanics. Make no mistake, Dark Messiah may look like its contemporary, TESIV: Oblivion, but the two couldn't be more different. Dark Messiah is a competent action game, and if that's all you're in the market for, I recommend it.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												This is the first Might and Magic Game I've played. So my review will be based on that.First of all, THIS GAME IS SHORT. You can probably beat in < 10 hours meaning one day of zoning out on the computer and bam, the final boss is down. The game is divided into 10 chapters with each chapter representing an area. Secondly, this game is as linear as it gets - there is an order for every place and you can't go back - just like FFXIII. The leveling system is also a bit weird - everything is done in skill points which are obtained by going through the storyline. There are a few optional skill points as well - for finding secret areas or completing optional quests but those are few and far.  You determine your characters "class" by spending skill points. Another thing to note - THERE IS NO TRADING. You can keep items in your inventory, use them, or drop them. That's it. The only healing you get is either through magic or healing items and mana restoration is only available via mana items which can only be found. So be very careful on how you use what you have.On an overall note this game is different, it's short, linear, and kind of limited, but it was still fun to play. So if you are looking for something and this game is on sale for under 10 bucks then this may be the game for you.RATING: 6.5/10.

content:
Posted: January 4
												Dark Messiah received mixed reviews after its release. There are two camps it seems. There are those who get tired of all its bugs, poor programming, and loading times, and overall lack of polish, and hate the game. Then you have those who endure; stick with it despite its shortcomings and love the game. This is reflected on ModDB (Mod Database) where the game has an overall score of 9.5 out of 10 at the time of writing. Ironic then that the game doesn’t have much in the way of mods – only small ones which are more like fixes that aren’t highly publicised. But I can’t think why anyone would want to mod it actually. Because even though it is flawed (and completely bearable compared to the console version developed for the Xbox 360), it is a fantasy-themed action role-playing gamer’s dream come true. It couldn’t really be improved that much more gameplay wise if you tried. If you’re the type who ate up the likes of Diablo and its sequels, then you should probably try this. It's highly underrated.There’s a very good reason why it goes on my list of best games I’ve ever owned. Because it is a bloody blast to play. And that’s what really matters in the end.

content:
Posted: March 12
												TL DR: Dark Messiah is a really great action game with solid gameplay which sometimes gets ridiculous with its use of physics, but it does force you out of stealth and into combat later on. Still, there's just an insane number of hilarious ways to kill things.Dark Messiah of Might & Magic is a first-person action game with some RPG elements developed by Arkane Studios and Floodgate Entertainment.In the game, you play as Sareth, the underling of a mage, in a quest to find a powerful item. The plot is pretty bad, with the only remotely funny thing about it being that there are two women constantly stroking your ego on proportions that the Half-Life 2 devs wish they had achieved. It's so much that I actually found it funny unlike Half-Life 2 which was plain annoying.Anyway, there are 10 levels, all mostly linear, though with some wide open spaces throughout. The game provides you with an extensive assortment of tools with which to murder you enemies (ghosting is also possible but not in the entirety of the game, as there are too many well-lit areas where you can't hide.) There's physics, weapons and magic. "Wait, physics?" Yes. Dark Messiah uses and abuses the Source Engine with weakly-supported structures whose weak supports can usually be brought down by sword, arrow or fireball. You also have a mighty kick which can be used against high drops and spikes to instantly kill enemies. Most objects are also grabbable and therefore throwable. You have a freeze spell and bow which when used on the ground can create a surface where enemies will slip and maybe fall to their deaths.By now some people already realized the amount of insanely entertaining♥♥♥♥♥♥you can do in this game and are playing it. Have fun!Apart from that, there's a great melee combat system. The direction of your movement affects the type of attack you can power up, and upgrading the Close Combat skill allows for charges, jump attacks and whirlwinds, bringing your number of attacks per weapon to seven. There's also an adrenaline meter which when full will mean your next attack is slow-mo and instantly kills and dismembers/beheads the enemy. The adrenaline meter also has special effects on each spell. You've also got bows, which can usually instantly kill with a well-placed headshot out of hiding (though the hitboxes are somewhat clunky), and even sometimes nail and enemy to the wall, which is pretty fun. There's also a rope bow like in the first two Thief games, which makes vertical exploration pretty fun. Weapons beyond the basic usually have skill requirements whch restrict you from equipping them.The aforementioned skill system is divided into Combat, Magic and Misc skills. You get skill points for completing objectives, which means you don't have to kill everyone for an optimal character. The amount of skill points lets you max out a skill tree and then more, though it's cooler to make a jack-of-all-trades kind of character. I started with a sneaky assassin (Archery and Stealth), and then started building more into open combat (Close Combat and Strength.) I managed to get through some areas undetected with wall-nailing headshots out of darkness, which was pretty cool. As for stealth, there is a meter indicating how well you are hidden but the parameters for being seen are never explained and sometimes it seems you're invisible in pretty light spots, which is strange.As fun as the game is, by chapter 9 I was already done with all the fun. I did finish the game but the repetitiveness of it was pretty evident, and the fact that chapter 9 does throw a lot of the same enemy at you at once, making it pretty hard to get through it without anything but straight close combat doesn't help. There's also not a huge variety of enemies in game, and by about half of the game you've seen all of them, even though that's compensated by the variety in killing methods that you have.Overall Dark Messiah is a pretty fun and silly game, and prefectly replayable if you don't feel you got enough on the first run.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												I first played Dark Messiah way back when it first came out and it's a game I have constantly revisited over the years.While I've sunk more hours total into any given Elder Scrolls game I've played, Dark Messiah by far holds my personal record of total completed playthroughs at too many to count but at least several dozen.I keep coming back to it to try out new skill/weapon combos and novelty character builds and keep finding new little hidden stuff even after years of replaying and knowing the game essentially by heart at this point.Therefore it's my personal nominee for the 2016 "Test of time" award.By the way, this review is solely for the single player part of the game. The multiplayer part was a publisher-mandated hackjob that nobody wanted and I don't think anybody ever played or mentioned ever, period. Except maybe to highlight unneccesary publisher-mandated multiplayer mode hackjobs that nobody asked for.On the technical side of things, Dark Messiah is an first-person action game in the fantasy setting of the turn based strategy games Heroes of Might and Magic, which I know bugger all about apart from this game.Not that you need to anyway, if you've consumed any sort of fantasy media in your life, you are familiar enough with the the setting.The game runs on Half Life 2's Source Engine and takes the same almost fetishistic joy in physics shenanigans and environment elements ready to be used to your advantage.To my friends I often semi-ironically refer to it as the best game ever made based solely on the fact that it's an ego-perspective game where you play an actual character with a full body rather than a floating pair of hands attached to an invisible hitbox.However this actually does hold some water. If you play other first-person games lacking full player character body after this, special mention going to Dishonored from the same studio (essentially an immensely watered down version of the stealth approach to gameplay in Dark Messiah, down to the same bugged up rope climbing controls), you'll see just how much immersion a full character model adds.The game has RPG elements, allowing you to earn and invest skill points rather freely into classic Fighter/Mage/Rogue skills to finetune your playstyle. I find nearly every character build to be viable although some are definitely more broken than others.There's several weapon classes (sword, daggers, combat staff, bow and arrow) with distinct combat differences, 10 spells (including Gravity Gun telekineses) many of which have additional or secondary functions (ice magic can freeze enemies as well as create slippery slopes on the floor if you feel like re-enacting Loony Toons routines with your enemies), stealth is almost always a possible option and then of course there's the environment kills and your almighty kick to the enemy's groin. You know what, I'm not even going to talk about those last two, just watch five minutes of a compilation on Youtube or something."Class mixing" is easily done and viable, but the real nice thing is that in any case one skill path doesn't neccessarily exclude you from anything else. Focusing on fighting also gives you access to decent daggers and staffs and the other way around, any build can use magic through collectable one-use-each scrolls, some weapons have magic extra effects, etc.The levels are varied and decently sized with tons of hidden areas and bonus objectives, although the route of plot progression in itself is rather linear.Speaking of plot, it's nothing special and about as unconventional and surprising as a harlequin romance novel.The game is definitely not without problems. While the most glaring ones from the early days have since been patched out there's still numerous bugs concerning crashes, glitching through walls, (occassional) framerate problems, save data not being found, exiting the game resulting in a crash which basically means you might as well exit through the Task Manager to begin with, and more. The entire reason I own this game on Steam is that in the original version there were some issues that were easiest resolved by re-installing which I ended up doing so often my disk just gave out (however, this in turn is just another point towards the game's immensely addicting qualities).The balancing can be wonky, weapon variety could be better and the sporadic platforming might turn some people off (being able to see your feet does help immensely though).At 5 bucks and even less when on sale it's an absolute steal for an unjustly forgotten gem of a game.Oh, one last thing:Everybody always talks about bad console-to-PC ports of games but if you ever want to see the reverse look no further than the horrendously butchered console version of this game. Damn, feels good to be PC Master Race.

												[h]Review for Dark Messiah of Might & Magic[/h1]  Game soon will be 10 years old and i can say that it has dated pretty good. Combat feels fluid, it's fun and doesn't feel repetitive. number of helpful: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												This game has the best melee combat I've experienced, but it's also sad that no other game has gotten close after more than 10 years. I played this game with nothing but the sword and shield, because it was so much fun. Most youtube videos show people killing enemies using magic or the bow, which only goes to prove how many different play styles this game allows for. During the Steam Awards, I nominated this game in the "choose your own category" section for The Most Creatively Silly Gameplay Award (and wrote this review to get a badge :P), since this is truly a slapsticktastic game. You can make orcs fall on their asses using an ice spell focused on the ground. You can throw enemies around like puppets using the Telekinesis spell when your Adrenaline meter is full. You can throw barrels at them to knock them on their asses. If you get a kick out of that, also know that you can kick enemies. The only thing more ridiculous than all of that, is how replayable it is. I played the demo like 20 times and still didn't get tired of it. While the game isn't always great, the fun parts are really fun to revisit.

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27
												A very good and very underrated game in my opinion! I bought Dark Messiah because it is a game related to one of my favorite strategy game franchises; Heroes of Might and Magic. The game itself does not much in common with the strategy ones, apart from the storyline, but the gameplay in general was really satisfying. The engine allows for some really neat mechanics and physics to be used (and even exploited in some situations) during combat, which is, for me, the best part of the game. The difficulty is trickier than some other first person RPGs I've played - in most situations you can't just click a button and slash through enemy lines, you have to utilize different strategies versus different enemy types. You have to take note of the environment and use it to your advantage! The story is mediocre, but an easy one to follow. There are a few choices you'd have to make and pick sides as the story progresses which I thought was a neat twist, but again it does not affect the game in a major aspect. I love this game, definitely recommending it!

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2016
												This game without a doubt has the best sword fighting in a game I have ever seen. There is a weight to the combat, and the enemies react in a believable way to getting hit and kicked. Arkane Studios is now known for Dishonored, but this game is completely incredible and should not be missed. It also has better sword combat than Dishonored. Kicking enemies off cliffs and into spikes does not get old. You will laugh endlessly when enemies fall through floors when you break them or set up other traps. The magic system works well too, and you don't have to be completely locked into just magic or just a melee character. An example of a spell, you can cast an ice spell to make enemies slip off cliffs or freeze them. The game also has stealth options that work pretty well. But again the real show is how well the sword system works. It just never gets old. I started playing this game in 2006, and have never stopped. I still can't believe how good it is. The storyline is good, and even if you haven't played the mainline Might and Magic games like me, you won't have trouble following the story. I can't find fault with any of the levels, they are fun to explore and by now, most of the bugs have been worked out. A non-issue with the game, is you will desperately want a sequel.

number of helpful: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												Arkane Studios and Floodgate Entertainment basically took the Source Engine and decided to make a game around its physics capabilities. The game wants you to utilize the environment as much as possible. Spikes, traps, barrels, cliffs, cranes, you bloody name it, you can use it to kill someone. It's pretty great. Progressing through areas is generally* linear, but you've got options on how to tackle content. You're rewarded for completing story objectives, so if you want to utilize a build that's light on combat, you're more than welcome to do so. *certain segments of the game are on-rails events, which kinda suck.The game understands dungeon crawling very well. If you've got a keen eye for detail, you'll spot lots of secrets. They're fairly well hidden and well presented. There's a few non-secret things you won't really find unless you get two certain talents, which kinda detracts from the experience, but at least the devs made sure they weren't secrets. The story and voice acting is...there. It exists. Don't take it too seriously (but do pay attention because there's a few interesting quirks). Soak up the awesome dungeon and world A E S T H E T I C S and use the physics engine to cause mayhem. You'll occasionally encounter some platforming, which isn't really all that intuitive considering you're playing in first person. Quicksave like a champ.It's got one really dumb and odd peculiarity: in certain parts of the game you'll need to open doors and porticulli. This basically requires you to hold down your use button (default E) for like 30 seconds, if you move around or release it too soon you're screwed and need to start all over again. You just sit here holding a button down for like a half a minute staring at walls. Otherwise the game is a very solid and fun experience. Would recommend.

content:
Posted: March 25
												Sure, the combat is loose and floaty. You can't really tell when any particular piece of steel of your own or that your enemy's is going to make contact. But that's not your primary ammunition -- it's your leg.They picked the right physics engine, because while the ornate traps they tried to create may have fallen flat, watching an orc's rag doll physics model tumble down a flight of stairs or off a cliff, is enough to forgive any faults in the game.And I've never kicked an orc down a flight of stairs in such beautiful, lush environments -- the graphics have aged well and still convey a sense of mystery and wonder.Conversely, the entirety of the story and its artifically branched endings feel bland and tacked on (particularly so for an RPG-ish title). But as I kick another orc off a mountain, I realize.. I just can't say mad.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Really REALLY good, like seriously good. Probably one of the best games I've played in quite a while.Do you like swords and high action combat?Did you enjoy Dishonored but didn't like how the game chastised you for killing people?Do you like paper thin plots that allow you to get to the action quicker?Do you like Ignoring weapons and using physics objects to kill people?Do you like kicking people off of cliffs?Then I've got the game for you, right here, this one.The swordplay is by far the best in any game I've ever seen, its very similar to Dishonored's swordplay (same devs) but it feels a lot more satisfying, and you can also throw almost every object in the world to completely ignore that great swordplay, also kicking, lots and lots of kicking. If there would be any comparison to make, Imagine thief, but with dark souls levels of combat, in first person. That is this game, this game right here, so good, so very very good.On a scale of 1 to 10 I'd give it an 8.5, while the gameplay is really, really good, it doesn't give you quite enough downtime to make the mechanics not feel stale after a while. Also enemy variety is sorely lacking.(enemy with sword, enemy with sword and shield, archer, zombie, mage, faster zombie and spiders.) There's a few neat boss monsters, and by a few I mean like 3, despite there being 6ish boss fights in the game, meaning that they get re-used often (I swear i've fought 4 cyclopses by now, once you figure out that only their head takes damage, the fight gets a little less epic. Also the plot is almost complete garbage, the only meaningful choice you get is one where you decide on whether or not you want to use a demon form (useless outside of very narrow circumstances) or a SLIGHTLY better sword than the one you already have.There's a perk based leveling system in the game that gets in the way of having fun more than it helps, you have to UNLOCK the ability to do a jumping attack, which is literally you just holding your sword upwards and slashing down. You may as well just give yourself all the upgrades at the beggining with cheats. Besides those two things, the games is pretty much perfect. All the maps are neat and unique (although the "orc tunnels go on a little longer than I would have liked) and up until the very end you're going through a very nice dungeon crawl.So yeah, this is a good game, pick it up when you can, even if you have to wait for it to be on sale, it's worth it.

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
Hail to the king, baby!No, it's not Duke Nukem, but the second-most mighty boot in all of gaming.Join Sareth and companion - his size 12♥♥♥♥♥♥kickers - on an adventure to rid the land of evil, carried forth by kicking orcs from ledges, into burning pits, or into plentiful and strategically placed walls of spikes. So much orc kicking even Boromir came back from the dead and shed a tear.Released in 2006, Dark Messiah takes full advantage of the Source engine, giving us plenty of fun physics to play with. Anything and everything becomes a weapon; whether you throw around crates, push enemies into the path of a swinging chandelier or just make them one with the floor with a well-placed freeze spell. Nine years later, it's a wonder why not more developers have taken advantage of this type of combat system.The typical RPG archtypes are all here, whether you choose to play as sword and board warrior, dress-wearing wizard, or♥♥♥♥♥♥ass thief. The skill tree keeps things fresh and gives you some variety as you progress. Unfortunately for the Elder Scrolls fans, there is not enough skill points to allow you to be proficient in everything, meaning you will have to plan your playstyle out in advance and stick with it.The plot is fleshed out well enough, but won't win any awards in storytelling. The combat is exciting yet frustrating as you load save for the tenth time trying to hack your way through another difficult bottleneck. The multiplayer aspect is unfortunately almost non-existant.If you've got a few bucks to spend when this game goes on sale, it is a highly worthwhile title worthy of multiple playthroughs.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2012
												Dark Messiah of Might and Magic was an attempt to branch out the otherwise stagnant Might & Magic franchise, and it should be remembered as one of the better attempts by all of those that played a little of Might & Magic's foray into the real time strategy genre, now that was a bad idea if I ever saw one. It's a Source engine action RPG. Unlike the usual Might & Magic RPGs it takes a much more mainstream approach to just about everything and anybody that's play even a little of modern RPG's will quickly find themselves at ease with the simplicity of it all.Gone are the exploration and everything else that made Might & Magic unique. Only the name and some of the lore remains. Not that I am completely opposed to ignore part of the Might & Magic lore, I was never that excited about the whole space aliens bit. Unfortunately this leaves the game feeling shallow. It's a game that saw what everyone else was doing and thought, "Hey, me too!".In terms of gameplay Dark Messiah is the worlds most premiere kicking simulator. It's an odd thing really, Dark Messiah has weapons, skills and magic but you'll find yourself using nothing but your boot to dispatch the vast majority of foes. The harder the difficulty is turned up the easier and more tempting it becomes to kick your enemies into spikes and off ledges simply because it's an instakill maneuver more often than not and your weapons and magic will never be able to match it for damage except in that extremely rare location where there is no environmental hazards to kick enemies into.The storyline is fairly decent, a little predictable at times but nothing worth complaining about. There is a pretend storyline choice or two that does have a little impact so that helps greatly.In terms of graphics and sounds it's the source engine and that all comes down to style and Dark Messiah falls squarely into the "Okay" range. Nothing too impressive but nothing that'll ruin your experience either. You'll never be in awe of it but you'll never get annoyed with it either.The multi-player component is fairly decent although it was always a graveyard so without friends it was impossible to play.Besides all the kicking Dark Messiah ranks as a not too bad game. It does nothing stellar, it doesn't even try to, but it does provide a decent enough experience that it's worth it to play through the once. And if you're feeling particularly feisty, you can challenge yourself by making a hard "No-Kicking" playthrough and watch the difficulty skyrocket.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												2006, arguably the heyday of PC gaming. Few first-person games got the mechanics so right as Dark Messiah did.  Built on the Source Engine, it pulls everything Half Life 2 had going for it into itself.- You have a body visible in first-person view! Look down! I have feet!- Telekinesis allows for "gravity gun" fun! And other spells for messing with the locals!- Duke Nukem's Mighty Boot, for punting Goblins off cliffs to your delight! Ahhh the screams!- The Rope Bow! When most games were consigned to stairs and ladders, you could go anywhere!*- Scripted events done right! With huge monsters and huge weapons!- Combat any way you want! Stealth, magic, a massive sword! Did I mention the Mighty Boot??-Mild RPG elements like upgrading your weapons/armour and spending skill points in skill trees (more like Bonsai trees, but still fun!)- Be Good or Evil! Multiple endings based on your choices throughout the game!- First-Person combat unmatched before or since! This is how the Elder Scrolls should have done it!!! Watch the vids, kids!Pros:LOTS! (It's five bucks as of this review too!)Cons:A matter of opinion. Find them all! Don't forget your jaded self is living 10 years into this game's existence. Everything seen here was first!** Full disclosure: I owned this game before it came to Steam and have a couple hundred hours in it through three playthroughs...TL;DR? No it isn't! You owe it to yourself to buy this game and thank Arkane Studios for their existence!!

												Great game. Awesome gameplay and great storyline. You level up and can choose skills in which type of gameplay you want. You can use a bow for ranged combat, daggers for close and stealthy kills, a staff, or you could use the classic Sword and Shield. Or a 2 handed sword. content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												Admit it, how many times you wished to explore every single nook and cranny even in a linear game, but the game itself stopped you from doing just that?How many times you wished to just behead your enemy and then kick their head around like a football? Pick them up with Telekinesis, then just toss them straight up, relishing in their screams? Having Sword Clashes ("Contests of Might" in game language) where the enemy gets Disarmed if you win and yet they still try to fight you using only their bare fists? Freezing up the floor in front of the enemy and then watch them just slip and fall with absolutely no grace?Making friends out of Goblins and even an ORC as long as you don`t hurt them?Then this game is for you. Maybe it`s linear and still has its own share of glitches, especially if you tend to "sequence-break", which will happen a lot if you absolutely despise escort NPCs, but the combat system, interactive surroundings (throw rocks, ignite patches of oil, break barrels, trigger traps and more!) and a big replayability factor all make up for it. A fair warning for players that absolutely despise crypt levels tho, this game is LOADED with those and since we also acquire the Rope Bow as well as Master Thief outfit, the latter demanding your character to be the ultimate sneaking machine, you probably know which game franchise is being referenced there. ;) :,D Only that in this game, we can shoot heads off the undead with a single arrow if being skilled enough, ha ha ha! >:DAbsolute classic and a must-have game to play, even if it`s only 10 years old nowadays when compared to its older spiritual predecessors like Arx Fatalis. Too bad its Multiplayer part is pretty much dead tho, but well, some things just cannot stand without help from the devs and anti-hacker protection. :(
