Posted: December 18, 2013
												Dark Messiah Might and Magic is a great action-packed Linear RPG. Graphics are good, Voice acting is decent, Storyline may be a bit lacking, but the combat is the redeeming factor. I sometimes wish that more games will adopt the combat system that Dark Messiah Might and Magic created. Running around rooms and throwing chairs, barrels, crates, etc. is awesome and not to mention kicking your enemy whether it's into his ally or off a cliff. On a side note... if you have arachnophobia be aware of the Temple of the Spider... I hear of mods that change the giant spiders into pigs, but have never tried one. I personally got through it with the audio turned off to avoid the hissing of those 8 legged monsters. I'd consider this game a bit on the short side, but Dark Messiah has enough choices, in leveling and story choices, to validate atleast 2 play throughs.

Posted: July 6, 2014
												This is a pretty interesting game. It's built on Source, and looks pretty good for the time. The mechanics are introduced in a fashion that doesn't leave you with many questions and the gameplay is pretty solid. There's a basic RPG framework built into the game that allows you to choose specialisation in three different primary areas of mastery. Stealth, Magic, and Weaponmastery. The enemy variety is mixed up enough to keep you from getting too bored, but the formula is pretty much the same for most humanoid enemies. The game includes a kick that has the ability to knock back a lot of enemies, and the game liberally places hazards for you to take advantage of, so most often it's a lot easier for you to just kick someone off of a ledge or into spikes than actually fight them.I feel the game is geniunely very difficult without taking the heal spell from the mage tree, but other than that, you can play the game without there being too many necessary skills. I would say that it's mandatory to either get magic or bows, however.

												The Ubisoft game that uses the same engine as Half-life 2, Dark messiah: might and magic. This game brings you into a first person melee combat game that also uses RPG elements. Posted: April 5, 2016
												This game is simply amazing. For an old game it has very nice graphics, interesting storyline and awesome gameplay. The combat system is really fun, especially with kicking. The game invites you to use the environment around you to your advantage, rather than just sticking to the usual combat methods. Plus it's always hilarious kicking enemies off the ledges and watch them fly XD! The other thing that is really awesome is the exploration element, there are some not-so-obvious places that you can get to find secret areas which most of the time contain very rewarding treasures. All that being said, I really wish that the game was longer, I felt it was way too short and too linear, I think it definetly deserves more. Also there are a couple of annoying glitches that are not patched, they are not game-breaking but very annoying. I would like to try the multiplayer but there doesn't seem to be many that play the game anymore. In the end, it's a very fun game and an awesome experience, I highly recommend it.

Posted: February 22, 2014
												Ok, before people start bashing this game for the admittedly terrible voice acting and lame plot, consider what this game does. It is an action RPG that focuses on being smarter and more skilled than the NPCs. Sure, you could charge at an enemy and beat them to death with your sword; OR, you could shoot them with your bow, crush them with collapsable scaffolding, drop them down a pit, down some stairs, hit them with barrels, kick them into spikes, burn them, kick them into each other, or stab them in the back. The level up system is kinda lackluster, and does seem like it takes forever to get some useful skills. If you RPG damage sponges want a game that doesn't require much thought to play, by all means, don't buy this game. If you are looking for an RPG that challenges you on multiple levels and prefer gameplay to plot and VAs, give this a shot. A good plot does not make a bad game better, but a bad story doesn't hinder a good game.

Posted: September 20, 2015
												Decent action-adventure hack&slash game with some RPG elements (skillpoints doesn't make a game a RPG) made with Source engine. Interesting story where you can make some choices which will affect the story and how the game ends. It has good voice acting and they have succeeded in making the woman talking in you're head one of the most annoying persons ever in a game and it gave me great satisfaction when I was finally able to get rid of her. The graphics are good enough for game from 2006 but there are many other source games which look much better than this (like HL2 or Portal).I played it on Hard difficulty and the enemies often one-shotted me, sometimes it felt unfair as harder difficulty makes the enemies tanks who take lots of hits before they die and some enemies are almost immune to fire or lighting, so in the beginning and middle of the game playing as wizard it will get very hard as you run out of the mana very often. The kick is one of the most powerful attacks of the game, if there is cliff, spikes or fire nearby you can kill almost any enemy with one kick, so it's good backup attack for Wizard, but for melee character kicking makes the game too easy. The game takes about 12h to finish, but there is replay value as you can make different builds with different story choices. Recommended for anyone who enjoys action oriented fantasy with small RPG elements.

Posted: August 20, 2011
												"Does Dark Messiah have an epic story with a lot of character development"? No. "Does Dark Messiah have a deep level of player choice and consequence"? Whether you are chopping an opponent's head off with an axe in slow motion, stabbing a cyclops through the eye, or goring someone through with your sword, the combat remains fun in itself, and each enemy encounter, even with mooks, is always challenging yet satifying and every fight is different.Oh, and boot♥♥♥♥. You can boot♥♥♥♥ people off cliffs, into spiked walls, off bridges, into the ocean, onto sharp rocks, into giant spiders, out windows, into other enemies, weak supports, and more. You can kill people with a COFFIN.

Posted: June 28, 2012
												The Good: Great visuals and voice acting, decent story, fun deep combat, lots of upgrades to get, tons of items to useThe Bad: Little in variety of enemy types, very linear, combat is tedious after awhile, semi-poor level design, HL2 engine is starting to look oldBefore I start here Dark Messiah suffered bad reviews because of all the terrible bugs that launched with the game. now that 2 1/2 years have passed Dark Messiah's bugs have been pretty much been ironed out and you now have a pretty fun action RPG. Before I start explaining the game DM uses the Half-Life 2 engine so you can expect some wonderful graphics and effects. DM uses the HL2 engine very well, but the engine is a bit supped up so you'll need a fairly beefy rig to run this game. If you computer was being pushed with HL2 then your computer will have a hard time running this game. I also have to mention that DM felt a lot like Oblivion Lite in the sense that it is set in Medieval times, melee combat is first person, and the art style is a little like Oblivion (not as unique of course).You play as a young protagonist named Sareth and you must stop the evil Arantir from using the Skull Crystal and bringing the Dark Messiah back to life. You have a choice to either stop him yourself or let the Dark Messiah live on. The story is actually fairly interesting and will keep you on the edge throughout this 15-20 hour adventure. Now DM is a linear RPG (it's not free roaming like Oblivion), but makes up for it with a intricate combat system. You have about 30-40 different item slots and you can carry things from health, mana, weapons, magic etc. As you progress through the game you will earn skill points for completing objectives and you can upgrade a variety of things from endurance, health, stealth, archery skill, learn new skills such as heal, fire arrow, freeze, sanctuary etc. There's a lot to learn and you won't upgrade 100% in a play through. You can either concentrate on being a Knight, Mage, or Archer or just go down the middle.There are a variety of unique weapons you can pick up throughout the adventure such as the awesome rope bow (shoot an arrow at any wood overhanging and a rope will come down), ice staffs, flame swords, poison daggers, and even a cool electricity shield that stuns enemies when they attack you. Now there are no shops where you can buy things so everything has to be picked up throughout the world. This keeps the action constantly going, but will disappoint people who are used to having stores in their RPGs.Combat consists of left clicking for your basic attack, but if you hold it down you do a Power Strike and whether or not you strafe, move forward, or backward will determine whether it's a side swipe, impale, or overhead strike. This can let you easily dodge attack and quickly strike back. You can use the right mouse button to block (and when you get the ability) left clicking to knock enemies back. Hit enough bad guys and you'll get your adrenaline bar up and this results in a gory slow-mo instant kill. This applies to all weapons and each of them have their own unique advantages to them. You have a kick button and this is great when you are on a ledge so you can just kick them off. Every so often you'll find spike beds on walls you can impale enemies on, also you'll find traps that can be kicked down to crush enemies.While the combat is really fun and you can do a lot with it; it will get repetitive after about half way through unless you use different weapons and toss things up. Every so often you'll find a blacksmith room where you can add bars of metal and forge your own weapons. Now when it comes to enemies there aren't to many of them (knights, undead, spiders, necromancers, evil demons) and that's about it. They are mixed up a lot, but you still can get bored of them after awhile.Every so often, though, you will get a great boss fight and these are huge creatures that require key items in the environment to kill them. These are pretty awesome and are very satisfying to take down. My biggest complaint must be the level design. A lot of times you won't find most of the hidden secret areas since they aren't even in places you'd remotely think they'd be in. There will be times you'll wonder around for over 30 minutes in the same place wondering where to go and this has to do with poor level design. The levels are very linear, most of the time dark, and really hard to navigate. Other than this Dark Messiah is a pretty good game, and you can even get it off Steam for $10! I highly recommend Dark Messiah to any action RPG fan.~Score: 8/10

Posted: March 4
												I finished it. in 8,7 hours.Of course it was singleplayer only, while the game has multiplayer mode, i don't think multiplayer will and can be finished.So if this game is really short, why am i recommend it?First of all, imo i like the characters, i don't feel forgetting/discarding easily of these characters, They actually felt alive and thus will not be forgotten so easily.While the game is made in source engine, many would say like"Wow, those physics are going to be gud"Not in my experience, although i think it was likely the developer's fault rather than source engine's fault. One of the problem is slidey movement, it's like taking your time to stop rather than a full, quick stop, in other word you'll die to gravity more than the enemy itself.And the combat is a little bit more different from most RPG games, it felt more like Chivalry style gameplay rather arcadey -i'll-just-hit-everything-accidentially. So you need to watch where you hit, supported by the different attacks even performed by a single weapon.This game is made in 2006, so you can't really judge it's graphics but i think it has good graphics at it's own age. Music felt nice, nothing special.In my experience, i've had numerous amount of crashes, i didn't really sure it was on my end or it was the game itself. Because of this i'd say this game is normal, nothing special, not bad, not great.I'd recommend buying this game on a sale, didn't think really worth it on full price. Hell i've got this for half a dollar.

Posted: September 13, 2014
												Probably the best and most satisfying first person RPG combat system ever. Blocking, combos and plain aimed hits are intuitive and responsive. Story, graphics and level design are alright, being on Source engine. Any TES game is ages longer, but even with mods their combat system feels crippled and stupid compared to this.Think HL2 EP1 as an RPG.

Posted: October 11, 2011
												Probably the first action-RPG I've ever played with a truly interactive combat environment.  Imagine being in a swordfight along the edge of a cliff, then reveling as a swift kick results in that guard you were dueling with falling hundreds of feet off the edge... to his DOOM! Or... fighting with some foes, you spot some spikes protruding from the side of a wall in the room. With a nice kick, that orc you were fighting falls onto the spikes, getting impaled on them! There are a few other things I could add, but you get the idea. The game also has some pretty nice combat animations for a first person RPG. Doing a power-stroke with your sword, some of these animations can involve driving your sword clear through the gut of your foes, then kicking their corpse off the blade with a well placed kick, resulting in showers of blood. Uses the Source engine.Warning: though fun, the game is EXTREMELY buggy. Fortunately it's also cheap! (And imo worth it at this price).

Posted: March 4
												I finished it. in 8,7 hours.Of course it was singleplayer only, while the game has multiplayer mode, i don't think multiplayer will and can be finished.So if this game is really short, why am i recommend it?First of all, imo i like the characters, i don't feel forgetting/discarding easily of these characters, They actually felt alive and thus will not be forgotten so easily.While the game is made in source engine, many would say like"Wow, those physics are going to be gud"Not in my experience, although i think it was likely the developer's fault rather than source engine's fault. One of the problem is slidey movement, it's like taking your time to stop rather than a full, quick stop, in other word you'll die to gravity more than the enemy itself.And the combat is a little bit more different from most RPG games, it felt more like Chivalry style gameplay rather arcadey -i'll-just-hit-everything-accidentially. So you need to watch where you hit, supported by the different attacks even performed by a single weapon.This game is made in 2006, so you can't really judge it's graphics but i think it has good graphics at it's own age. Music felt nice, nothing special.In my experience, i've had numerous amount of crashes, i didn't really sure it was on my end or it was the game itself. Because of this i'd say this game is normal, nothing special, not bad, not great.I'd recommend buying this game on a sale, didn't think really worth it on full price. Hell i've got this for half a dollar.

Posted: October 17, 2015
												[Note: I only have 5 hours on record, because I already owned the game long before I had a Steam account.]This game still has the best combat mechanics of all the first-person games I ever played.Not to say combat is perfect. It can feel quite clunky at times, but there are so many features and options for any battle that "tactics" actually are an applicable term here.Combat is interesting and varied from the start, but the available actions are expanded along the course of the game, by unlockable skills. This skill system also gives the game some replay value, since you're unlikely to be able to unlock all of them.A downside are the dated graphics, or more specifically the obvious lack of details, regarding the game world.

Posted: July 9, 2011
												I don't really think that this game justifies the mediocre scores it achieved. It's not cutting edge - after all it uses the Source engine familiar in many FPS's. But this has got a number of novelties in it - a few extras that make you think the developers thought quite in depth about this hybrid of RPG and FPS.It's much more action focused than say Oblivion, but in doing so, sacrifices a lot of the depth of that game. Sometimes the controls are a little fiddly and the enemy manages to score hits on you when clearly they didn't. Seemingly difficult situations like a horde of spiders in their lair can simply be defeated by running in circles around them and hacking away.Dark Messiah is best viewed as a Source mod. When taken in that context, it's really very enjoyable - with some excellent dialogue and set pieces. Don't think of it as a ground breaking RPG, as it clearly isn't. But it carves out a welcome niche for itself within the genre. 7.5

Posted: January 26, 2016
												What a good game. As you may have seen, I haven't played this game much (I have about two hours put into this game currently), but I'm deciding to write a review anyway. This game is good. Combat was challenging yet very creative and fun at the same time. You could face several enemies at the same time or just kick them all of a ledge. Skill system was great, no certain path for what "class" you may have wanted to take, but just some skills to choose from which you can easily mix and match. You could be half assasin half wizard and everything would work out just fine. Or you could go only melee, doesn't matter. Story (so far) isn't special, but it's not bad. Characters weren't very special either, but the gameplay makes up for it. Graphics aren't fancy but they run well on any low-end computer, so no one should worry about running the game. I rate 8.5/10. Very much worth the $10.

Posted: January 19, 2016
												I don't even know where to start. This game ♥♥♥♥ing ROCKS! Great setting, awesome characters. And the shining point is the combat. Played as a hybrid fighter/mage and had a blast. Ledge or staircase + Freezing spell = UNCONTROLABLE CHUCKLES. Looking around the enviroment for spikes, pits or flimsy wooden beams to kick enemies into is a great way of slaughtering those filthy orcs and undead. Also fine to pick up a jar, big rock or a broom and throw it at a necromancers bald ugly head!You can even literaly (and often) THROW A BARREL AT IT!  (Pro-tip yo, lite that barrel on fire; it's wood and burns, enemies can go up in flames)The number of different ways to kill enemies (enviroment hazards, with spells like lightning bolt and fireball, different weapons or tricks like liting an arrow with a nearby fire to make a fire arrow!) had me interested throughtout my entire play through. Also, the old school puzzle elements, secert areas and a bow that shoots a freaking arrow with a rope that you can climb where very enjoyable.I would like to come back to this game again some time in the future and try out a sneak/dagger archer build. I think that will be so much fun. The story is fantastic, and I like how both the romantic leads are manipulating the main character. It was a really tough choice for me to choose at the end. The voice acting is awesome. Moon Dailly, (the actress that voiced Xana) did a great job. Everyone else was also pretty well voiced. The only problem with this game is dated graphics, but considering its AGE this game looks freaking awesome. Even the cinimatics have aged very well. It looks decent. Not amazing but not bad either.Truely a great game in so many ways. AND NO SECOND GAME!? WTF! how this just got dropped I'll never know...BTW: If your interested in a bit more lore of this story and a couple of it's characters; check out Heroes of Might and Magic 6. In the Infernal Campaign if you make Kirie a Mage > Hellcaller You get XANA! as a companion. It's pretty cool.

Posted: January 19
												Still one of my favorite games ever. Well designed levels, a pretty good combat system and the source engine still looks good.However this game has some minor bugs and is not perfectly polished, which isn't worse than is most other games.

Posted: December 27, 2013
												One of the best hack n' slash games ever. You control the character Sareth, but you can roleplay his character to an extent, by changing the story every once in a while, and choosing how he fights. The gameplay is what makes the game so great. You can use stealth, magic, and direct combat, and excel at your favorite path with skill points distributed throughout the story, or create a satisfying mix to your liking. There are so many ways to play the game, and they are all unique and fun. All the levels lend themselves to how you have moulded Sareth, and all the different skills shine brilliantly. It will be a fun, challenging game that you will want to play more than once, and will be the most fun hack & slash RPG for a long time.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												Arcane Studios second big game Dark Messiah of Might & Magic stands the test of time, by providing fast paced meele Action with great physical elements. After their Hommage to the Ultima Series "Arx Fatalis" Arcane created this truly unique game as part of Ubisofts relaunch of the equally important Might & Magic Franchise. The Story takes place a generation after the Story of the turn based Heroes of Might & Magic V. You are Sareth a young wizard's apprentice tasked with accompanying a expedition in search for a ancient artifact "The Skull of Shadows". The story is mostly a backdrop to the real core mechanics of the game. Those of the combat. You have the choice between very distinct playstyles. Charge into Meele with Magic Assistance? Use the rudimentary stealth system to sneak and assassinate your enemies avoiding their reinforcments in the process? Be a Archer that falls back on fast daggers or fast swordplay? Lay traps to soften your enemies to uttely destroy with Elemental magic?This promised and marketed Diversity of Playstyle still holds true to this day. The great level design caters to most playstyles and offers a great amount of secrets and ways to overcome opposition.All in all an amazing experience that still shows it's influence in the game systems of Dishonored and Dishonored 2.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												Not super popular and in my opinion, underrated, this is still one of my favorite games.  It's a fun balance for me of being hard enough to feel rewarding but easy enough that you can play around with the different combinations of ways to kill opponents.Really some of my favorite moments simply involved hiding in some dark corner and shooting ice arrows at the feet of enemies who stood at the top of a flight of stairs.  Goblins or necromancers just absolutely befuddled as to why the stairs are so slippery this morning and why they keep falling down them and into their goblin or necromancer friends, knocking them over in the process.  Play Yakety Sax in the background for enhanced mood.  I was once able to fire an arrow at a guard, kill him, and pin him to one of his guard buddies who still ran around looking for the person who shot his buddy who was now pinned to his back.  The ability to do that made me smile, the situation itself made me laugh, and the rag doll physics involved made milk come out of my nose and I wasn't even drinking milk, I was drinking coffee.  An arrow, a torch, a stack of barrels.  A flaming orc, more flaming barrels, lots of flailing around and catching environment and other orcs on fire and falling off cliffs.  High comedy and sure to cheer you up when your're feeling down.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												This game is still enjoyable after all these many years. While the story may not be the most complicated affair out there, there are plenty of fun enemies, varied environments that make the best out of the Source engine from back in the day and a satisfying fluidity to one- or two-handed melee fights that a lot of other games (most modern games?) lack. Once you got used to kicking your enemies down a ledge or into some spikes, you'll play other first person games and wonder why no other developer ever made use of your player character's legs in that way. Intuitive and fun! I often find myself saving at certain parts in the game only to then try out all possible ways to kill all enemies using whatever traps / props / means the environment and spells/equipment one carries provide.A few of the levels can be a bit hard to navigate and one gets lost here and there, but at least in some cases this adds to the immersion, for the most part though this is a strictly linear game; you won't be going back and forth a lot. Very well worth a shot if you haven't played this yet! Just be nice to the poor goblins and orcs, I feel kinda sorry for 'em getting kicked around all day! x]

Posted: November 17, 2016
												This game has one of the best combat systems that I have even experienced. The combat just makes sense. Find an enemy standing near a cliff and want to take them out quickly? Just give them a good kick off of the edge. Rag dolls work as you would expect. They don't fly across the map like some other games, but instead they act much more naturally. It has actually been quite a while since I last played this, so I do not remeber a ton of details. All that I remember is that the combat was top notch, and the game overall was a great experience.Definantly worth a try.Note: I never attempted multiplayer, and I'm not even sure if it works at all. Never was interested in that part of the game.I have reinstalled the game and played it for a few hours. The first few hours were pretty good. After about 3 hours I had my first crash. The crashes (so far) are not too bad. They only happen occasionally. It may get worse later in the game though.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												This game has so many equally good and bad things going for it. + Half life 2 engine still looks gorgeous. The art here is pretty generic D&D but the models are nice and the entire atmosphere is very well done. Music is moody as well.+ This game is challenging. If you turn the difficulty all the way up, it's just like playing Dark Souls but in first person! Even a single zombie can kill you. If I didn't use all the combination of weapons I had (swords, daggers, bows) and also magic, I couldn't get past even the 3rd chapter. This is NOT a game to go hack/slash in. You will die as quick as you start fighting. + The RPG elements are fun and although aren't as deep as any traditional RPG, they are fun to mess around with. I played as a pyromaniac swordsman and it was definitely fun! BUT read the final negative below point as well.+ Lots of ways to set off physical traps and kill you enemies with. For example, cut a rope holding up a bunch of logs and watch it fall down on your enemies. Never gets tiring.+ The game is barely more than 10 hours long. First playthrough anyway but because of last point, there's moderate to high replayability.+You can kick enemies into spikes and pits.- There are lots of bugs. I encountered a lot anyway. Graphical, like black boxes appearing over my spells when fired. Controls, like assigning a spell to a number on my keyboard and not having the spell come up even though I pressed the corresponding number several times. This gets very annoying especially when you're in a tight situation and want to change your weapon or change to a spell. It just doesn't work sometimes. Sound bugs, as in voice overs repeating or missing or playing in the wrong places which could mislead the player. As I said, lots of bugs.- Platforming is CRAP. It was bad in Half Life games and it's still bad here. And the fact that there's almost a high amount of it in the game makes it the more painful. You even have a bow which extends a rope down for you to climb and this gives possibilities to explore more of the world or just get past levels but the jumping and walking controls are so loose that it just doesn't work in an enjoyable way.- Most of the time your objective becomes VERY obscure and I personally got lost a lot in most of the maps simply because the exit to some rooms were so out of sight and unlikely to be where they actually are that I needed to look at walkthroughs in some places just to know how to get out of a certain dungeon.- The story is almost non-existent. Don't come into this expecting any cohesive, attractive story or ending. Even though there are 4 endings, they are alll equally predictable and not worth playing the game for. - multiplayer is long dead. Unless you have other friends who have the game on steam. But it's nothing special. Passable.- Most of the time, the game throws loads and loads of enemies at you which seems more like what a shooter would do than a game like this. Soon it becomes such a chore to manage a crowd of 5 ferral ghouls who are attacking you from all sides.- The RPG elements are fun but really unbalanced. You find so many weapons from the 3rd chapter on that you can't equip way into the game unless you were super pin-pointed towards a certain role (fighter, archer,white mage, black mage, thief). If you want to spread out a little like, say, be a white mage/thief, you're not going to accumulate enough upgrade points to truly be that until the very end levels of the game. That seems pointless to me as well as the fact that some classes like archers and thiefs will never be strong enough to take on most of the enemies in a game which is so close-combat oriented. The fact that you don't get any experience from defeating enemies but only from story checkpoints is a very bad choice to me. As you see, I can say the game has much potential and I am going to give it a thumbs up even though it annoyed and frustrated me as much as I enjoyed some of its better moments. If you're willing to risk, give it a go. I'm sure you'll find your own reason to like it. It tries to be deeper than what it is and sometimes that's both a blessing and a curse.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												(quick note: I played this game off Steam for many, many hours. I know what I'm talking about!)Dark Messiah is a really interesting case of a game being completely carried by a single gameplay element.In most respects, this game is unremarkable. It takes place in the Might and Magic universe, but bears almost no resemblance to its namesake. In fact, the only thing "M&M" about this game is the villain being a member of the necromancer faction. If you took the word "necromancer" out of the script, it would just be another generic fantasy world. The story is extremely simplistic and transparently linear; the average dialogue will be "I am <name>. The <Macguffin> is at <location>. I will <plot>. Good luck!" Sometimes, the only thing pushing you forward at all is the knowledge that you're in a videogame and have an objective. As for the characters... Sareth, the protagonist, only speaks to complain or prompt other characters to provide exposition ("What is <Macguffin>?" or "I'm tired of staring at a horse's ears"), Xana is just a sultry tease-dispenser ("You did all of this for a hug. If I were there..."), Leah is the hopeful love interest ("With you here, we should have the <Macguffin> in no time!"), and every other character has too few lines to even be described. Combine this mediocrity with a scrabbled-together Source engine full of bugs and freezes and you get an overall disappointing experience. Well, except for one BIG thing...The combat in this game is sublime. Attacks are directional, animations flow into each other seamlessly, combos feel satisfying, and the environment is RIFE with opportunities to punish your opponents, with plenty of blood and gibbing to reward you for the effort. There are three combat styles: melee, ranged, and magic, and each style has substyles (for example, melee has sword-and-board, staves, daggers, sneak attacks and backstabbing, and so on). Fighting in this game just feels good. There's one level in particular which gives you a compound full of easy-to-kill goblins and lets you wreak havoc however you wish. I won't lie, I love to reload that level and play it over... and over... and over... and over, trying out different methods for mass murder. Perhaps most satisfying is the synergy you can develop between styles. For example, you can shoot a blackguard in the leg from behind, then tear his head off while he's limping. However, the most iconic moment in this game is when you kick an enemy into a spiked wall or off of a cliff. Seriously; if you thought you already had the most satisfying kicking experience you could in a game, YOU THOUGHT WRONG. The kicking alone makes this game "good", and the rest of the combat bumps it up to "memorable".Should you buy this game? Well, have you ever wanted to kick an orc into a pillar holding up the wall of the building, causing the wall to crash down and kill a dozen orcs and goblins before they can react? Have you ever wanted to beat a crowd of people to death using the dead body of one of their friends? Have you ever wanted to slit a foe's throat and kick their dying body off of a cliff above the clouds? Most importantly of all, have you ever wanted to beat an entire video game by just kicking people into stuff? If any of these sounded like fun, you should probably drop a couple bucks on this game.P.S. The multiplayer is fun if you can get a couple people together for it. It's a real kickapalooza.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												Don't confuse this game with the other "Heroes of might and magic" games. This is a entierly new game. Everything from the universe to the genre is completly changed. The game plays very much like Dishonored, as Arkane studios is the developer of both games. (*cough* also a bit like the recent theif 4 game as edios kind of ripped of about everything, and then dumbed it down*cough*). This means that you can play the game like you want to play it, you can go about any problem your own way, be it sneaking, backstabbing the crap out of everything, to just improvising and just throwing random props you find on the floor. Or maybe you go about it with magic or raw strengthThis is NOT an open world rpg, and it does not try nor need to be. Much like dishonored the "maps" are open linear. It is a big, well designed map (that you will not find in any openworld game as it would take to much time to design), that has lots of thoughts behind it, with loads of variety. The levels can be explored and very often interacted with. I often find myself drifting around, looking for secrets, or new ways to kill enemies. "humm that 12 meters statue looks fragile, maybe i can destroy... OH GOD ITS FALLING RUN!!". Some parts inbetween levels are linear, be it jumping between rooftops in a frantic chase, it still feels authentic and as if it has a part in the game. The niche of this game is the phisics. Be it kicking people into spikes, throwing barrels, kicking orcs of clips you name it. Combat is fluid, active and varied. The enviroment is a weapon that you will need to use. There are lots of diffrent weapons, with diffrent "enchantments". The combat is not only skill in the heat of battle but also choosing the right tool for the jobb, as using a firesword to hit a demon is not the greatest idea. in other words use logic when choosing weapons. As far story goes, you are Sereath accompanied by Xana (the weird sarcastic woman stuck in your head), trying to find the skull of shadows, an ancient artifact, part of the legend fortelling the doom of mankind "something something".The story is fairly predicteble, but nonetheless worth experiencing. It's not bad because even though the story is a classic cliche, it is well executed. Just dont expect a bioshock infinite.This game remains to date, as one of my favorite games of all time. Good work arkane studios!

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												I bought an hard copy (DVD) of this game around 2008 and indeed I had much fun with it.  It's your standard "Action RPG" and the gameplay is mainly focused on melee combat, however you can use bows and magic projectiles as well. By progressing trough the game, ie. completing the quest (which are in linear succession) and killing enemies you earn experience and skill points which you can put into Combat, Magic or Mixed Skill trees. You also aquire objects. Some of these require you to have a particular skill, so choose well.Although usually the game is a first-person "hack and slash", you also have sections where you are unharmed (and muct avoid enemies) or you must chase an enemy through rooftops etc...The gameplay is fairly linear, this is not a sandbox or open world RPG, but it's fun. Sometimes the combat can get a bit repetitive, but it is satisfying overall.One of the main perks of the combat is the variety of ways you can kill your opponents. You can used situational hazards like fire or spikes and kick your opponents into them to kill them. You can also pick up objects such as crates, vases or shovels to throw at them, you can kick them off ledges, rooftops, etc.There is some witty humor in the game and the story, although perhaps not innovative is quite interesting. GRAPHICS: very nice... still hold up to this day... it has aged fairly well. Only problem often things are too damn dark (which is easily solved by the "night vision" spell you get at the beginning at the game and uses no mana)AUDIO: nice music and voice acting is decent. Only complaint is your own footsteps. If you are wearing earphones it sounds like someone is banging at the door when you walk... you simply can't immerse yourself into a stealthy gameplay when you sound like that when walking...GAMEPLAY: nice combat system, fun and satisfying, although a bit repetitive sometimes. Might be a bit tough in the beginning (getting the healing spell REALLY helps), but it's not a very hard game (not on normal difficulty at least)Also the game offers a variety of locations, which is nice.TECHNICAL: Worked fine on Windows XP and Windows 7 (when I played w my physical copy) and works fine with windows 8.1 too. Not sure why some people complain... Maybe Win10 is screwing this game too? ((many negative reviews on older games indeed relate on the fact that they are unplayable on Win10))It's quite stable (never run into big bugs)---So overall I am recommending this game. I re-bought it on STEAM (although I still have a physical disk somewhere) for like 1 US dollar or so... truly a bargain.  Normal price is like 4 dollars anyway... still a bargain! If you like action RPGs Dark Messiah is right up your alley!

content:
Posted: January 8
HOW TO APPRECIATE COMBAT: read before playing.You won't like combat if you treat it like a normal game. THIS IS NOT A COMBAT SIMULATOR. It's more of a puzzle game that uses melee animations. Swords do no damage. That's because you're supposed to figure out how to get them on the ground to finish them off.Enemies are massively tough. That's because you're supposed to figure out the insta kill in the room. Shoot their heads as they go up ladders. Use the swinging chandelier. And every day is leg day!IF YOU DON'T SEE IT THIS WAY, COMBAT IS FRUSTRATING AND UNINTUITIVE. But when you treat it as a puzzle game, it becomes pretty fun.And the story and voice acting is so bad, you'll be driven insane. It's wonderful. WHERE IS DARK MESSIAH 2? Bring me it's head.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												This is really quite a hidden gem of a game. The story is tired: You are the chosen one crap, a world that doesn't have much depth unless you already know the lore of the world of might and magic, and standard fantasy fare as opponents- orcs, spiders, dragons, goblins, etc. But where this game REALLY shines is the combat.Every single fight is intense, quick paced, and fresh with every battle. There's a reason this game is known as stompy mcheavyboot's adventure in the land of spikes: kicking opponents into environmental hazards is usually an efficient way to kill almost anything. But there's so many options for combat: kick your opponents into each other, sneak up and cut ropes to activate traps, launch your opponents into huge ravines with well placed fireballs. The combat is so damn satisfying and the exploration is so gratifying that you're glued to the game. I picked it up on a sale, and this is more than worth your money.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												I remember way back when this game was about to be released. The entire gaming community online was going bonkers with this game, the demo that had been released roughly a year prior had been completely broken down.It was hacked and people discovered loads and loads of hidden features and at that point unused enemies that had giant errors as skin. Everyone was waiting, including me,  and then at the day of release....Nothing, no one bought it, review sites gave Dark Messiah a horrible rating calling it less than average.Me and a friend of mine were even the first people to buy it in our country, the game sales guy was shocked that we were the only 2.And now, after so many years, it still recieves horrible reviews from critics, but I'll step up to defend it. LEt's just go over it point by point see where and how they are wrong.This review will contain spoilers but I highly recommend it if you haven't played it yet.First off, the Story.-------------------People say the story is transparent, why? Because the game is called Dark Messiah? Or how about that first cut scene, you know where you actually SEE the ending in a dream.I never can understand why anyone would say that, the game never tries to fool you.Others might say that there really isn't much story to begin with....which is also false.Most of the story actually lies in the past, things that have come and gone already, I think it has enough depth.Gameplay-----------I've heard more than enough times that the combat is repetitive, but I don't understand why.This is where Dark Messiah excels , never not once in playing it have I gotten bored during combat, fighting enemies is never the same. On the highest difficulty setting fine you know, yes the enemies have some really cheap hits, that do a heck amount of damage. But I never saw it as unfair, only that I had to be better, faster, more cunning and slippery.Everything is a weapon, going from a big Wooden Barrel, to a bucket of plain rocks.Often I found myself actually reloading a certain fight scene when it went to EASY, killing 5 vampire knights without any damage....no that didn't do it for me, so I did it again and after 40 retries I finally succeeded again.And the kick, nothing beats that, if there's a ledge someone is going down, and it never gets old.RPG or Not?-------------I wouldn't call Dark Messiah an RPG, persé. Howeverit does have RPG elements. But you don't gain skill points for killing enemies, and there's no class system.Most people really hate that about this game, but I don't. At least it's a refreshing take upon the genre, just build your own class. And if you don't have enough skills to finish your end goal...well you screwed up not the developers. The only thing that I kinda don't like is the fact that in a way you are forced to have at least 1 magical ability.Ending Good or Bad---------------------There's only one true ending, and that's the evil ending. The game is called Dark Messiah, the ending is shown to our protagonist in the beginning in some sort of vision. Even the crew of Might and Magic themselves kinda admitted to which was the real ending when they included good old Kha-Beleth in the series.Again a refreshing take, not everything has to be sunshine and lollipops with rainbows.Final score I give it a 10/10, play this, love this and enjoy this.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Most will have played Skyrim by now, so I'll compare to that to save time.This game is very similar to Skyrim, but it has a few significant differences.  It is not open world, you have to follow a linear story; there's still plenty to discover throughout the game.  Character builds still touch on warrior, mage, and thief aspects, but it's almost all combat-focused.  The REAL difference in this game is the physical interaction.  Smithing, for example.  You can't smith-and-sell like in skyrim with all the complexity of a miniature free market, but you can go through each step of smithing.  You see your hands and all the objects move as they should; everything is suitably realistic.  This realistic physical detail applies to EVERYTHING in the game.  The way your arms and body (this game has full body awareness, just look down and see your body) move during combat, running, kicking, everything.  The only thing not covered is grabbing and pulling levers with your hands.  This PHYSICAL DETAIL in absolutely everything you do is intoxicating to me.  Even the environments and enemies are full of physics and interactivity.  Throw boxes and barrels, the way you climb ropes, the viewpoint as you look around actually follows your head, and even when you die the camera follows where your eyes would be on your physical body as you fall down.(Yes, it can feel a bit mirror's edge-y when you run, but the only free-running is vaulting onto things) This combined with the fantastic combat (better than skyrim's combat imo), plenty of character customization, and beautiful artistic design make the whole journey enjoyable.  I suggest playing on the hardest difficulty to make your character build choices feel like they really affect what you're doing.  (If it gets frustrating repeating areas, just play on Normal at first)tl;dr - YOUR ARMS AND LEGS ♥♥♥♥ING MOVE LIKE REAL ONES AND YOU CAN INTERACT WITH EVERYTHING PHYSICALLY HOLY♥♥♥♥♥♥YES! 11/10Since I can't say it with the yes/no thumbs, I'll have to say it here :  I give this game a HELL YES!

												A thrilling first person action game featuring one of the most impressive melee combat systems seen to date. Although the game is fairly linear, levels are at times open enough to allow some optional exploration, often resulting in usefull rewards that can be uncovered through the games numereous secrets rooms and pathways. There are also three branching character paths the user may choose from, allowing for different play styles, and some replayability.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
Product received for free
												Le moins qu'on puisse dire, c'est qu'on a déjà vu des jeux plus récents qui ont beaucoup moins bien vieilli que celui-là. Dark Messiah, c'est quoi, au juste ? C'est un jeu qui s'inscrit dans l'univers de Might and Magic (d'où le nom à rallonge) et qui n'est ni plus, ni moins, que l'ancêtre de Dishonored, qui est la version aboutie de ce jeu. À quelques détails près, évidemment. Là où Dishonored est un jeu clairement conçu pour de l'infiltration avec, en bonus, la possibilité de faire du combat, Dark Messiah est un jeu clairement conçu pour du combat avec, en bonus, la possibilité de faire un tout petit peu d'infiltration. Et puisque je parle de Dishonored... Si vous avez joué à Dishonored avant de jouer à ce jeu, préparez vous à rager un petit peu quand même. En effet, si vous avez joué à Dishonored, il est tout simplement impossible de ne pas remarquer que Dishonored est la version améliorée, sculptée, dégrossie de Dark Messiah... c'est à dire qu'il sera impossible de ne pas remarquer plusieurs petites imperfections dans le gameplay de Dark Messiah, qui, bien que petites, vont vous rendre un petit peu fou lorsque vous constaterez que vos habitudes dans Dishonored (notamment en ce qui concerne les mouvements du personnage) ne marchent pas dans Dark Messiah, ce qui est parfois pesant (on remerciera la poursuite du chapitre 3, pas nécessaire et mal fichue). Mais bon, si le jeu souffre un peu de la comparaison avec son successeur, comme je vous l'ai dit, il n'a pas trop mal vieilli non plus. Il a même plutôt bien vieilli, en fait. Côté graphismes, c'est propre, et c'est même assez charmant, autant en ce qui concerne les textures que les animations en passant par la direction artistique. ATTENTION cela dit, le jeu tourne sur Source, ce qui veut dire que le jeu se calquera sur la langue utilisée pour votre client steam (potentiellement chiant, surtout quand vous passez d'une cinématique en anglais à un dialogue en français tout de suite après). Niveau son aussi, rien à dire, même si on aurait apprécié une OST un peu plus marquante. Niveau gameplay, le personnage manque peut-être un peu de souplesse dans ses mouvements (ça rejoint ce que je disais sur Dishonored) mais ce n'est pas bien grave. En fait, le gameplay du jeu est extrêmement simple (First Person Slasher de base avec des pouvoirs), mais étonamment riche. On peut récupérer pas mal d'armes / armures différentes, et se spécialiser dans le style de combat qui nous plait : plutôt magicien, plutôt archer, plutôt épéiste... Sachez toutefois que les côtés "archérie" et "furtivité" ne sont pas assez fournis pour s'y spécialiser entièrement : ce sera juste un bonus apporté à votre build, qui sera déterminé par là où vous mettez le curseur entre magie et combat. On peut donc manier des bâtons, des épées, des dagues, des arcs, des boucliers, sans distinction véritable, ce qui permet de varier un peu comme ça nous plait (et idem pour les compétences magiques). En plus de ça vient se rajouter une barre d'adrénaline qui vous permet de déclencher des exécutions violentes à l'épée (quand je vous disais que c'était le prédecesseur de Dishonored !) ou de booster une autre attaque. Mais bon, si le gameplay du jeu est aussi fun, ce n'est pas (seulement) parce qu'on a des pouvoirs, ce n'est pas (seulement) parce qu'on a de la variété, ce n'est pas (seulement) parce qu'on a des mouvements réalistes à l'épée... c'est surtout grâce à une chose.Le coup de pied.Et là, je vous montre une petite vidéo très drôle qui résume assez bien à quel point on peut se marrer en jouant à ce jeu. Non seulement ce coup de pied est extrêmement pratique (c'est votre outil numéro un), mais en plus, s'en servir est super drôle.Donc malgré les petites imperfections dont je parlais au début, le gameplay est vraiment bon.Un petit mot rapide sur le scénario, enfin : ce dernier est assez bateau, et on s'en fiche pas mal, car le jeu n'est pas là pour nous proposer une histoire originale. Par contre, je tiens à dire que la narration est franchement pas mal du tout. D'autant plus que le jeu a le bon goût de nous proposer quelques choix qui influeront sur la fin, et comme le jeu est plutôt Immersive Sim côté game design, j'ai bien l'impression que les développeurs ont prévu un petit dialogue pour (quasiment) chaque éventualité, même les plus rocambolesques. Donc voilà. Le jeu a pris quelques rides, mais il vaut quand même le coup, largement !

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Actually it's a good game. It's based on sourse, but it's an first person RPG, Oblivion-like. And though it has a small skills tree, the game offers you a nice variety of tactical solutions for your battles, you can impale enemies on spikes, push them off the cliffs, cut ropes so stuff fall on their heads, throw random objects at them, stun them and finish them off later... There is plenty of options and I didn't even mentioned the half of them, also there is a grappling bow, so you may climb some difficult to reach places and a pretty decent variety of weapons of all kinds. There are couple of points I'd like to mention to you first:1. Game is linear. You may choose your approach to the situation as you wish, but it's a straight-line story you'll follow.2. Choose your class wisely. Warrior, assasin or mage... Though it would help to have some extra perks from other classes trees, points are given for completing parts of the main story, so I'd suggest to invest them in the build that suits your gamestyle the most.3. Keep all the stuff you'll find. You never know when you could need it.4. Secrets, puzzles, hidden loot, etc. Be observative.5. Use your surrounding to your advantage, you won't always be able to win by brute force.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												An action-adventure taking place in a fantasy world and all this with Valve's Source engine! I liked how varied game they developed - you can be a master of swords or become an archer or simply stick with magic. There are a lot of traps here and there which means the game lets you use the environment to kill your opponents. For example: you kick a support beam after which a dozen barrels are dropped on your enemy. Or you can sneak up to those standing near cliffs and kick them down into the abyss. This environmental combat is what makes Dark Messiah a unique game. Looting exists but you cannot really equip that many weapons - it is as if the creators wanted to put the system there as it was a requirement for an RPG anyway.Putting the insignificant looting system aside Dark Messiah is a very good fantasy game. If you love Might & Magic you can pick up its FPS iteration: you won't regret it.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												This is a gem from the last era in PC gaming and must-play material for any fantasy or adventure game enthusiast. The simplicity of the structure of the game is both decieving and rewarding; There are at least 5 viable and engaging ways to play the main character of the story and each of them is fun. Add in a few twists depending on the choices you make, more than one ending and several difficulties and you're looking at hours of fun. The secret areas and special items you can find and pick up earlier on in the quest do a lot to make the experiences of exploration and discovery. Took me 25 hours to clear this game the first time poking around every room and corner looking for secret goodies. Probably 20 hours straight through. Large and small bosses, tons of neat physics, traps and environments that force you to make changes in your items and spells to adapt mean you're going to enjoy Dark Messiah. Take the crystal, Sareth; This is but a first small step on your journey...

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014



YouTube™ Video: Attention! Dark Messiah of Might and Magic 

			Views: 109		

			http://store.steampowered.com/app/2100/ Follow me on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Little_B_Gaming		

DMOMM is a good game, that just misses the mark of been great. Let me start with the story. You take the role of Sareth – an orphan who is train by the wizard Fenring. Years goes by and finally our hero is tasked to deliver a crystal to another wizard named Menelag in the city of Stonehelm. But before you leave master Fenring summon a woman name Xana, who will be your guardian and she settle in Sareths head. When you're getting closer to the city you see people leaving because army of Necromancers are about to attack. And they do and Sareth saves the city … for now. After the battle you meet Leana, niece of Menelag and the wizard himself. Sareth goes to sleep and in the middle of the night he is attacked and here start your adventure. The story is the big minus of the game – it is so predictable. The other thing is the stealth. There is no point of using it, which is a shame, but game is design  around to fight, not to sneaking.There is some rpg in DMOM and it's not deep. You earn skill points by doing tasks and you distribute them in three categories. There isn't big skill tree and some people won't like it, I personally don't mind that much. It would be better if the developer put little more variety in the skills.The combat is what I like most. It's is somewhat repetitive, but awesome. At your disposal they are swords, bows, staffs, daggers, shields, magic all their pluses and minuses. When clicking the left mouse button you perform normal weak attack, but if you hold it you execute power strike, which do more damage and depending of your movement the animation is different. While battling the enemies adrenaline meter is filling. When it's full you can kill enemy with one hit and it is gory. Lets not forget the mighty kick. In a lot of cases enemies will stand near a cliff, fire, spikes and you give them the boot it's instant death.The magic spell are nothing new or exiting. You can freeze, shoot fireballs, lightnings. The most useful spell for me is Charm. There is nothing more satisfying of making group of enemies killing each other.  The level design is great. You will walk in to caves, island full with ruins, sewers, castles. Exploration is rewarded, they are a lot of hidden stuff.There is a decent variety of enemies, but their design is generic. You will encounter humans, orcs, dragons, goblins, zombies, spiders, cyclops and the most annoying enemy – ghouls. Most of them has some weakness, but not the ghouls. They are just annoying. The game is hard. If you walk right in front of more than two-three enemies, most likely you will die. Use the weaknesses, set some explosive traps.Despite some shortcomings DMOMM is good game and I definitely recommended it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I don't quite know what it is about this game that keeps me coming back to it. (At least twice after my initial playthrough.) I know nothing about the Might & Magic world or the other games set in it. I'm sure there's more story the characters and events in this game. I hope so since the story felt a bit disjointed and incomplete. I was put in middle of events I have no idea why they happened. The characters were never properly introduced either. Or built upon.But the gameplay. There is that little something in the gameplay. I can't quite put my finger on it but best I could describe it is solid. This feels and plays like a very solid game. What that means I'm not too sure. I have no problems with any of the gameplay mechanics. I just love how the gameplay feels.The graphics, despite being an old game, still hold up just fine. It has that old time 3D feel but that's just fine. I think it adds to the game. It is also worth noting that this is a very linear game. There is very little exploration to do. And I dislike most linear games.I really like this game. Every time I think about it I get the urge to try it out once more. The story isn't all that interesting to me and graphics just do their job. It's the combat and overall gameplay that keeps me coming back. But I just don't know why.If this ever goes on sale again I definitely suggest picking it up, just don't expect a great story. Even so this is one of my favorite games among such popular hits as Trine 2, Mirror's Edge, and Psychonauts as you can see from my profile showcase. I feel like this is a very underrated and unknown game.If you're a game designer or a wanting to be one I suggest you check out this game. Perhaps you could take apart and analyze why this gameplay feels so different from all the other sword and sorcery RPGs. I genuinely  think there is something to be studied here.----[Rating weighted based on the genre]----Story: 1.5/5Gameplay: 5/5Challenge: 4/5Discovery: 2/5Replayability: 4/5Aesthetics: 4.5/5Visuals: 3/5Atmosphere: 3.5/5Music: -/5 (I don't remember.)

content:
Posted: March 31, 2013
												This game has the best combat system I've ever seen. You can use the enviroment to help you in combat. For example you can trigger traps, throw objects on your enemies, or kick them to water/from stairs, impale them on spikes, or climb above them and shoot them with your bow. As assassin you can hide in shadows and backstab your enemies. As wizzard, you can freeze your oponents, make them smaller or cast ice on earth and watch them as they slip on ice. You don't have to learn skills from one class, so you can learn anything and become anything you want. Some people say that it's useless to learn some skills, because the kicking is the most powerful weapon in game. It's not true. It's more effecient to be for example  assassin(and of course, it's more fun).Game is linear, you cannot stray, but there are four different endings.You have been possessed by a demon which will help you and say funny comments on some situations in the game(and she's got sexy voice). The story is simple but good. The maps are very well designed. The atmosphere is different from location to location. Somewhere it's peaceful, elsewhere it's calm, or dark, or little disturbing.The game is from 2006, but still good looking. Textures aren't high quality, but the illumination is perfect and enhance atmosphere. Music is mix of orechstral and industrial, someone can say it's dark fantasy.  You can find soundtrack on youtube. Sounds are average. Water sounds like water. The characters have very good voices, even the supporting characters. There are also ambient sounds. There are very good and further enhance the atmosphere.Dark Messiah is the most underrated game I've ever played. It definitely should have second part. I played this game three times and it's still fun. There was still places that I didn't see in previous playthroughs.Many people were dissapointed becasue they thought Dark Messiah is RPG. It's not. It's action game with RPG elements.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												- Melee combat is amazing and satisfying- Spells are mundane- Stealth is less satisfying than full melee (Stealth can actually be really hard since some parts require full balls deep yolo-mode and your damage/armor is low)- Archery is... archery (meh)- Story is a bit corny and weird- You can't bang any of the hot grills- Suffers from some frequent crashes (but only on loading screens and exiting)- You're fighting a lot of the same monsters: Ghouls, spiders, orcs, thieves, casters, vampire knights, a few liches, oh and 4x cyclops. There is enough to not make it boring, but after 30 spiders you'll start to notice it.- Game suffers from some bugs, especially with the rope bowOverall 6/10I recommend it only if you can look past the flaws, because the melee combat combined with the traps and kicking is 10/10 fun guaranteed.

												the game is fun and challenging. the game rewards hunting for collectables and completing side quests. you won't be able to get EVERY upgrade but you can get a few so don't waste it on something stupid like bows, instead spend it on magic and health because you can't take on 4 or more people without the ice spell or the surrounding enviroment. speaking of the enviroment, use anything. rocks, pots, skulls and bowls can all be thrown at your enemys to stun them or knock them down so you can finish them off. enemys can run away however, i don't think i've seen the orcs run away but goblins have no balls. a weapon i'd recommend is the staff of reflection. when you see mages, you're actually seeing magic dispensers. thingd i don't like:the undead have an abillity to spray you with a green gas that poisens you.poisen drains you all the way down to a one hit kill and the antidote is really hard to get.health potions are everywhere but not really useful when you have the heal spell.the stamina bar is so small. it's like the skyrim stamina bar when you start the game.bows suck.stealth is harder than skyrim but not impossibleand the friendly NPCs are so weak and the only one that isn't weak is really annoying.Main reason you should buy it is you have a sexy woman in your head who talks to you and says she will do "things" to you or "treat you better"

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												story-driven compared to oblivion, but came out around the same time and is another great first-person fantasy rpg. It's currently on sale, so I suggest you grab it for 2 and a  half bucks at a steal.  Keep in mind, like with oblivion, to play with a gamepad you will need to use software like pinnacle game profiler (frequently on sale for 10 bucks for lifetime license) or xpadder or joy2key. joy2key is free, I think xpadder may also have a free version, if you have pinnacle there is an official (pinnacle official) pad profile downloadable in the program and custom ones are available on some sites.  But anyways, it works great with kb/mouse and is a fun, solid first-person combat rpg experience. The multiplayer is p2p and I Believe it's still able to be used if you go through some trouble to find people and host or have them host, but don't expect to be able to use the multiplayer as the game is pretty old by now. It looks as good if not a little better than oblivion in some ways though, in spite of it's age and plays as well. Many of the combat mechanics are better than oblivion's too in my personal opinion.

content:
Posted: January 14
												I've just completed this game. For the first time, despite having played it as far as at least 9 years ago.Why? Because the plot is just... let's just say it's so bad it's just irrelevant to any sane player. Don't even bother following it. The setting/vibe is kinda nice, reminds me of old-school RPG games, that's M&M alright.However, the gameplay is absolutely fantastic. This game is over 10 years old and it still has one of the best combat systems I've ever seen. That's why most people who bother to play it never get to the ending. They don't have to, simply because they have what is best right from the beginning: combat.How is it remarkable? I'd explain, but I think a video - which wasn't made by me - is gonna be more expressive than a thousand words uttered by me:


YouTube™ Video: Dark Messiah Of Might And Magic Is Ridiculous 

			Views: 224,961		

			Game - DarK Messiah Of Might And Magic Music - Fatman Scoop Vs. Amerie - Get Ya Hands Up (TheFunkyFr34K Mash-Up)		

Oh, and if you're worried this game has aged too much for you to bother with it - no, it hasn't. Trust me.By 2017 standards, my rating is:-graphics: 5/10 (that has aged, indeed, although they aren't offputting)-sounds: 7/10 (voice acting is kinda mediocre, and once you hear Leanna, you'll want to plug your ears with something... although Xana is just as obnoxious with her "edgy" commentaries)-gameplay: 9/10 (plotwise, your choices don't make much sense, there is very little character development, but less is more, if it's polished - and it is, if you ask me)OVERALL: 7,5/10One con: be prepared for crashes while loading the game. I mean, some people report that this game crashes on other occassions, too, but I only had crashes while reloading savegames for any reason. Oh, and multiplayer is dead. Which really does suck. But it's still worth it.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												- Melee combat is amazing and satisfying- Spells are mundane- Stealth is less satisfying than full melee (Stealth can actually be really hard since some parts require full balls deep yolo-mode and your damage/armor is low)- Archery is... archery (meh)- Story is a bit corny and weird- You can't bang any of the hot grills- Suffers from some frequent crashes (but only on loading screens and exiting)- You're fighting a lot of the same monsters: Ghouls, spiders, orcs, thieves, casters, vampire knights, a few liches, oh and 4x cyclops. There is enough to not make it boring, but after 30 spiders you'll start to notice it.- Game suffers from some bugs, especially with the rope bowOverall 6/10I recommend it only if you can look past the flaws, because the melee combat combined with the traps and kicking is 10/10 fun guaranteed.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I don't quite know what it is about this game that keeps me coming back to it. (At least twice after my initial playthrough.) I know nothing about the Might & Magic world or the other games set in it. I'm sure there's more story the characters and events in this game. I hope so since the story felt a bit disjointed and incomplete. I was put in middle of events I have no idea why they happened. The characters were never properly introduced either. Or built upon.But the gameplay. There is that little something in the gameplay. I can't quite put my finger on it but best I could describe it is solid. This feels and plays like a very solid game. What that means I'm not too sure. I have no problems with any of the gameplay mechanics. I just love how the gameplay feels.The graphics, despite being an old game, still hold up just fine. It has that old time 3D feel but that's just fine. I think it adds to the game. It is also worth noting that this is a very linear game. There is very little exploration to do. And I dislike most linear games.I really like this game. Every time I think about it I get the urge to try it out once more. The story isn't all that interesting to me and graphics just do their job. It's the combat and overall gameplay that keeps me coming back. But I just don't know why.If this ever goes on sale again I definitely suggest picking it up, just don't expect a great story. Even so this is one of my favorite games among such popular hits as Trine 2, Mirror's Edge, and Psychonauts as you can see from my profile showcase. I feel like this is a very underrated and unknown game.If you're a game designer or a wanting to be one I suggest you check out this game. Perhaps you could take apart and analyze why this gameplay feels so different from all the other sword and sorcery RPGs. I genuinely  think there is something to be studied here.----[Rating weighted based on the genre]----Story: 1.5/5Gameplay: 5/5Challenge: 4/5Discovery: 2/5Replayability: 4/5Aesthetics: 4.5/5Visuals: 3/5Atmosphere: 3.5/5Music: -/5 (I don't remember.)

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												story-driven compared to oblivion, but came out around the same time and is another great first-person fantasy rpg. It's currently on sale, so I suggest you grab it for 2 and a  half bucks at a steal.  Keep in mind, like with oblivion, to play with a gamepad you will need to use software like pinnacle game profiler (frequently on sale for 10 bucks for lifetime license) or xpadder or joy2key. joy2key is free, I think xpadder may also have a free version, if you have pinnacle there is an official (pinnacle official) pad profile downloadable in the program and custom ones are available on some sites.  But anyways, it works great with kb/mouse and is a fun, solid first-person combat rpg experience. The multiplayer is p2p and I Believe it's still able to be used if you go through some trouble to find people and host or have them host, but don't expect to be able to use the multiplayer as the game is pretty old by now. It looks as good if not a little better than oblivion in some ways though, in spite of it's age and plays as well. Many of the combat mechanics are better than oblivion's too in my personal opinion.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												I have played the single player and it was great. I like how the game provides several ways to engage your enemies. For example, the obvious way is the hack and slash method which is very straight foward but I chose any high ledges I could possibly get my feet on and shot away with arrows using an "endless quiver" I found within the game.  You can also change your methods and weapons for engagements as you please. Some enemies are best to engage in hand to hand (sword, dagger, staff, etc), others with the Bow (fire damage, ice damage, poison, etc) and some require the use of magic to defeat. There are several ways of not only killing your enemies but also eliminating them quickly either kicking them off cliffs, stabbing them from behind, kicking them into traps, activating traps while the enemy move across the area, etc. You can use the environment to your advantage or it can literally kill you if you're careless.It's a good game all around and it provides you with a few choices within the game; optional objectives or alternate endings based on certain choices throughout the game.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2013
												This game has the best combat system I've ever seen. You can use the enviroment to help you in combat. For example you can trigger traps, throw objects on your enemies, or kick them to water/from stairs, impale them on spikes, or climb above them and shoot them with your bow. As assassin you can hide in shadows and backstab your enemies. As wizzard, you can freeze your oponents, make them smaller or cast ice on earth and watch them as they slip on ice. You don't have to learn skills from one class, so you can learn anything and become anything you want. Some people say that it's useless to learn some skills, because the kicking is the most powerful weapon in game. It's not true. It's more effecient to be for example  assassin(and of course, it's more fun).Game is linear, you cannot stray, but there are four different endings.You have been possessed by a demon which will help you and say funny comments on some situations in the game(and she's got sexy voice). The story is simple but good. The maps are very well designed. The atmosphere is different from location to location. Somewhere it's peaceful, elsewhere it's calm, or dark, or little disturbing.The game is from 2006, but still good looking. Textures aren't high quality, but the illumination is perfect and enhance atmosphere. Music is mix of orechstral and industrial, someone can say it's dark fantasy.  You can find soundtrack on youtube. Sounds are average. Water sounds like water. The characters have very good voices, even the supporting characters. There are also ambient sounds. There are very good and further enhance the atmosphere.Dark Messiah is the most underrated game I've ever played. It definitely should have second part. I played this game three times and it's still fun. There was still places that I didn't see in previous playthroughs.Many people were dissapointed becasue they thought Dark Messiah is RPG. It's not. It's action game with RPG elements.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												Good gameplay and interesting story with plot twists if you don't mind the graphics.The best thing about the game is the gameplay. There are many puzzles, and when you have to fight, you have lots of ways to approach (or evade) the enemy. First, you do this by choosing your skills (melee, archery, spells and/or stealth). Then, you can fight your enemies using the traps in the environment, you go past them with stealth or kill them silently, and you can combine these strategies with blunt force and a good mixture of weapons and spells.8/10 I recommend for those that are looking for a refreshing gameplay experience.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												This game really deserves a sequel or spiritual successor. The first person sword fighting is good, satisfying and possibly the best of its kind (haven't played Dishonored yet). There are some issues with hit detection, and Flurries (your main attack, but you'll probably be using power strikes most of the time) is pretty crap, but apart from that the melee combat is done pretty well and has a good sense of impact and physicality, whether you're blocking a strike with your shield or kicking an enemy. The RPG elements, which let you use magic and stealth as well, and environmental weapons (wall spikes, fires, flimsy wooden supports that can be broken to topple barrels and crates on enemies etc.) allow for different approaches to each battle. The platforming is also decent. The game isn't perfect of course. Some sections of the game don't cater well to a specific build, boss fights are dull and in some cases (usually when they fly) annoying, and some of the enemy types aren't nearly as fun to fight as others. There have also been complaints about the plot, characters and voice acting, but I wasn't bothered by them.Basically, if you're looking for good first person sword fighting and physics in a fantasy setting then Dark Messiah of Might and Magic is the game for you.
