content:
Posted: January 14
												I've just completed this game. For the first time, despite having played it as far as at least 9 years ago.Why? Because the plot is just... let's just say it's so bad it's just irrelevant to any sane player. Don't even bother following it. The setting/vibe is kinda nice, reminds me of old-school RPG games, that's M&M alright.However, the gameplay is absolutely fantastic. This game is over 10 years old and it still has one of the best combat systems I've ever seen. That's why most people who bother to play it never get to the ending. They don't have to, simply because they have what is best right from the beginning: combat.How is it remarkable? I'd explain, but I think a video - which wasn't made by me - is gonna be more expressive than a thousand words uttered by me:


YouTube™ Video: Dark Messiah Of Might And Magic Is Ridiculous 

			Views: 224,961		

			Game - DarK Messiah Of Might And Magic Music - Fatman Scoop Vs. Amerie - Get Ya Hands Up (TheFunkyFr34K Mash-Up)		

Oh, and if you're worried this game has aged too much for you to bother with it - no, it hasn't. Trust me.By 2017 standards, my rating is:-graphics: 5/10 (that has aged, indeed, although they aren't offputting)-sounds: 7/10 (voice acting is kinda mediocre, and once you hear Leanna, you'll want to plug your ears with something... although Xana is just as obnoxious with her "edgy" commentaries)-gameplay: 9/10 (plotwise, your choices don't make much sense, there is very little character development, but less is more, if it's polished - and it is, if you ask me)OVERALL: 7,5/10One con: be prepared for crashes while loading the game. I mean, some people report that this game crashes on other occassions, too, but I only had crashes while reloading savegames for any reason. Oh, and multiplayer is dead. Which really does suck. But it's still worth it.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Intro:Dark messiah does not feel like a linear adventure game with their backpack and level system. It's more like an FPS/RPG(I woudlnt say action rpg).Longevity and difficulty:It does not take too many hours to beat it, but it's worth it. Play at very hard and i bet you won't survive. I tried it on hard mode, but you still have to limit yourself if you want your hard mode to be challenging. Limit yourself(a game is never too hard):So if you want your hard to be hard, you should not unlock healself and do not use weapons that do exactly what a spell does unless you want to do a quick speedrun. At the very least, drop the ice bow and lighting shield.Combat:One of the best combat system. The enemies and the ai are strong and smart enough to beat you in a duel. so imagine when 2 of them jumps on you. This forces you to sneak first before you engage. It forces you to use you spells strategically to kill a couple before you jump on the last few of the room to kill. Thus, it forces you to use your environment and front kicking your opponent on a spike like a mortal kombat's fatality. Speaking of fatalities, you will most likely kill your opponent with a fatal blow and you must build up your meter for that like a super meter from street fighter.Story: Il say it now, don't play for the story. The immersion is there and everything, but the story is not that good. The ending is one of the worse. Verdict: Buy the game. It's unique and this game probably influenced most first person slashing games after that. It was very unique when it came out in 2006 and it still feels that way.

												It's fun at first, when you're kicking guards all over the shop and punting them off high ledges, but this wears off soon enough and all that you're left with is a generic fantasy game with uninteresting characters and a plot as dull as dishwater. The game is split up into ten chapters/levels. The first four - five at a push - are great fun. They allow the game mechanics (especially the kick attack, oh baby) to really shine and I had some of the best fun I've had in a video game in a long while. Unfortunately, you spend the rest of the game navigating claustrophobic dungeons fighting boring enemies. Overall, Dark Messiah is the product of wasted potential. There are some really great gameplay and level ideas present, that, like I said, flourish primarily in the first half. I'd strongly recommend getting this game on sale as I did, because you'll probably justify the price tag from the fun you'll have booting guards into campfires and orcs off cliffs. It's just a shame it becomes more of a chore nearer the end.6/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 11, 2016
												Dark Messiah is mostly known as "the kicking game", and while that isn't an inaccurate description, there's more to it than that. Most people only know Arkane Studios for Dishonored, possibly without even realzing that Dark Messiah still influences things to this day, like the Deadly Reflexes mod for Skyrim, because its combat was so fun that very few other games have managed to match it. The game uses the Source engine's physics in the combat arguably better than even Half Life 2 itself did, letting you pick up almost anything in the environment and throw or kick it as a weapon, use telekinesis magic to turn anything from flaming corpses to pies into projectile weaponry, smash environmental traps to send things falling onto enemies, and of course the ever-famous kick, allowing you to stagger and kick your enemies into environmental hazards or off cliffs. Along the way you can put skill points into buildling your character for stealth, magic, or standard combat, each of which are equally fun and viable. The story isn't really its strong point, but you'll be too busy kicking things to care much. If you liked Dishonored and you haven't played Dark Messiah, you should probably fix that.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												Good gameplay and interesting story with plot twists if you don't mind the graphics.The best thing about the game is the gameplay. There are many puzzles, and when you have to fight, you have lots of ways to approach (or evade) the enemy. First, you do this by choosing your skills (melee, archery, spells and/or stealth). Then, you can fight your enemies using the traps in the environment, you go past them with stealth or kill them silently, and you can combine these strategies with blunt force and a good mixture of weapons and spells.8/10 I recommend for those that are looking for a refreshing gameplay experience.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												I have over 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game. One Hour Reviews #38 - Dark Messiah of Might & MagicI played a number of the very early Might & Magic Games.  In particular I remember playing a ton of Might & Magic VI.  I remember it as a role playing game before the Heroes of Might and Magic series overshadowed it with a completely different type of gameplay and focus on strategy.Dark Messiah of Might and Magic is a different beast altogether.  It's not a turn based strategy game like Heroes is.  But it's also not an RPG like the original games either.  This is more of an action RPG, with an emphasis on the action.    You do have some RPG aspects, for example the game provides 3 skills trees, one for melee, one for magic, and a third for other skills.  The early skills are cheap, so it's easy to dabble in each of the skill trees.  I found this to be good because I was primarily focusing on melee, but early on I found it extremely helpful to train a heal spell.  I noticed I wasn't really healing on my own, but I would slowly get mana back, so being able to trade mana for health made things a lot easier.Even with the skill tress and RPG elements, I still consider this game pretty RPG-lite.  If you are looking for an open-world type game, this isn't for you.  The story is linear and really the game feels more like an adventure game with an emphasis on combat than a typical RPG.  This may sound like a turnoff, but the combat is actually a lot of fun.  I really liked the feel of combat.  It isn't just smashing buttons or turning on auto-attack.  Another nice aspect to this game is the interactivity with the environment.  The game encourages you to kick the crap out of your enemies, either into a fire, or into a convieniently placed spike rack, or over the edge of a railing.  In fact arguably your foot is the best weapon in the game, at least from what I saw.Probably the most fun I had in my hour of play involved a chandelier.  I cut a rope which caused this chandelier to start swinging around.  Meanwhile I had about 4 guards chasing me.  I'd run past the chandelier while it was on it's upswing, and the guards would stupidly follow me without paying attention and get smacked as the chandelier came back down.  It was kind of ridiculous as I'd watch the guards body ragdoll it's way across the room as if it was hit by a wrecking ball.  After about 3 laps around the room, I had killed all of the guards by chandelier.My only complaint about the game was it was rather crash prone.  It crashed 3 times on me in the hour I played.  Once it crashed on startup, once it crashed as I was quitting the game, and once it crashed in the middle of the game.   Perhaps this is from me running Windows 10 (the game came out for Windows XP).  Looking at other reviews, this doesn't seem to be a common issue, so it may just be something specific with my setup.Overall, the combat alone is enough to make this game fun, and to earn my recommendation.  I did not check out the multiplayer version of this, so my entire review is only based on the single player game.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												I'll give this game a tentative 'endorse.' I ran my first playthrough as a thief with some archery. While rough, it eventually became awesome stealth-one-shotting enemies after an ever uphill battle. I figured for sure a second playthrough as a fighter-mage would be even more epic, if thief ended up so well done. But really, I'm on chapter 9 now with that character, and it's pretty bad. For the most part, the magic is incredibly impotent by end game. For being called Might *AND MAGIC* it's a pity to see magic really only good for healing. On the contrary, I find myself increasingly just bashing enemies to death left and right with the fighter abilities I took and keep on trucking against the hordes.Overall, worth a playthrough or so. Just don't go in expecting to be some kind of omnipotent mage by the end - that WILL NOT happen.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												A forced union of two personages from opposing factions gives birth to an unlikely hero. Parents separated, mother dead, raised by foster family, apprenticed into the basics of wizardry. You are tasked to deliver a mysterious artifact to a guy who then dies, like, a few hours later. His hot niece, who totally has a crush on you, helps you retrieve the artifact from the bad guys. She dies. Or she doesn't. Anyway, in order to get even, and fulfill your destiny, you must find and use a skull. And then you die, but not really. Because your conscience, which also totally digs you, brings you back to life and triggers your mega-evolution. You can continue on the pokemon path, or choose to cleanse yourself of the annoying voices in your head, and then you get some hot lewt good vs undead. You kill some more guys, and then another guy, and then you can choose to either watch a cutscene, or the other one.But srsly, I recommend it with all my limbs. If you haven't tried it before, you will notice similarities with Arkane's previous first-person slasher, Arx Fatalis. But with more emphasis on melee&ranged, and a simplified magic system. It features some damn awesome melee combat. Slashing, backstabbing, kicking, is just too damn fun. Also connects with the HoMM series (5th), but I won't say how because spoilers.I give it a 9.75/10, but only because it makes me want to backstab people while walking down the street. Can't have that, man

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
Product received for free
												DARK MESSIAH OF MIGHT AND MAGIC single playerTHE BEST DUNGEONS AND DRAGONS GAME EVER MADEDeveloper: Arkane StudiosYear: 2008Genre: Fantasy Action-Adventure RPGFranchise: Might and MagicEngine: SourceTL;DRThis is one of my favourite games of all time. It's visceral, it's lovably janky and most of all it makes me feel like I'm playing D&D more than any other game I've seen. Yes, even Skyrim.REVIEWStory:DMoMM's story is rather like used toilet paper: Thin and ♥♥♥♥♥♥. It's generic "Ancient prophecy" dark fantasy type stuff, with characters that are hardly characters and can be described with a simple 'Personality trait+Job' formula. It's a bland character's quest for the skull of mcguffin, which embroils him in a plot involving the bland villain and his bland henchmen  and a bland prophecy that fantasy fans have seen hundreds of times before. With that said, the story is mercifully removed from the gameplay, and although it's generic it's rather inoffensively so.  4/10Graphics:Passable. They have a sort of vomit coloured mid-2000s look to them, and the character movements are a little stiff. However they function well enough and thankfully run on mid range laptops, which is good news for yours truly. 5/10Gameplay:Now we get to the meat of why I love this game. 1UP.com once criticised the game for it's reliance on the kick move. The kick is legitimately my favourite video game attack because of how bloody fun it is to use. The swordplay, the kick, the spells and the traps are all excellently visceral and brutal. When you attack a foe, they let you know that you've attacked that foe.  The ragdolls are comical, and for some may prove a point of distraction, but I love them. The dungeons are varied, labyrinthine and fun. You hear that Skyrim? Dungeons should be fun. Each one is full of traps that are equally deadly to you and the enemies within and that allow for creative uses of the source engine. A simple set of skill trees allows for the creation of a unique character, and magic items and secrets abound to augment your playstyle. Although I think that the combat system is solid enough to hold up the entire game, others may consider it repetitive. Obviously a lot of it falls to personal choice. 9/10Overall:DMoMM is a fun, satisfying Action Adventure RPG with large levels and solid core gameplay, though it comes at the cost of a thoroughly mediocre set of graphics and a bland story. For less than ten New Zealand dollars I can't recommend this game enough. Give it a bash if you like Dishonoured and don't mind low res graphics. 8.5/10Til my next review!

												Dear Reader,Simply put, this game was fun.There are some frustrating issues with modern OS's and Dark Messiah crashing fairly often, but they aren't game breaking. The story is a bit hokey, but it was still rather thrilling. The characters are a tad cliched, but a few still stood out. The game has aged fairly well. The melee combat is still engrossing, and the environments are for the most part well made. If you can find the game on sale, I would say it certainly it worth the playthrough. There is a multiplayer component, but that has remained untouched. I may update this review in the future if I happen to play it.A demo is available, which would easilly allow you to try it out. There's no reason not to!

content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												A VERY Good Singleplayer Game. Its innovative and quite Imaginative. In its gameplay, definetly not the Enemy Variety. Orcs, Spiders, Goblins and Vampires, Zombies and Necromancers. If there were Skelletons, all ... Oh wait, the final BossYep, all Generic Enemy Fantasy Types are in this Game. Which isnt a bad thing at all. Enemies have different Strengths and Weaknesses.Story is a bit too easy to guess but good nontheless.You get your fair share of Different Endings, 4 to be clear and a few ingame decisions. Which is basically one, and you can decide at which Point you do them.You can decide to be good and get a Powerful Weapon or be Evil and turn into a Demon Xenomorph,  including Tail, Claws and running on all 4.No Classes, free skilling and the amount of Skillpoints you get is very fair and Balanced.Weapon Variety is big and this is one of the few games where you can actually fight with a Staff which is pretty damn Badass. The First Person Weapon animations are Fluent and look really impressive.Hitboxes are spot on and only a centimetre next to an enemy makes you miss and curse over and over as Enemies can dodge and avoid your attacks easily.The Game pretty much Forces you to use the Physics Engine. Every Room has an easy way to kill enemies. Spikes on the Wall? Kick them in it. Fighting in a stairwell? push them down. A Candleholder floating over the Room? Cut the Rope and crush them. You get the Point.Dont expect a good Ending though. All Endings end in a Poem like the game starts, leaving you in a Cliffhanger what might happen.The Game is great Honestly. Not Perfect. It needed alot more Love put into it and some gameplay changes to make it better.Definetly worth buying. Even when its not on Sale.

You get the Point.Dont expect a good Ending though. All Endings end in a Poem like the game starts, leaving you in a Cliffhanger what might happen.The Game is great Honestly. Not Perfect. It needed alot more Love put into it and some gameplay changes to make it better.Definetly worth buying. Even when its not on Sale.

												Dear Reader,Simply put, this game was fun.There are some frustrating issues with modern OS's and Dark Messiah crashing fairly often, but they aren't game breaking. The story is a bit hokey, but it was still rather thrilling. The characters are a tad cliched, but a few still stood out. The game has aged fairly well. The melee combat is still engrossing, and the environments are for the most part well made. If you can find the game on sale, I would say it certainly it worth the playthrough. There is a multiplayer component, but that has remained untouched. I may update this review in the future if I happen to play it.A demo is available, which would easilly allow you to try it out. There's no reason not to!

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												The only reason I powered through the god-awful writing, shallow voice acting, and generic and little-developed Lore was because of the fairly entertaining Gameplay, thanks to the game's use of the Source Engine. There is a leveling system which gives this First-Person Adventure Game permission to call itself an RPG, although it is rather flawed. Many Skills are only obtainable if all of the little experience you get throughout the game is poured into one Skill-Tree. Some of the most useful skills weapons or skilled are only possibly made available just before the game's "Epilogue," which isn't actually an Epilogue but just the last chapter of the hollow story this game tells. I would recommend this game, but with a message of caution: What the game lacks in depth of Story and writing/acting, it (just barely) makes up for in fun, occasionally challenging Gameplay. While Dark Messiah provided me with around 75 hours of gameplay, it also gave me a terrible ending, in which none of your choices mattered. I was not surprised, but I was left with an empty feeling.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												Nice Half-Life 2:ish linear and scripted FPS with fantasy elements. In the end it becomes a little bit too repetitive and thus more boring. The story line carries over the dull moments. I did not see much bugs mentioned in the reviews from the period of game's actual release. I had had the game on my Game Library for many years, but now eventually I decided to give it a try at last, and was worth the time. I finished the game within a couple of days.The game's melee fighting system was first of its kind and very sophisticated, better for example than of The Witcher 1.Some remarks of critique. The choices one makes could have had a huger impact, but thinking of the post-HL2 time it was released, multiple choices still is worth, maybe of an another playthrough. The ending was a bit dissapointment. It was short and a bit "flat" after all the big expectetions one had built during the playthrough.Nevertheless, I recommend this a bit old game for all enthusiastics. It took ~16 hours to go through for me.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												If you're looking for a hidden gem, you've come to the right place.If you're looking for a tripple A game that is perfect, gtfo.Heres a TL;DR for those in a rush:This game is much better than the console. If you've played this on the console and hated it, buy this version. Why? One simple reason: Unlike the console you are NOT restricted to choosing a class. The goods about this game are: Physics are utilized, despite being linear there are multiple ways to take on missions and groups of enemies, fun to explore, combat is fun, pretty much everything is fun in this game.Whats bad about this game: Pretty old, sometimes easy to get stuck/lost.Buy this game, its worth the money and has replayability. Detailed review:I remember getting this game for the console when I was younger and feeling like I missed out, due to you having to choose a class before the game start. Choosing your class determines what skills you can and cant take, and what weapons and armor you can and cant use and it♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off that 1 of the 4 classes were locked off until you beat the game (or some♥♥♥♥♥♥like that). When I came across this game on steam, I almost passed it up beacuse of how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ the console made this game seem. But at the time I was going to lose my internet in a few days so I decided to download it. Once I lost my internet (for maintenence reasons), I played this game. Holy hell was it fun. I could take what I want, when I wanted. Do you want to kick a dude into a nearby hazard (firepit, spike trap, off a ♥♥♥♥ing cliff/mountain), do it. You want to stab him? Yolo. You want to be a sneaky character that uses magic? Or how about a guy that is focused on combat that uses staves? You can do it. Whats good about this game is that the combat is satisfying, and feels right. The fact that, despite being linear, you can still explore and sometimes even get lost. This game truly makes you feel like a protagonist, where you start off as an average joe but the more and more you level your skills, find (and even make) your own weapons, the more and more powerful you get. The level design is great. Not the best, not the worst, but good enough to have fun with. Be it using the environment to kill your enemies, sneak around, ambush, its just fun. The graphics are pretty poor and are nothing to write home about, but i feeel as if it fits the game. There is multi player, but I never checked it out. Something worth mentioning is you can really do what you want with this game, and as far as building your character for combat/utility, its almost as flexible as how Oblviion was in that reguard. Though it is discouraged through the rarity of certain items, it is possible. For example, I was able to build a mage that wore heavy armor. Was it hard to beat the game that way? Yes, very hard, but I found it fun. I might have always been running out of mana, but it wasnt impossibly hard, just hard enough to pose a challenge. While building something more forward like a warrior with a sword and sheild, or a sneaky character using daggers will do you justice, the game will still be challenging enough. The difficulty of the game is almost perfect. It punishes you for not using the environment to your advantage, punishes for poor skill, and punishes for blindly mashing the attack button. Also, the story is pretty good in my opinion. Dont ask me if the lore is friendly or whatever because outside of this game I have no clue about the lore of the might and magic universe.However, with all the amazing things this game brings, there are of course some bad things. The graphics are pretty bad. They are pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥. Bugs do happen. Not often, but often enough to note. No game breaking bugs thankfully. Despite this game being extremly fun, its pretty forgetable. Also, the end of the game feels... kind of disappointing. That might be me just being an♥♥♥♥♥ but thats just me.I still reccomend this game though. Buy this game right now. However if you come across the console version of this game, do everyone some good and burn that copy.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												This game, in my opinion rocks. It's a splendid first-person adaptation with a very action-oriented control set. There is a delightful variety in abilityes/skills/spells, for the type of game anyway, and a goot spattering of secrets. The story isn't particularly incredible, but the game has aged fairly well considering its time!You can use a variety of weapons, stealth, freeze enemies, kick them into spikes/over edges/underneath breakable roofs, etc.It carries the M&M moniker but it's really more of a first-person run around and beat 'em up, contained within the M&M mythos, of sorts. Think more like the older Crusaders of type game and whatnot. Definitely would recommend it!

content:
Posted: October 21, 2013
												Best First Person Hack'n Slay ever!Best melee combat I've experienced so far.There's no other game that accomplished this task so well.Your head moves depending on what attack you execute.At any time given you have full body awareness.All of that feels and looks very natural.Plus you can kick enemies and objects with your boot.How awesome is that?Also the sound is very good.For example, when you walk your steps sound massiveand you get a feeling for the weight of your weaponry and equipment.I especially like the sound of walking over wood.The medieval settings are also well done.Overall the atmosphere is very thick.You feel fully immersed in the dark and gritty world presented to you.All in all it's one of my favorite games.Melee combat wise definitely better than Dishonored(which is another favorite game of mine)!Only minor complaint: it's a bit too linear.

Posted: August 4, 2011
												Dark Messiah is one of the greatest first-person RPGs I've ever played. Combat keeps place with character development, so it remains challenging throughout the game. The "magic" side of the title is a little under-powered, but overall it's an excellent combat game that has a well-done plot and connections to the wider world of Might and Magic, including tie-ins to the strategy wargame "Heroes of Might and Magic V".

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												If you're looking for a nostalgic trip to the past of PC gaming, this will fit the bill, albeit briefly. It has all the trappings of oldschool PC gaming like no map, no direction, clunky movement, clunky combat, goofy looking (blocky, rough) NPCs, etc. It looks old and feels old, it may use the same engine as half-life but it is not even close. It is what it is, good for 1 play through.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
												Combat is fun and one specific cliffside level on the 5th chapter was also well designed. Other than that the game quickly falls flat. Difficulty curve ramps way up for no reason in the 6th chapter which is where i had to quit the game because of not enough healing items to progress further. Level design is terrible. Doesn't give any direction on where to go and i found myself having to use a guide just to progress. Had to use cheats because the game glitched at one point and i couldn't progress further. The game gets to a point where it's constantly throwing enemies at you that do more damage than you can do to them and it gets frustrating.Environment traps are encouraged by the game for the player to use but in some situations i found that these simply didn't work or were badly placed.Story and characters are barely there and the characters started to get annoying after the first 30 minutes. Was really expecting more from a game using the source engine, regardless of the age.

content:
Posted: January 25
												!!!DO NOT BUY THE STEAM VERSION FOR WINDOWS 7 64bIT!!!Many players including myself experience gradual FPS drops resulting the game reaching sub 10 FPS - some reported the game playing like a slide show (I had 8 FPS at one point). I have tried multiple fixes from various Steam threads, forum posts, and  PC Gaming wki. The game is apparently patched to 1.02 per the Tilde console which was supposed to fix FPS issues but a config file in the game folder says otherwise. Downloaded patches from the Internet (which are no longer on Ubisoft's website) doesn't recognize the Steam version.I dont remember having issues when I first tried the game a long time ago, but I didn't get far and when I came back, it was fine until I reach a certain point. One work around was able to get it running back to 60fps and even 90s, but it started to drop again, which many assume is due to a memory leak. I even tried using a third party program to increase the memory access size for the game, suggested by PCGamingWiki (Large Address Aware) and that did not resolve the issue for me. I won't say that these workaround will not work for you, but it is very likely they won't.I have fortunately past the time frame to refund this game, so I will have to resort to other means.The Disc version can still be found on Amazon and probably a downloadable iso if you look hard enough.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												Come for the kicking stay for the stealth.Frankly this one of the most unintentionally funny games I've played and at times it's also genuinely fun to play. That said it's not without an abnormally large number of problems I'll be getting into. The game runs like butter in 4k maxed out (Source engine game from 06 after all) and the visuals have held up well overall thanks to some fancy lighting effects and general visual flair and well as a reliance on physics that would make Half-Life 2 blush. The lip sync is great and the animation is decent even though that's primarily because it's a Source engine game and you'll often recognize some canned animations reused over and over if you've played other titles on the engine. Faces are a mixed bag with some humans looking great and others obviously not being capable of and facial animation. All the monsters look great but the people aren't all well detailed and are sometimes more ghoulish than the beasts you encounter funnily enough.One thing that could have made up for the wonky animations would have been good voice acting but unfortunatley that's another thing this game lacks to a frankly laughable degree. Things like he ability to see your feet and phyisically use your hands to pick objects up in the world (In addition to some slightly sickening head bobbing) make up for that quite a bit and can make it incredibly immersive at times even if you'll see your sword floating out of your hands or just walk past all the enemies like I did. The overly drawn out tutorial followed by a long drawn out linear opening are a few issues that keep you from getting into the meat and potatos of the game but during this time you'll have held every useless object in your hand (if your me) or destroyed everything with your awesome kick.There is stealth, there's magic, swordplay (You can dual weilding daggers, using a sword and sheild, just a sword or a staff all of which can also be used to block with), archery and donkey kong which is my preffered playstyle. The most effective weapon is the♥♥♥♥♥♥lying on the floor. You'll find yourself mostly jumping on enemies as it ragdolls them even when they are already lying down, picking up a body to block attacks, kicking people and generally being merciless as enmies limp away only to get kicked. While kicking has limited stamina it's quite useful as ledges and spikes are everywhere. It kind of reminds me of Theid with the whole game feeling like a source engine version of that title for better or worse.It's biggest problem is the lack of polish which only effects the 2 of the 3 most important things in the game those being the the gameplay and story. It's a wee bit janky and the occasional badly compressed FMV's are another thing that makes it a chore to sit through. In Half-life 2 if you got bored at least you could climb around the room and throw stuff. Funnily enough NPC's actually react twoards your bad behavior for the most part outside of cutscenes but then the game will reload a past checkpoint after you've been chastized even if all you did was throw a bottle or jump on someones head. I guess this is also because unlike Half-Life 2 you can ALSO kill pretty much anybody which could have lead to some awkward moments if you walked into a room and accidentally killed off an important charcter needed for progression.I disliked everybody I met in the game which is why it's a bummer I can't just kill everybody all the way until the end of the game. Regardless the price is right and I advise anybody who hasn't already to pick it up as there is a lot of freedom in terms of what means you use to progress.I don't know if it's really good or really bad but overall I reccomend it.Oh and Ubisoft AND Arkane had a hand in it whcih probably explains a lot.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2015
												Amazing game. The combat system is visceral and your input really matters. You have a myriad of real choices and moves to do with any weapon. The dev really knows how to make visceral sword fighting and all around great fantasy violence.Graphics are great and designed well, gameplay is phenominal and very few games (Mount and Blade, and thats about it) even try to make interesting melee combat like this game does while giving you the choice to use magic or archery aswell.Its really cool and a very varied game with a neat story with actual diffrences in results of the choices and alot to do when killing fools. The combat is very fun unlike the much more "acclaimed" Skyrim which dousn't have 1% of the combat variety this game does.Its a good cult classic game. Games this good don't come around often and rarely make large amounts of money. Any flaws are really quite minor and not a real hinderance to enjoying the game. Through my entire playthrough the melee combat was constantly freshened up and interesting.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												KICK EVERYTHING!  Kick them off cliffs. Kick them into spikes.  Kick barrels into enemies.  Kick shrine offerings into the pit.  Kick that annoying nagging NPC into demon-hell for the True Ending.Be prepared to enjoy unique, open level designs with plenty of hidden areas.  First person combat mechanics that mix spells, range weapons, and melee all together.  And it works.  This is the combat you wish Skyrim had.  Some stealth is also possible although you cannot bypass most fights.  Instead use it to gain the initiative and pick the encounter location.The story is decent too, with four possible endings and some real choices to make.  It's unfortunate more games have not emulated Dark Messiah.

number of helpful: 28 of 60 people (47%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												Posted elsewhere in 2010, since I revisited this game recently, I feel the need to post this here.Dark Messiah could have been an excellent (though still extremely linear) game. For one, the game's combat is probably one of the best uses of melee combat in a FPS, with excellent hit detection (but still not perfect) and combat that puts lots of importance in good use of the environment. It works for a bit, but then after a while something simply feels off and it does get boring if this isn't the first game you have ever played. The game gives the illusion of having varied way of playing through it. The warrior, mage, and assassin archetypes are all present with the addition of archery. Now these "classes" aren't static in anyway as you don't pick who you want to be at the start of the game. Instead you are awarded character points for completing objectives with which you are able to allocate to three different character traits: combat, magic, and "other" (which consists of stealth skills, stamina and mana boosts, etc). Because there are a finite number of character points available, you will need to place these points in each category with care, as being a generalist in this game will simply make it much harder. However, the care needed to put points in some categories is further increased due to the simple fact that many of the skills and the ways of approaching this game are simply a waste of time (in that they are useless) or are completely un-entertaining. An excellent example is in the "stealth" route of character creation. For one, the game is far too linear for implementing any real semblance of "stealth" game-play, and the only real use for stealth is for scoring one-hit kills on unsuspecting enemies (which are great, because after playing "through" this game many times, sometimes it is nice to be able to avoid a drawn out confrontation). The problem is, there are very few hiding places and opportunities to use stealth, because even if there are shadows to hide in the place usually is very narrow hallway. If you have some space to maneuver, the places are usually very well lit and makes it hard to sneak anyway. In all, putting any points in this skill is an utter waste simply due to map design.Archery, like stealth, is also unsatisfying and character points are best spent elsewhere. Unless when used in conjunction with stealth, arrows do very little damage, and you will only be able to get in two, maybe three, shots in before the opponent is in your face before you need to switch to a weapon with the ability to block with. Sounds easy, but switching weapons requires a lengthy withdraw from sheath animation and by the time you pull your weapon out you already lost lots of health in the mean time. Granted, this danger could be avoided if you pull out your weapon earlier, but that would sacrifice the ability to fire more than once… so in the end, really, there is no need for archery in this game unless certain things were tweaked.The tweaks about to be mentioned would also benefit melee combat as well, as using a sword/staff/daggers (why are daggers in fantasy games always in pairs?!) because combat in this manner also suffers from issues.Weapon damage in this game is too flawed. Quick strikes simply do no damage at all, now it does make sense they are weaker than power strikes, but hacking an enemy in the face should at least some effect. As a result, there is no reason to quick strikes, and you'll mainly rely on strong strikes and kicks, neither of which do any real damage either. This simply makes the game an especially grating experience on harder difficulties as you receive far more damage from attacks but still inflict very little unless you use power strikes, but being extremely slow, you'll get hit many times before you can strike yourself. This could have been easily remedied with a sidestep or back dash system of inputting a direction twice and quickly hopping in the direction at the cost of a fair portion of your stamina. You know, spice up the combat, something this game needs. This is where more flaws come in, the power attacks only come in two or so animations in a game with pretty precise hit detection this is an awful combination.The weapon swings in a set path, and with it the camera jolts with the swing, the result: you have very strange attack animations, with limited functionality in battle as the swing arc is a such a strange plane it will often miss your intended target. It is really hard to accurately portray this, but if you were to pick up a staff (the "crowd control weapon") and use it's power attack, you'll see first hand by what is meant by attacks being unresponsive. What could have remedied this would be a simple directional input plus attack button scheme which would result in a different kind of attack. Step to the side for a sweeping attack, forward for a power overhead strike, back for a stab attack; you know to spice up combat and do it in a logical and intuitive manner.Blocking is yet another sterile facet of combat. It is always the same animation, and it is uninteresting to perform (though in dispensable). What could have been done to make it far better is incorporate better animations, maybe more depth to it (like needing to block directional attacks) and adding the ability to actually parry attacks. How that would work would be simple (and intuitive) like the directional attack idea: direction plus block button when timed versus an attack would bat away an enemy attack allowing for you counter attack with your weapon or kick. I believe this feature and the directional attacks had they been included in this game, Dark Messiah's combat would have been epic, but alas, innovation isn't attempted nearly often enough. Kicks are a great tool and are probably one of the highlights of the game. They allow you to clear paths, kick enemies off ledges or into spikes and fires, and break through an opponent's guard. But since swinging your weapon is either too weak or too slow, so the last example is, for the most part, pointless. In fact, the combat outside of kicking, combat is so ineffective and stale, you are better off playing through just blocking with your weapon and kicking your enemy to their death. Once again, here is another transition that leads to yet another flaw of the game.The combat is so boring, and the developer seemed to notice this as well, that the game is over reliant on using environments to kill the opponents. So much so you will find spiky wall thingies everywhere for some strange reason. It gets ridiculous. Luckily, many of these spiky wall thingies happen to be in some of the more interesting maps (albeit linear) in a FPS to date. The Orc fortress and cliff side houses being the high point (stupid pun intended), and offer a great many ways and places to kick enemies off of ledges.The last way to play the game is with magic, and compared to all the other ways you can play this game, it is the most effective. But no all is well as not all spells are made equal and the only ones worth using is the basic fire bolt, lightning bolt, heal (if you don't have enough food rations or health potions), and maybe charm (though never really necessary unless you are being mobbed by many ghouls or during that duel sequence with a Orc clan leader). The trap spells (and most of the others), are kinda useful, but they're nothing but a fancy way to waste mana and character points.Continued in comments.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												For now, this review is just going to note some problems I've hadwith the game. I will be updating this review to talk about the game itself later.I'm on Windows 10, 64 bit, and this is a pretty old game!- Game often force closes when loading a new level. Quitting the game also makes it think it has force-closed. Enemies spawning also seems to cause crashes on occasion.- The "rope bow" can create ropes that stick you into walls. Having two ropes next to each other can make it incredibly diffiucult to dismount the ropes and get on the ground. Save frequently (F6 is quicksave)!- When trying to stay afloat among some rising water, the character makes some horrible drowning noises. Pretty grim! Minimise them by aiming upwards and holding jump. - There are three difficulties: Normal, Hard, and Hardcore. I opted for Hard. The game starts off incredibly difficultly, but it quickly teaches you how to use footwork and the environment to dispatch your enemies. Unfortunately, you can be faced with a large room filled with multiple guards, and by far the easiest way to kill them is to use the environment (in this case, there was a chandelier which killed them in one hit). You get some more armour, weapons, and skills, and the game difficulty is bearable, and you're able to use your sword. However, there are some escort missions, and when you come across the orcs they can kill you (and your escortee) in one or two hits, if you're unlucky. You can change the diffiuclty mid-game by using the command line, e.g. to switch to Normal mode, type:mm_game_easy_difficulty 1 mm_game_hard_difficulty 0Or set the game to start with the parameters:+mm_game_easy_difficulty 1 +mm_game_hard_difficulty 0

number of helpful: 5 of 15 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
												Can't recommend this.Only about 4 hours into the game, and I've run into several moments of cheesy, artificial difficulty, culminating in one that finally made me say "Nope. Done".-- Spoilerish --Without ruining it, it has to do with keeping a certain NPC safe while getting to a temple. I deliberately placed the NPC out of the enemies' range, and well out of line-of-sight. Didn't matter. While responding to me attacking one of the enemies, 2 others ran straight past me like I wasn't there, and made a bee-line for the NPC, killing them and causing me to fail the mission. And it's not like the NPC was "right there" in the open. No. I'd placed them a good distance away and well out of sight. The enemies would have to see through solid rock to know they were there. In other words, it's hard-coded into the game, and there's nothing I can do to prevent it from happening. So basically, I don't get to decide how to handle that part, I have to figure out and do it the way the devs want me to, or fail the mission. Way to rob the player of agency, folks. Lame.-- End Spoilerish --Oh yeah, and those spike boards the designers scattered all around like confetti, even in places they make no sense (like the middle of a busy village square)? These guys are apparently impervious to those, too. I kicked the same enemy directly into one 3 times. Nothing happened. It was unphased. Just got up and came back at me. Were they props with rubber spikes?And what is it with arrows killing an enemy in a single hit if they don't know you're there, but then being able to shrug off 3 or 4 of them if they've spotted you? Do the arrows get intimidated or something? Do the enemies deploy invisible force-fields?I like challenge. I like mystery and having to figure things out. But I like the challenge and mystery to make sense - to have some kind of train of logic attached to it. Sadly, DMoM&M isn't designed for that. So much about this game is so arbitrary and inconsistent, and it undermines what would otherwise be intriguing and entertaining gameplay opportunities.Either way, a cool concept, and a beautifully rendered/designed world which is sadly mired in poorly executed and arbitrary gameplay.Thumb down.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												I only thumb this down for one big reason but before we poke at that, lets look at the good stuff.Pros - 1. This game runs on the source engine so it has that Half Life feel and sound face into it, making for a very nostalgic piece.  Along with that, the game is very fast paced and has a good, even difficulty with plenty of enemys in it.2. The Story while now adays is a bit easy to catch on to still has a good number of twists and confusing ends for you to try and figure out on the quest.3. The Combat is strong and the branching trees and inventory are easy to play with. Overall it takes no effort to getting used to the controls, only getting used to the task bar really.With all these pros whats the one big issue with this game?Cons -It barely ever works. Reports from other players say they can barely get past the prologue, infact, the most infamous bug (the one I'm having) is that apparently, this old game from a generation ago will constantly crash on the major area of the game over and over and over. This ruins the entire experience as you'll be busy slashing at orcs while Leana is healing you, your about to land that killing blow! Then a black screen appears, the game says MM.exe is not working and all your blood lust is turned into rage. This is such a horrible flaw because its on every computer past Windows 8.1. That is total crap, the fact that an old game can't run on these high tech systems is like saying you can't use a bullet for your new fancy gun because it now needs "Special Bullets". Until I find a fix for this, steer clear of this game unless you are below Windows 8.1.

number of helpful: 7 of 21 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Dark Messiah is a fantasy action game dressed up like an RPG.  As the nameless one you will explore castles, crypts, caves, orc villages and more on your quest to...I am not sure what the quest is but there is plenty to do/kill along the way.  However you better love the combat (melee, archery, magic) and scenery because the RPG aspects are bland and minimal.  There is character building but it is simple and never really changes how you play the game, just makes you stronger in your particular discipline or allows you to equip special weapons.  Also the skill points to “level up” are only available by completing quests, and there is a set amount so it takes forever to build your character and you are very limited in how strong you can get.  There is inventory management, but no stores to buy and sell, and what you find is also very limited.  Want to interact with NPC characters, there is none of that either except as scripted cut scenes.  As an RPG Dark Messiah is a failure, but as an action game it’s decent but very repetitive.  I made it over half way through hoping the game would get deeper or the story more interesting, but this really is just an action game at heart, and a fairly generic shallow one at that.  If that’s what you are looking for Dark Messiah is not a bad game, however if you are looking for an RPG as I was look elsewhere. I played with the Steam Gamepad, with a little tweaking it worked well and you can map everything you need to the controller if you are so inclined.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												When this game was actually working, it struck me as "okay." I felt like the developers were going for a grand feel, but weren't quite able to achieve it. Everything seemed to feel a bit awkward, especially the combat. Even when out of combat, I felt strangely "off balance," as though I couldn't quite get the right feel for the world my character was in."Dark Messiah" also had significant technical problems on my machine. For reasons I never understood, the framerate would start out well and then gradually drop to the single digits. Reloading an area would fix the problem...only for it to come back. I attempted a couple of different fixes, but I couldn't nail down the problem.In the end, I had a game that just generally wasn't fun to play and would become flat out unplayable after a few minutes.I just can't recommend something like that.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												This game is actually a game of football. EA Sports actually has the rights to the sequel, and has lent the same code for fifa road to world cup (tm) so that they would use the same mechanics, only instead of a leather ball it's orcs, spiders, humans that you kick around. And they fly! Look at them fly! Like tiny dragon butterflies they fly and fall of walls, on spikes very accurately placed so that you can kick your foes into (it's a soccer goal, I know).The magic system is awesome: You have to wait for many seconds in between spells, that are not really better than melée combat at any time in the game. Also, the enemies can run forever, and you can, which is very good, because that means you actually get to die, when 45 enemies spam over you and can run forever while you are like a fat, retired Ronaldo that is about to be hacked to death by angry orc mobs.Also, ingenious, is the fact that the animations are not skippable in game. I love that. You can't stop the orc cleric from having the most boring speech ever.The stealth system is mandatory, and even if it doesn't work, exactly as in real life, it might bring you some advantage before you kick the enemies and you see them flying in the air.Fighting is amazing; your hits don't land, you have no clue how much damage you're dealing, and that makes the game far much more real. Also, using first person shooters with movement combos for power strikes is ingenious, i.e. you will break many mouses. Mouses are fun to break. And Overrated.The game is also very smart: In order to increase the user experience, it will have mandatory game stops that happen at random. Yes, the game will crash on many animations, which makes for excelent user experience and will leave you hungry for more. Don't buy this game.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game. For the part of the game that I was able to play, I did enjoy it a lot. It's a high fantasy first-person linear RPG, with different skill trees, combat types, and hidden secrets. By linear I mean you progress from one level to the next and can't return to older areas. It works really well - the game is surprisingly fun when it works.UInfortunately, I ran into numerous bugs that made it very difficult to proceed. One bug about 2-3 hours into the game makes it unplayable - no matter what you do at a certain stage, you are guaranteed to lose if this bug crops up. Restarting the entire level doesn't fix it. The only way to avoid the bug is to completely restart the entire game, and hope that you don't get the bug AGAIN, which would require another restart.I've searched for patches and mods to fix this and there are none. Until this game-breaking bug gets fixed, I cannot recommend this title, as much as I wish to enjoy it.

number of helpful: 4 of 17 people (24%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												I got hyped about this game reading reviews. After playing for more than half of the game, I honestly regret buying it, even in 75% discount price. This game might have been great in 2006, but it's annoying in 2015 and not really fun. I could overlook the technical aspects due to game's age (except for the forced motion sickness mode), but even the gameplay mechanics are poor compared to newer games (or even, say, Half Life 1).The gameplay issuesEnemy variety is tragic. There are like 4 different enemy types, everyone looks the same, and an area is usually populated by a single type or two. You fight them over and over again.The fact that you can use environment to kill is cool, but in this game you are forced to do so, and you're almost forbidden to use standard means (like, a sword!). Because the enemies are extremely hard when fighting the standard style (they can parry as fast as you can strike and they never miss a parry), but they are extremely vulnerable when anything hits them. Throwing a jar at them can yield a better result than hitting them with a sword from behind to a neck (really, because a jar or a barrel knocks them down and you can then kill them instantly, but hitting them from behind to a head doesn't... makes real sense, and definitely not a gimmick!). So using environment is not a great addition to your fighting style here, it's shoved down your throat and you need to use it all the time.The technical issuesThe game is full of bugs that either make you fail instantly or prevent completion of the area. I had to load a past save several times to work around those. Make sure you save (and don't rely just on a quicksave).You'll get stuck on anything and everything. Using ladders, ropes, jumping through a window, all of that is incredible pain and you'll often die because the engine is dumb.The lighting is so bad that half of the game is well lit and the other half is pitch black (like house interior during a day). Enabling HDR makes it even worse. You can't see a damn thing and you need to use night vision a lot just to work around poor lighting. Adjusting gamma doesn't help too much, you'll still see sh** and the rest will be blinding bright.The hitboxes and targeting, oh damn. Very often you hit something completely else, like a wall *behind* a person. Performing an execution is a random chance whether the game considers you in the right place or not.The UI for switching weapons is far from usable. You can switch from sword+shield to a bow, but you can't switch back. You can either switch bow->sword (and only then add a shield), or switch bow->shield+random weapon (usually not the one you want). Very clever.Forced motion sickness. Oh yes, you human weaklings, the developers will let you suffer, you deserve it. You can disable head bobbing, but that's the least of the problem. The image tilts every time you strafe. Every time you move sideways, your view moves unnaturally, right side up left side down, or vice versa, like boat swaying on a see. I found a way to disable it, otherwise I'd have refunded this immediately. You can see my solution on pcgamingwiki[pcgamingwiki.com].I ended in chapter 6 in crypts, fighting zombies. I didn't see sh**, everything was pitch black so I had to constantly toggle night vision, and it was near impossible to execute a zombie, because of targeting glitches, so the fights took eternity. There was no fun in that.How long can you enjoy throwing barrels at people and kicking them from ramps, when you're forced to do that a thousand times over and there's no other way? 9 hours seems to be my experience. (In hindsight, I was really persistent.)

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												"Kicking Simulator"I really dont know, what I should think about that game and I really dont know, what I should write about it.Based on the Source Engine and Half Life 2, the Game places you into a medival fantasy setting, somehow based on the universe of Heroes of Might and Magic.The story (if we can call this "something" a story) is a classic "slumbering evil is about to get awaken. Player is a unknown noname who will face incredible odds and become a true hero with hidden destiny. I think this is, how IGN would describe this game.But well, lets talk about the story (maybe spoilers!):You are some student of a wizard, discover an artifact, get a mission to hinder the dark forces from unleashing a great evil. Then, after a short intro session (which is quite a nice tutorial), you will get a mysterious female companion, who is bound to you and is only speaking in your head.This is, where the game gets strange, somehow interesting, and crazy and throws tons of klischees at you.Shortly after you are in the middle of a necro army, a cult that will fight evil with evil, your hidden destiny (which is totally silly) and a (total stupid) choice between two sides.The game even have some decisions, you can make and has "4" endings. (kinda)But dont expect a deep story. If the game were a parody of fantasy plots it would be a 20/10. Maybe it is a parody and I got it wrong. But the whole storyline throws so much ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t at you, that you go through 3 phases.First you are enjoying it.Then it annoys you.At last you encountered so much ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, that it starts to be a real fun (like: At this point I will just lean back and smile).The whole story has one good part, which is also its greatest flaw:The two female characters. One a voice talking in your head, the other a young mage, not talking in your head, but is annoying, useless and always in your way. Because of the major plot around these two characters, the whole story seems to be a big funny stupid fanservice. Both characters seems to fight each other to get you, even if they will never meet in the whole game. Both are making you compliments, trying to get your attention and in the end, trying to get you to kill the other one.While the the mage is an annoying little girl, the voice in your head is a well written, awesome voiced character, who is maybe the strongest and most enjoyable element of the game. While I hated every single second hearing the mage girl talking, I enjoyed every second of the other character, laughed about her dark jokes and couldnt do anything but liking her, even if she is "the evil one".Within the game, you have the choice to rescue the mage, after she is captured and nearly fed to giant spiders, after that, she tries to get you cleaned from the voice in your head.I rescued the mage and then tried both decisions...man, I never felt so guilty after killing the voice. It was (given the age of the game) one of the most touching scenes outside of a cutscene in a game.Even after loading my game, I still felt guilty.Well, in the end, siding with the woman in your head, you WILL have to face and kill the mage. It is not even a bossfight. It is a stupid girl, who is mad at you, and wont stand down, until you kill her.Maybe the game want to teach you a lesson of life decisions and their consequences, I dont know.The combat system is somewhat awesome and frustrating. You can block, do different strike attacks, sneak, use bow and magic. But the main part is your enviroment. Every object, you can move, you can use as a weapon. Pick it up, use telekenesis, kick it...you can do so many things, to make your environment your weapon. If you ever felt like it is a good idea to end a mountain fight by kicking your enemy of the cliff, this is your game.But after enjoying your big playground for a few minutes, it will get really annoying after the first hour. Throwing objects will get boring, and a fight at the docks, ending a fight by kicking nearly every enemy into the water, because it is an insta kill, will make you question your life decisions.Swordfight is unsatisfing because the enemy blocks every non power attack and on his side hits you every time, you lower your own block.Magic feels even more static than in skyrim and looks over 5 years older than the game already is. Also it simply does no damage.Ranged comat is flawless, which makes it a flaw. You could play the game with bow only, kicking your enemys out of melee range, camping on top of stairs and feel simply op.Sneaking and dagger fighting feels somehow useless, because you have to put way to many skillpoints into it, but still after the first kill the survivors will start attacking you, even when they couldnt see you. Walking in sneak mode is one of the slowest movements I ever encountered in any game.But my favourite were the bossfights. First looking really good, they mostly will turn into a confusing pseudo cutscene, where you senseless attacking the monster, until one of your followers tells you, what you really have to do.Also I really dont get, how you are able to finish the final fight without any ranged attacks.I really had to push myself to finish this game and Im not really happy about it. It is a game full of great ideas, which could have given the start to an age of medival FPS games, but was so poorly executed, that everyone forgot the game.In the end, the only thing I remember clearly, is the funny voice of Xana (the voice in your head) and I think it is the best memory I can get from this game.Last but not least I want to say: Making the mage girl your follower, making her killable and making her a story relevant character, so you will loose the game, if she dies, and then making her stupid as ♥♥♥♥, running into her death...I was terrified how much I enjoyed the moment, shutting her up for good. What a crazy game, making you go down the evil part, because the only good character makes your skin crawl.(I had a lot of more things I could rant about, but it is irrelevant)

												At first I found this game rather enjoyable. It introduces alot of very interesting and unique concepts along the way, and item progression, as well as skill progression, actually matter quite a bit in this game. The main pitfalls (heh...) of this title are the mechanics, the physics engine. Enemies are tough to kill in combat, even if you tool yourself out with the best equipment possible, the game is brutally difficult. As such, many just resort to ranged combat, and trick the AI into getting stuck, so they can peg them with dozens of arrows. Main issues I encountered were such: Getting lost again and again, which I realised was partly due to several progression bugs which prevent key doors from opening. The level layout does tend to make everything sort of blend in, so figuring out just which corridor contains the identical looking wooden door you need to go through does happen. The rope bow/arrow, well before the latest Croft game and other titles empoyed it, is quite fun, until you start floating through walls while climbing ropes, because the physics engine was not programmed to deal with this vital game mechanic. The number of times I died whilst trying to do the fiddliest of tricky platforming (which as always, in a first person game, is just an awful idea from the start), due to the rope intersecting with a chunk of rock, which caused me to noclip out of the level... It gets frustrating very quickly. Finally, the magic in this game feels utterly flat. Fireballs hit enemies as though you just threw a small water balloon at them. Lightning appears to have the same effect as assaulting your enemy with a particularly wet piece of paper. There was absolutely no appeal to using magic in this game except as a means to use the mana I have anyway. If you really want to try it, nothing I say is going to stop you, but otherwise i'd say leave this game where it belongs, in the past.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
 Originally posted on July 11, 2009 Dark Messiah of Might and magic is a truly disappointing game. From the clunky controls to the frustratingly simple combat, the core game mechanics are boring, and the presentation is quite shabby to boot.Graphics- While some of the game's graphics can look pretty good, the overall effects are very uneven. Especially the game's more open areas look absolutely atrocious in comparison to other source games, as low res textures and bad backdrops abound.Sound- I found the sound design to be generic and not really anything special, although it did the job. The voice acting was pretty bad.Gameplay- The hack and slash mechanics with magic mixed in work much better in other titles that mix these dynamics, but for some reason Dark Messiah features a terribly frustrating control scheme and nonsensical combat mechanics that often feature your character taking damage full seconds after the enemy blows have been deflected. Button mashing combined with circle strafing led me to the most success when playing this game. In short, the gameplay, enemy, weapon and skill systems are pretty generic and do not provide for a satisfying experience.In addition to these concerns, the story is very very dull, providing no narrative flow or any kind of imperative to your actions.Overall, I'd say Dark Messiah is a sad example of low-budget game development gone wrong.

number of helpful: 8 of 59 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												This game is a combination of an action game with some RPG and magic elements. It seems to be very, very interesting.BUT.Could this game be any more harder? It's so hard it's almost ridiculous. I never was able to even finish the first level, even on Easy difficulty. Already the first enemies you encounter are like boss battles. I mean, even with bow and arrow an enemy takes about 5 to 10 shots before dying. A sneaky shot from behind to the head from behind doesn't deal any more damage.This is ridiculous.Additional to that comes the somewhat extremely clunky, not responsive controls. It's just plain awful and frustrating to play.The levels are designed to provide unique ways to kill an enemy, like kicking them into spikes / over the railing or destroying some planks which hold some barrels. This seems to be the ONLY way to succeed in this game, since a direct confrontation is pure suicide. Further problem is: Moving your character seems to be too stiff and not responsive and the back-steps are so tiny you're constantly being attacked.In conclusion for me, this game is way too hard, clunky and therefore no fun at all. I really tried it on Easy difficulty several times with different approaches and even on this setting its unplayable. For hardcore gamers or those who get the right tactic this might be a challenge but for gamers who just want some casual fun now and then, not a good choice.Update: Curiosity made me cheat - so I activated the God Mode, gave myself about 300 skill points and put everything to the maximum. I have to say: Good thing I didn't play this game the normal way so the disappointment came rather short. The visual effects and presentation of the spells like fireball or lightning bolt (both are fired through your hands) are looking, feeling and sounding very, VERY uninspired and boring.Don't buy it. And for the haters: Just respect another person's opinion. It's not that hard ;)

												Kicking Orcs Off Ledges Simulator 2006 still stands up today as the ultimate kicking things off ledges experience. There is more to it than just kicking, however. Posted: March 2, 2014
												Arkane Studios never was a well-known studio until their deal with Bethesda to make the critically acclaimed game; Dishonored. Before their rise to recognition. Arkane Studios made a semi-obscure game called Dark Messiah of Might & Magic. Dark Messiah of Might & Magic, is the story about a young man named Sareth who has been trained his whole life by his mentor named Wizard Phenrig. In time he is finally given a task on helping his mentor Phenrig to find a sacred crystal called the Shantiri Crystal. After retrieving the Crystal, he's sent off by Phenrig to travel to the city of Stonehelm in which he's to deliver the crystal to another Wizard named Menelag, who is lord of Stonehelm. Though Sareth doesn't go alone and is given a spirit guide by Phenrig called Xana, who resides in Sareth mind. DMOMAM (Dark Messiah of Might & Magic) story is possibly one of the worst stories a fantasy game could ever have. From the characters names, dialogue and boring and forgetful lore. DMOMAM doesn't seem to have any redeeming qualities in this field. Characters are usually shuffled in and out as quick as possible with very little backstory or personality to them. Many of the characters are more annoying than interesting. The spiritual guide; Xana is by far the most annoying out of the bunch as she literally talks in a sinister and almost hammy voice which is off putting beyond belief. The voice acting in the game is also terrible with chew-scenery attitudes and almost wooden performance from each character. Even if they were good it wouldn't have saved the goofy dialogue.Though this may be the case for DMOMAM, what the game really shines on is its gameplay. DMOMAM's gameplay features a wide range of skills and traits for Sareth to choose from. This game is more fantasy RPG in skills than any other aspect. The game provides Stealth, Combat and magic as the main skills in which you can choose from. When specializing in one skill it can be very satisfying taking out enemies, like using a fireball to sizzle opponents alive, hack off a enemies head with sword, use the bow to take out targets from a distance and use Stealth to backstab your enemies silently. All is great fun and having the use of the kick mechanic can send enemies flying to their death onto spiked walls or off ledges. This is helped by the fact that the game engine that they use is the Source Engine. Which does good use with the physics and certain traps that are featured in the game. DMOMAM does have some slip-ups with the combat though, sometimes the games hit detection glitches up, making you miss your opponents body, leaving you open to be hit. Because the game uses an actual character in first-person than a set of floating hands, it can be hard to navigate when climbing up stones and buildings in high places, leading you to a quick death. The stealth though good in some areas, is flawed in that it’s too easy to sneak and hide. The game uses an indicator which goes from 0-4 bars (0 being exposed, 4 being hidden), sometimes you'll be completely hidden even though you are out in board daylight which doesn't make any sense. The graphics in the game are quite good and have aged well since the games release, with good physics and great lighting and textures, the game does holds up very well and helps with the immersion of the game. Art design of the world is quite boring when located in cities such as Stonehelm but at great when going through the mountains and dark caves. The sound design is quite weak when coming to certain sound especially from magic spells. DMOMAM though is a game with tons of potential but a lot of things bring it down. It is a fun game though and will keep you entertained due to its RPG skills tree which will give you a decent amount of replay value. (Strong) 6.50/ 10.0

Posted: February 23, 2014
												This game...it needs to win the underrated game of the universe award.  Apparently went it first released, it was hampered with bugs and over shadowed by games like Oblivion. It is a Source Engine based game that plays very much like a combination of Thief and Half Life controls/combat.  It uses chapters/missions similar to both of those games as well.  It isn't open world but that won't bother you because there is plenty of loot hidden in secret areas for you to find.  It also starts off a bit rough with a hard to understand story and uninteresting at the time, plus the combat is difficult until you get new skills/weapons.  The combat in this game is so well done, especially for a game this old.  Most people say that if Elder Scrolls had this combat, they would be the best games ever made.  You'll have so much fun kicking enemies into spikes, fire, off stairs and using the many types of weapons you find along the way.  You even get to forge a few weapons.  Once you get past the first few chapters the story and gameplay really get great. I highly suggest playing on Hard mode because it forces you to use the various methods of fighting within the environment well.  You can activate traps laced within rooms like cutting ropes on swining objects, throwing oil on the ground and lighting enemies on fire, etc.  This game was worth every penny and I can't wait to finish it.Pros- Brilliant Combat System (super fun)- Variety of weapons to use and loot- Challenging Difficulties- Interesting Environments- Great Inventory and Skill System- Interactive Environments and SecretsCons- Mission based - Not Open World (plenty to explore though)- Story is bland at times- Steep learning curve- Unbalanced beginning- Slightly outdated and a few bugs remain (not the spiders)Score 9/10

Posted: March 12, 2014
												I kicked a guard in the crotch and sent him flying towards a firey death. 10/10.Okay, seriously tho, Dark Messiah is a game that wants me to hate it: The combat is repetitive and dull early on (not to mention some of the very frustrating enemy mechanics), the story is very predictable, the environment design can sometimes be really confusing and, to top it all off, the game is riddled with glitches (but considering this is a Source based game, I think that’s to be expected).But yet, I can’t dislike this game, no matter how hard I try: It’s incredibly immersive; it has an amazing atmosphere and succeeds at making you feel like some sort of almighty jack-of-all-trades warrior. The level design can be confusing, yes, but it’s creative and entertaining. The combat does get a lot quicker and more intense as the game goes on, and the huge “bosses” you have to fight through the game are all epic and nerve-wrecking.Overall, this game is a recommend for me, but only to people who are willing to overlook some pretty major flaws in order to find a very entertaining and unique adventure. Fully action-based FPSRPGs are hard to find, and Dark Messiah finds that niche nicely. If nothing else, give the demo a shot. It gives you a pretty good idea of what you’re in for.

Posted: August 22, 2011
												Probably one of my most replayed singleplayer games because of all the different ways you bring pain to the not so defenseless (and quite tough!) enemies. Wether it be outplaying them in the way of melee combat or simply being a lil bich and chucking a barrel right in their face, this game offers many, MANY ways to play it with its huge replay value.Wanna be a spell-casting mage that still fights with swords with the occasional use of bows?Go right the hell ahead, there is absolutely no limitations that stop you from doing just that.The incredible versatility and depth of the combat system provides many etertaining ways to dispatch enemies. Learn ice magic and freeze your enemies. Discover that you can use said spell on the ground and create a patch of ice, watch and laugh your♥♥♥♥♥off as 5 orcs coming to chase you all slip on said ice and fall to their deaths. This is just one of the many past times you'll come to see in this gameThe game is built on the source engine and makes use of all the nice, juicy physics engine that we've all come to love over time. Pick up heavy objects and toss it at enemies which results in the enemy stumbling hilariously in whatever direction the object was thrown in. Use your mighty Duke Nukem boot to send a baddy flying down a crevice or to send them into the many VERY  convinently traps.The RPG elements certainly blend well with the game, with the skill trees being flexible and many of the skills being quite handy. You are also able to spread your skills however you please so it opens up many possibilities on different playstyles that will certainly not all be experienced in just one single playthrough.

Posted: August 9, 2013
												Right off the bat, Dark Messiah makes me question the simplistic nature of all combat in the Elder's Scrolls games. One thing is clear, though. Dark Messiah is a PC game, meant for gamers rather than mainstream turkies (gobble gobble!).Comparisons aside, this game has its moments but the AI is rather simplistic. Combine this with highly linear mapping and progression, and you have something very close to a late 90's-early 2000's, relic. Still, the distinction between the "classes" is well done. Magic, however, is feeble through most of the game without certain gameplay "tweaks". Typical really, as most devs have little vision for such things. Once you get a certain upgrade, however, you become untouchable. That's abstinent, rudimentry balancing if I ever saw it. The main problem lies with the adrenaline system and why magic had to be tied to it.Like most medieval-based games of this nature, Dark Messiah is catered primarily towards fans of swords, shields, and gimmicky action. I will say they did a good job of it, though. Progression and mapping may be simple, but the environment itself can be a lethal weapon. Magic may be feeble, but it's done just well enough to be enjoyable.
