An unofficial fix can be found here:         http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Dark_Messiah_of_Might_and_Magic#Crash_when_exiting_the_game     -Game may crash while loading a level.     -Sometimes the dialoge does not display, runs slow, or goes too fast.     -You'll be unable to read some of the tips on the loading screen if your PC loads the game too   quick.     -It is possible to get your character stuck on certain areas.     -It is possible to make your inventory & skill bar unusable after performing an assassination on enemy from a certain angle.-The game uses a field of view of 85°, which cannot be modified even with the command "default_fov #". In order to change the field of view you must enable cheats with "sv_cheats 1" then select the field of view to your liking with the command "fov #", but note that you must set your field of view again when your character gains a special ability.Other Info:-The game does not have large address aware enabled.-32-bit executable.PCGamingWiki Page: http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Dark_Messiah_of_Might_and_MagicWould I buy? Posted: March 12, 2014
												I kicked a guard in the crotch and sent him flying towards a firey death. 10/10.Okay, seriously tho, Dark Messiah is a game that wants me to hate it: The combat is repetitive and dull early on (not to mention some of the very frustrating enemy mechanics), the story is very predictable, the environment design can sometimes be really confusing and, to top it all off, the game is riddled with glitches (but considering this is a Source based game, I think that’s to be expected).But yet, I can’t dislike this game, no matter how hard I try: It’s incredibly immersive; it has an amazing atmosphere and succeeds at making you feel like some sort of almighty jack-of-all-trades warrior. The level design can be confusing, yes, but it’s creative and entertaining. The combat does get a lot quicker and more intense as the game goes on, and the huge “bosses” you have to fight through the game are all epic and nerve-wrecking.Overall, this game is a recommend for me, but only to people who are willing to overlook some pretty major flaws in order to find a very entertaining and unique adventure. Fully action-based FPSRPGs are hard to find, and Dark Messiah finds that niche nicely. If nothing else, give the demo a shot. It gives you a pretty good idea of what you’re in for.

Posted: March 2, 2014
												    Not normally a huge fan of dark dungeon type video games but lately have been finding quite a lot of joy in this one.  2006 release date but when I first played I thought the game was a lot older.  Not necessarily a bad thing because to me it felt authentic and I felt like it reached back through time a grabbed some of that fun and imagination that Gygax inspired with his RPG.  Very easy interface for new gamers and the items and attacks are straight forward and REALLY easy to use and understand.  It's a little too easy to become overpowerful if putting all points in might, stealth, and health and makes the game go by SUPER fast. Try mixing it up with spells and looting to get a little more flavor of the game. All in all a very fun, quick game and something I enjoyed very much. Two thumbs up.

Posted: February 25, 2014
												I bought this game two days before and i have already finished it TWO times.Lets begin from the start, DM(dark messiah)  is a FPS RPG pretty much like skyrim but without an open world.By gaining points (you gain points by completing main or secondary quests)  you can choose the path you feel is best for you (assassin,warrior or mage) through a skilltree( ofcourse you are able to be an hybrid for instance an assassin with spells).The skilltree i mentioned before offers MANY unsual but very awsome skills and abilities.The part that excited the most, is the combat, except from blocking ,hittting and avoiding hits you are able to use the enviroment to your advantage for example kick an enemy to spikes,fire etc or activate a trap killing instantly the enemy.In addition to that ,DM has a big variety of BOSSES which are not just NPCs with tons of HP but most of them must be fought diffently.Also,DM offers many weapons(swords,bows,staffs,daggers and shields) which are mostly hidden inside secret rooms.Another great aspect of this game is his great storyline with FOUR(4) alternative endings based on your decisions through the game.My first playthrough lasted 15 hours and DM is a game that you should play it again trying another class and making other choices.In conclusion ,I believe DM is a MUST-BUY game for the fans of FPS-RPG gamers  and in comparison with today's-RPG games I strongly believe it is SUPERIOR in almost all aspects!!! 9/10

Posted: February 28, 2014
												Disclaimer: This game is extremely buggy on Windows 7. Alt-tabbing is almost guaranteed to crash it. Sometimes it just crashes because it feels like it.Other than that, this game is great. The world is fairly generic high fantasy, but it does have a dark atmosphere to it that sets it apart. The game is called "Might and Magic" - but by far the most fun and viable way to play the game is Might. The first person melee combat is actually enjoyable and fairly deep.The most fun part of the game, though, is kicking things. The playable character has a mighty boot that is extremely satisfying to hit enemies with, and the game is littered with deadly things for you to kick them into. Kick them off ledges, into spikes, into fires, etc.

Posted: March 5, 2014
												Ah, Dark Messiah. A wonderful game! I had a lot of fun with this one.Graphics:Source engine. Sharp textures nice physics. There isn't much to say about it really. The graphics look fine and they are holding up well to this day. Oh there is one thing, you are able to see your own feet. I think this is important, it somehow adds a lot of "friction" to the world (think: Arx Fatalis)Sound:Okay. Has oomph. Little music in this game - which is a good thing (think: Dark Souls).Story:You are a hero on a quest to save some part of some world. I don't think there were any rats in a basement to kill, but there is a succubus manifested in your head that'll talk to you occasionally, resulting in some funnily greasy moments. It's nothing special all in all - but the succubus gives it a decent twist.Gameplay:This is where Messiah shines. Luckily - who gives a damn about graphics and story in an ego-fantasy-rpg-hackfest? Well, lay aside the rpg, there isn't much roleplaying to do apart from some character development. This character development will decide whether you'll be casting, shooting arrows or close combating your way through the world, and with the given physics and environmental dangers in level design this gives for some really awesome fights. I love the fights! I love the kick, i love the brutal finishing moves and i love the kick. Yea, you can kick people off high places in this game, and you'll never grow tired of that since there are about a million ledges to kick people, orcs and other monsters off of... of? The combat is awesome, like seriously. It's like Skyrim done right! It's fast paced, it's gritty, it's evil and it'll make you feel like a real Badass Dark Messiah of Might and Magic! You should get this game just because of that. That's it. Start, and don't stop playing until you get to the Orc village. If you hold through until then, you will start loving the game. But yea, until then everything is weird. Combat mechanics feel odd and the game starts slow and boring.I beat this game annually, because it's cool.

												A fun, if familiar first person magic/melee game with light RPG elements. Runs on the Source engine so don't expect the prettiest game but it runs like a a dream. Large, nicely designed levels with lots of secrets to find. A number of ways to play through the game whether you want to go magic, melee or archer. Special shoutout to the greatest kick in the history of gaming. Kicking enemies off of ledges or into the ocean is a blast. The story is slight but there are four different endings depending on a few decisions. I think I got this game for $5 in a Might and Magic pack so I'd say it's definitely worth that.

Posted: June 28, 2015
												Advertised as the first ever First Person Slasher, the game is a mix of RPG and FPS elements that is surprisingly fun, but a little cluncky. I really like the atmosphere and some aspects of the art design, and the three skill trees you can pursue offer distinctly different styles of play. That and different endings avaliable offer a degree of replayability. If you want to go on an adventure in the world of Might & Magic (specifically Ashan) slashing, shooting and/or casting spells on fantastical creatures like orcs, ogres, cyclopses, skeletons, zombies etc. this is the game for you. The game also has a multiplayer mode, but even soon after the premiere I had difficulty finding other people to play, so I can't recommend it for people who mainly play online.

												Amazingly fun singleplayer action. From beheading enemies in a slow-motion moment to tossing corpses at goblins! The combat in this game is intense and keeps you on your toes. I would like to say that they could have added a wider variety of weaponry but with what they have, it's fantastic! Posted: April 26, 2016
												A personal anecdote from yours truly.I was a young'un during the heyday of EverQuest, and later WoW.  Too young to muster the resources to see those games in action, let alone play them.  (Yes, that means videos too -- dialup, motherf**ker, have you used it?)  So I was left to simply imagine the majesty of these virtual worlds.  Mind you, I wasnt raised on Dungeons & Dragons, frankly I found Tolkienesque fantasy a tired premise before I even knew the name 'Tolkien'.  But gaming was the new frontier of entertainment, and the idea of entering a bona fide fantasy realm set my little mind ablaze with possiblity.Maybe I 'missed the wave' with MMORPGs.  Or maybe my years with Counter-Strike took the sheen off multiplayer gaming.  But by the time I finally saw WoW for myself, I couldn't care less.  I'll gladly take five minutes of deathmatch over a month of MMO banality.But then I randomly found this game, Dark Messiah.  And I was amazed at how it looked and played exactly like the MMO fantasy I had imagined all those years.  Combat wasnt just a mathematical abstraction, the level design looked like a coherent living world (even though, ultimately, its a linear FPS affair) and the art direction made the most out of everything to immerse you into it's world.  This was the fantasy adventure I wanted, but didnt get, from MMORPGs.The only thing missing is the multiplayer, but thats a fair trade IMO.  Pubbies ruin everything anyway...

Posted: August 8, 2015
												This is literally the best Multiplayer RPG I've ever played. It has distinct classes and the sorceress could use a nerf to her bramble + stone skin build, but it's not going to happen at this point.Just to make it short, it's a PvP first person fighting game where you choose a role and evolve as you complete objectives. Warriors are melee beasts, archers have powerful long range attacks, mages focus on area damage, assassins can backstab and instakill anyone, sorceresses heal and debuff enemies... And you get to choose the path you want to follow for each class. It's a pity the game's dead because it's one of the best multiplayer PvPs I've ever played.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												The game shows the signs of age, but nonetheless a good remark about some aspects that RPGs usually don't take into account.Pros:+ Good gameplay, with a wide range of possible strategies to afford enemies;+ Environment can (must) be used; also, good stealth mechanism;+ Multiple endings: now we're all used to it, but back in the time it must have been awesome and it's right to give it the right credit.Cons:- Lack of secondary quests and lore - set aside the choices for the endings, the storyline is straightforward;- Few customization options for the character's skills;- Poor enemy IA, counterbalanced by high damage output - no way to be tank;- The story is nothing new under the sun.There might be other pros and cons, but the main ones are here. Recommended, for the nostalgic or the "collector" who wants to see with his eyes an RPG which gives importance to the environment (I'm both).

Posted: December 27, 2011
												This game is simply amazing once it gets going. While the combat and movement may seem a bit clunky at first, you quickly get the hang of it and realize what all it offers. Many games say they deal environmental damage, but Dark Messiah is the only one I know of that continues to offer alternative routes for just about every thing you can possibly do. While you are not technically in an open world, the large levels with a plethora of secrets and alternate routes give you the illusion of one.  I'm still finding secrets several play throughs later. If you like first person action/adventure games, particularly those like Thief, you should definitely give this game a try.

Posted: July 30, 2015
												I bought this game almost on Day 1 back in 2006 - Steam seemed to have reset my progress during an update, so I gave it another run-though.This is a great game, very underrated and immensely fun - albeit flawed in a few areas.The graphics are amazing for 2006 standards, Source is used very well, the environments are beautiful, the atmosphere great and the models are also decent. The game is BRUTAL, finisher moves, burning corpses, beheadings, turn limbs etc.The gameplay... oh dear, how do I even describe this. "Might&Magic" is about right, I'd say. On my first playthrough, I decided to go full-on Warrior (usually I'd go for a mix, paladin-ish thing), and it was IMMENSELY fun, the combat is great once you get the hang of it, although I'm sorry I didn't play it on hard, because once you get beefed up a little, slaying enemies is a bit too unchallenging. I think I died maybe twice the whole campagin during combat. When you get the Lightning Shield and the Dragonborn sword, well, it just gets ridiculous.On my second playthrough, I chose a full-on Mage (combat mage, staff and all) and while I was a bit whimpy at first, by the end, I was even MORE powerful than a Warrior. Mana-sucking staff and Sanctuary=god mode, basically. I wasn't new to the game though, so that helped, but still, if you're going for a narrow, "one-trick-pony" build, perhaps play on Hard right off the bat, otherwise you might wade through enemies like dust.The reason why I said "Might and Magic is about right" is that I tried doing the whole Stealth/Thief thing, and more often times than not, it falls a bit flat. It's either too easy (really obvious ledges and rafters to avoid enemies) or too hard (open areas where you can't really be sneaky at all), and the inconsistent Stealth meter doesn't help - you can be "invisible" in plain torchlight or completely visible in total darkness; go figure.  The story is... alright, it has a few twists, and the game has 4 endings, depending on which woman you choose to leave alive and what you do at the very end. It's alright, but to me, it was really corny, though it wasn't necessarily the bad kind of corny either. Oh, and the voice acting is pretty cringe-worthy, it's just soooo emPHATIC and exaggerated to death. Nothing like the subtle delivery of Half-Life's Alyx or Barney, hell, even Dr. Mossman wasn't as annoying as most of the characters in this game. Not driving an Orc Cleaver through Leanna's face requires some serious self-control, believe me.One more (rather major) gripe: it does have a tendency to glitch/crash at times. The Rope Bow close to flat surfaces is a classic example, then there are random crashes, overall, it's not the most stable of games, so save often.All in all, it's Skyrim/Oblivion without the overbearing world and clunky combat system. It's a non-stealthy Thief. It deserves your attention and at the very LEAST, two playthroughs.

Posted: July 21, 2011
												You like Single-player RPGs? You think that Bioware is awesome for making Dragon Age or Mass Effect?Here's the real gem of Biowares RPG team. Dark Messiah is a brilliant blend of storytelling and first person action. From a team that understood the birlliance of the "Thief" games, we get an immersive action game with dynamic and deeply interactive combat. You can pick-up and throw almost every single object in the game.Have to fight three guards at once? Throw a chair at them to knock them down, grab a pot of oil to smash on them, and then light your arrows on fire using a nearby torch and light 'em up.Sword to sword combat not exciting enough? They throw in an any-time any-where kick key allowing you to manipulate combat like never before.Really though, check it out.Oh, and although I doubt Multiplayer still has an active playerbase, fun fact: They had a seperate development team for the MP so it doesn't feel tacked on. It's a whole 'nother freaking game.

Posted: September 9, 2015
												Set the constant crashing aside and you have a game that immerses you into great first person combat. For a game released in 2006, it really feels like it was ahead of its time.Pros: - Solid physics based combat- RPG elements allow you to build your character into various specialties without getting too complicated or barring you from selecting multiple paths.- Solid story in the Might and Magic universe. It is enoughCons: - Save often as the game tends to crash whenever it gets the chance to load (icon in the upper right).- There were times I had to remember hard why I was in an area storywise. Could be that I was simply immersed in fighting though!

Posted: September 7, 2015
												No, This game doesn't redefine first-person action RPGs. No, this isn't on the scale of Obllivion or Skyrim. However, this game is a blast to play.I personally love the combat components that some people hate, like how kicking enemies and throwing barrels are powerful as hell. It is worthy to note that this game is focused on weapon-based combat while the dope spells are pretty much just side-moves. For me, that's a plus and its the way I like to play. By the way, there's impaling. That's also a huge plus from me.This game runs on the source engine, so it's moderately pretty. The story isn't grand, but I still quite enjoyed how it progressed. Yes, it's linear, but there's still a lot to do in this game to get around the story. The music is complementary to the gameplay and enjoyable to the ears.This may not be a mind-blowing or absolutely innovative game, but it's fun to play. With its many weapons and ways to kill enemies, I give this an 8/10.Just don't expect an incredibly innovative storying or expansive world.

Posted: July 14, 2011
												This is a forgotten gem. A first-person perspective action/adventure/RPG game set in the world of Heroes of MIght and Magic, it plays very similar to the old Thief classics. Combat is very difficult and you often have to use the environment to your advantage to survive a battle against more than one enemy. You get skill points for reaching objectives in the game, and you can spend them on combat skills, magic skills or "general" skills (thief, plus stat increases). You to combine powers to create many fun character builds.If I can find something to criticize it is the 2d female characters. You have one ♥♥♥♥♥♥ temptress, and one saintly good girl, and you get to choose between them. That's it. The level design is fantastic though. Chasing a fleeing thief across rooftops of a city, moving across crumbling orc huts precariously put at the side of a great mountain. Areas all look great and are fun to explore, and are filled to the brim with secrets.

Posted: June 28, 2015
												Advertised as the first ever First Person Slasher, the game is a mix of RPG and FPS elements that is surprisingly fun, but a little cluncky. I really like the atmosphere and some aspects of the art design, and the three skill trees you can pursue offer distinctly different styles of play. That and different endings avaliable offer a degree of replayability. If you want to go on an adventure in the world of Might & Magic (specifically Ashan) slashing, shooting and/or casting spells on fantastical creatures like orcs, ogres, cyclopses, skeletons, zombies etc. this is the game for you. The game also has a multiplayer mode, but even soon after the premiere I had difficulty finding other people to play, so I can't recommend it for people who mainly play online.

Posted: May 10, 2015
												This is one of my favourite games of all time. I've played it lots of times, even before I bought it on Steam. How the metascore could be 72 is beyond me. Anyway, here's a list of advantages and disadvantages:con:-It has some technical difficulties sometimes-you will fight a lot of clones, all with the same voicesliterally nothing elsepro:-It has one of the best combat systems I know,-you can play it in many different ways, because--a: you can interact with the environment in so many ways, and--b: the skill system, which does not offer many skills, offers a few really powerful ones, so that you can quickly specialize significantly. Especially if you use the according items.-the level design is simply divine.-story is archetypal, but with brilliant cutscenes and very nice characters, given the relatively short time in which they appear.-the story is embedded in the Might and Magic universe, so it has a lot of background and many references to the stories in the Heroes of Might and Magic series.-the art design is great, it really feels like something different altogether and something very raw, gritty and realistic. So even now, years after the graphics are actually outdated, it still looks good. -the overall atmosphere is thrilling and tense in a way I do not experience often in video games.So, don't let the age or the low metascore fool you, this game gets 9.5/10

												The singleplayer is a truly unique and (yes, in this case, the word fits) epic experience, it's a pity that the game is hard to mod and didn't ever get a sequel. Lot's of hack 'n slay fun with a combat system that may LOOK like Oblivion/Skyrim/..., but is superior and more fluent in any way. Posted: August 14, 2015
												Great game overall. Some funny aspects to it like kicking enemies off ledges or into fires. You can also pick their corpses up and toss them into the fire. Like the fact that there are other options to make them fall off cliffs. Great that there are a lot of fires and/or spikes into which you can cause their demise. Challenging game. Parts of the game actually time you so you have to rush like the roof top chase (not many now that do that cause most are easy mode). There's difficulty modes also a plus. There are however a few bugs and the games graphics are outdated but hey it's an older game what can you expect. Great choices on how your character can be made (skill options). Great time consuming game (in a good way unless it makes you late for work, classes, etc. lol. Overall I'd say this is worth the price.

Posted: November 25, 2010
												A really great and terribly underrated game. It's a bit like Half-Life mixed with Oblivion, in that it has a linear story but RPG elements that allow you to build whatever kind of character you like, whether it be a swordfighter, sorcerer, assassain, or a combination of different abilities. Has great combat and bloody fatality-style moves that are always fun to do. It even has good multiplayer, which combines classed-based point capturing like TF2 with a per-round experience system that gives you greater abilities like in the single-player (although I don't know how many people are on the multiplayer anymore). A really fun game the whole way through, and a must-play for it's price.

Posted: February 25, 2014
												I bought this game two days before and i have already finished it TWO times.Lets begin from the start, DM(dark messiah)  is a FPS RPG pretty much like skyrim but without an open world.By gaining points (you gain points by completing main or secondary quests)  you can choose the path you feel is best for you (assassin,warrior or mage) through a skilltree( ofcourse you are able to be an hybrid for instance an assassin with spells).The skilltree i mentioned before offers MANY unsual but very awsome skills and abilities.The part that excited the most, is the combat, except from blocking ,hittting and avoiding hits you are able to use the enviroment to your advantage for example kick an enemy to spikes,fire etc or activate a trap killing instantly the enemy.In addition to that ,DM has a big variety of BOSSES which are not just NPCs with tons of HP but most of them must be fought diffently.Also,DM offers many weapons(swords,bows,staffs,daggers and shields) which are mostly hidden inside secret rooms.Another great aspect of this game is his great storyline with FOUR(4) alternative endings based on your decisions through the game.My first playthrough lasted 15 hours and DM is a game that you should play it again trying another class and making other choices.In conclusion ,I believe DM is a MUST-BUY game for the fans of FPS-RPG gamers  and in comparison with today's-RPG games I strongly believe it is SUPERIOR in almost all aspects!!! 9/10

												Disclaimer: This game is extremely buggy on Windows 7. Alt-tabbing is almost guaranteed to crash it. Sometimes it just crashes because it feels like it.Other than that, this game is great. The world is fairly generic high fantasy, but it does have a dark atmosphere to it that sets it apart. The game is called "Might and Magic" - but by far the most fun and viable way to play the game is Might. The first person melee combat is actually enjoyable and fairly deep.The most fun part of the game, though, is kicking things. The playable character has a mighty boot that is extremely satisfying to hit enemies with, and the game is littered with deadly things for you to kick them into. Kick them off ledges, into spikes, into fires, etc.

Posted: November 25, 2015
												This incredibly cheap game represents many hours of good entertainment. This excellent 1st person shooting game (not even close to open world RPG as TES) is presenting an advanced combat system full of opportunities, like using the main characters superpowers (that means his right leg) to kick your enemies of heights, maybe the best feature of the game. You may also throw anything you find on the ground at your enemies in combat, like a dead body, a small clay pot or a barrel. I would reccomend the barrel as that may actually destroy wooden floors. The combat in this game requires more of the player than many other games, especially in the start. You have to see the possibilities around you in order to defeat enemies of equal strength to you (Equal strength in the start, before you get to the fancy stuff). You have to search for heights, throwable items or spikes to kick them on that is there for the only purpose of helping you kill your enemies. In some locations there is even secret traps you might trigger to help you against your enemies.Just to settle the way your character advances through the game for all who might wonder. There is no direct class and leveling system. In the start of the game you will always begin with the same character, and he will be step by step customized by your choices. As you complete objectives you will gain skill points, and you may use those skill points to become a better fighter, learn new spells, become a better archer, better sneaker or even gain more hitpoints.Then you may make a balanced character or maybe a character that only knows how to fight with his sword. I myself has played much with the sword/archer combo character, and I found that quite entertaining and would reccomand that if you don't have any preferences yourself.There are in total two weapons you may craft yourself in the game with a very complicated and overdone crafting system, yet maybe more realistic than most games. Both of these are swords. There are many secret locations with magic equipment, traps that can kill you or other fun stuff.The story of Dark Messiah is a standalone story, but it is recognizable with the story of the strategy game Heroes of Might and Magic V, set to the world ashan. Many people think the plot weak, but if you have played the Heroes V vanilla campaign you will recognize characters and elements, and the plot will seem quite strong. I might say that the main character in Dark Messiah is the son of two characters that you meet in Heroes V. There is a love story in this game as well, where you have to chose between two women eventually, but it hardly affects the game's outcome at all.Many people are dissapointed because the online servers to the multiplayer version are shut down. That does not mean that there is no hope. I think there are still hosted servers if you do some web research, or check out the steam community, but the official servers are shut down. I have heard about a few guides to find servers to the multiplayer game, but I haven't felt any urge myself to try it.There are a few bugs with this game. The most major one in my case was that the program Dark Messiah of Might and Magic.exe stopped working every time I tried to quit the game, but that is not a major problem, and it will not affect your saves if that worries you.The animations and graphics of the game are staring to get a little poor, but the game is 9 years old, so that is to be expected. I would compare the graphics to TES IV: Oblivion. There is still an incredible amount of detail in the game despite the old outdated textures.Dark Messiah of Might and Magic is a very enjoyable game, and I ensure you that you will experience a most powerful right leg. If you want to buy it I would suggest you check out Heroes of Might and Magic V as well (not VI and VII). I bought Dark Messiah with the Heroes V pack, and I reccomend that game as well (but it is not as good as this). Hint: Archery might be difficult until you learn to hold your bow steady, but a head shot is a head shot.

												This game...it needs to win the underrated game of the universe award.  Apparently went it first released, it was hampered with bugs and over shadowed by games like Oblivion. It is a Source Engine based game that plays very much like a combination of Thief and Half Life controls/combat.  It uses chapters/missions similar to both of those games as well.  It isn't open world but that won't bother you because there is plenty of loot hidden in secret areas for you to find.  It also starts off a bit rough with a hard to understand story and uninteresting at the time, plus the combat is difficult until you get new skills/weapons.  The combat in this game is so well done, especially for a game this old.  Most people say that if Elder Scrolls had this combat, they would be the best games ever made.  You'll have so much fun kicking enemies into spikes, fire, off stairs and using the many types of weapons you find along the way.  You even get to forge a few weapons.  Once you get past the first few chapters the story and gameplay really get great. I highly suggest playing on Hard mode because it forces you to use the various methods of fighting within the environment well.  You can activate traps laced within rooms like cutting ropes on swining objects, throwing oil on the ground and lighting enemies on fire, etc.  This game was worth every penny and I can't wait to finish it.Pros- Brilliant Combat System (super fun)- Variety of weapons to use and loot- Challenging Difficulties- Interesting Environments- Great Inventory and Skill System- Interactive Environments and SecretsCons- Mission based - Not Open World (plenty to explore though)- Story is bland at times- Steep learning curve- Unbalanced beginning- Slightly outdated and a few bugs remain (not the spiders)Score 9/10

Posted: January 29, 2012
												Though swords and magic settings are primarily used by rpgs, this game uses the setting for an action game. There are no choices, shops, or overworld. There is character customization in which gear you can equip, spells, if any, to use, and the like. Combat is fairly decent, with variety in weapons, swords, daggers, staves, and such. But the most fun you can have is seeing the ways in which you can cause environmental deaths by using your kick to knock enemies around. Whether it be spikes, cliffs, traps, or mixing it up by hitting them with a pot of oil, then lighting it, environmental deaths are often the funniest and most efficient ways to defeat your foes. At ten dollars, it's not a bad buy, but Steam has sales with it often enough, so pick it up then, and it will truly be worth it.

I was woken up by a house servant and was told someone was attacking us, as I got off the bed an enemy ran up the stairs and tried attacking him. I moved into the way and parried with my dual daggers and dispatched him.After opening the front door I was spotted by 4 enemies and they started to use bows on me, so I pulled back in and closed the door and let them come to me. I then realized the servant was upstairs so i decided to do a final last stand on top of the stairs to protect him and use as a natural choke point.I consider this game at least $10 as I find it enjoyable, not everyone is the same. So it's up to you if you want to play this title.Story 4/10Gameplay 7/10Fun 8/10Price 10/10

Posted: July 14, 2014
												My word this game is underappreciated/underrated!!This perfectly represents what the game industry used to be like - the main design goal/focus being on the player having fun!A world that acts as a playground for your own creativity and enjoyment. All real-time physics - no scripted death sequences if an enemy gets too close to your character's proximity, no cover/hide-mechanics to disguise shoddy/unreliable coding - just you and the endless options afforded to you by the power of your imagination!!If you miss the good old days of the early era of 3-D gaming and the exquisite experimentation and boundary-pushing software that was developed at the time, then this game is ideal! Harken back to the platinum years of sandbox gameplay, right here!I would easily place this game in my top 100 list, it's that entertaining. A true diamond in the dust.Arkane Studios are rapidly becoming one of my all-time fav developers.

Posted: July 11, 2014
												Have you ever wondered how does it feel, to cast a freezing spell on an orc, then slash him into pieces with an arrow? If you did, check out Dark Messiah. The gameplay is absolutely flawless - using the environment, to destroy your enemies. If that's not enough, create your own hero: you can became a warrior, who is mastered with one handed weapons, and a shield. If you are not the fan of weapons, you can became a wizard: lethal fireballs, freezing spells, or just pick up a barrel with telekinesis, and smash their heads. Too much offensive battles? Then become a rogue! Dual-wielding daggers, and hiding in the darkness. Just stab'em in the back, or just kick them in the end of a cliff. Multiple endings (depending on which side you choose on your adventure), genial soundtrack, and the list goes on and on - absolutely marvelous game, but sadly it's way UNDERRATED! The only problem that the multiplayer isn't the best. If you like dark-fantasy, or you're an FPS-fan, but searching for something different, you should check out this masterpiece!

Posted: July 21, 2011
												You like Single-player RPGs? You think that Bioware is awesome for making Dragon Age or Mass Effect?Here's the real gem of Biowares RPG team. Dark Messiah is a brilliant blend of storytelling and first person action. From a team that understood the birlliance of the "Thief" games, we get an immersive action game with dynamic and deeply interactive combat. You can pick-up and throw almost every single object in the game.Have to fight three guards at once? Throw a chair at them to knock them down, grab a pot of oil to smash on them, and then light your arrows on fire using a nearby torch and light 'em up.Sword to sword combat not exciting enough? They throw in an any-time any-where kick key allowing you to manipulate combat like never before.Really though, check it out.Oh, and although I doubt Multiplayer still has an active playerbase, fun fact: They had a seperate development team for the MP so it doesn't feel tacked on. It's a whole 'nother freaking game.

Posted: May 10, 2015
												This is one of my favourite games of all time. I've played it lots of times, even before I bought it on Steam. How the metascore could be 72 is beyond me. Anyway, here's a list of advantages and disadvantages:con:-It has some technical difficulties sometimes-you will fight a lot of clones, all with the same voicesliterally nothing elsepro:-It has one of the best combat systems I know,-you can play it in many different ways, because--a: you can interact with the environment in so many ways, and--b: the skill system, which does not offer many skills, offers a few really powerful ones, so that you can quickly specialize significantly. Especially if you use the according items.-the level design is simply divine.-story is archetypal, but with brilliant cutscenes and very nice characters, given the relatively short time in which they appear.-the story is embedded in the Might and Magic universe, so it has a lot of background and many references to the stories in the Heroes of Might and Magic series.-the art design is great, it really feels like something different altogether and something very raw, gritty and realistic. So even now, years after the graphics are actually outdated, it still looks good. -the overall atmosphere is thrilling and tense in a way I do not experience often in video games.So, don't let the age or the low metascore fool you, this game gets 9.5/10

Posted: August 22, 2014
												The year is 2006. Half Life 2 has recently come out, and as a result everyone wanted in on this whole "real time physics" thing. Dark Messiah went absolutely batshit with it. With the dedicated "kick" button, you can send foes into convenient spike walls, off of cliffs, into fire, and more, and I never grew tired of it. In addition there are objects littered about that you can throw (or kick) and a lot of fun toys to play with like the many different spells and a rope bow. The big downside is the oft wonky melee combat. Turning off the headbobbing helped me out, and the cursor isn't very reliable with some strikes. That being said it is very enjoyable if you get the hang of it, and what you're left with is a silly, overly dramatic fanstasy romp that is funny when it shouldn't be.

Watching idiot soldiers investigate and then slip on a patch of ice from your frostbow never gets old.I only have two real complaints (although plenty more suggestions and dreams for a theoretical sequel): 1. The story was a tad predictable with overly straightforward characters - no subtlety.2. Difficulty settings just change damage taken/dealt so enemies become tanky and you become fragile. Increasing enemy speed and aggressiveness would've felt better, more like the end-game knights which are challenging even on normal difficulty.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												Most fun FPS/RPG period. This game makes every other RPG feel lacking. The sheer joy of booting enemies off ledges, setting them on fire, baiting them into horrifying traps, and chucking objects at them keeps me coming back. But behind that there is a surprisingly deep and interesting combat system, each path of skills are well balanced and each makes for a very different play-through. The game starts hard until you realize what makes the combat richer and more tactical than any other FPS/RPG and at that point it becomes a gleeful slaughter-fest that never loses the edge of difficulty but never becomes totally impossible.  The plot is mostly boilerplate dumb fantasy, but is smart enough to stay out of your way and let you get to the killing, it's not obnoxiously bad in anyway.Note there are a couple memory leaks that are easily fixed, if your game starts chugging look up a fix.

Posted: July 14, 2014
												My word this game is underappreciated/underrated!!This perfectly represents what the game industry used to be like - the main design goal/focus being on the player having fun!A world that acts as a playground for your own creativity and enjoyment. All real-time physics - no scripted death sequences if an enemy gets too close to your character's proximity, no cover/hide-mechanics to disguise shoddy/unreliable coding - just you and the endless options afforded to you by the power of your imagination!!If you miss the good old days of the early era of 3-D gaming and the exquisite experimentation and boundary-pushing software that was developed at the time, then this game is ideal! Harken back to the platinum years of sandbox gameplay, right here!I would easily place this game in my top 100 list, it's that entertaining. A true diamond in the dust.Arkane Studios are rapidly becoming one of my all-time fav developers.

Posted: July 11, 2014
												Have you ever wondered how does it feel, to cast a freezing spell on an orc, then slash him into pieces with an arrow? If you did, check out Dark Messiah. The gameplay is absolutely flawless - using the environment, to destroy your enemies. If that's not enough, create your own hero: you can became a warrior, who is mastered with one handed weapons, and a shield. If you are not the fan of weapons, you can became a wizard: lethal fireballs, freezing spells, or just pick up a barrel with telekinesis, and smash their heads. Too much offensive battles? Then become a rogue! Dual-wielding daggers, and hiding in the darkness. Just stab'em in the back, or just kick them in the end of a cliff. Multiple endings (depending on which side you choose on your adventure), genial soundtrack, and the list goes on and on - absolutely marvelous game, but sadly it's way UNDERRATED! The only problem that the multiplayer isn't the best. If you like dark-fantasy, or you're an FPS-fan, but searching for something different, you should check out this masterpiece!

												A severely underrated game.  I've played through it multiple times, and will probably continue doing so. Completely different than all the other M&M games and much more intimate, IMO. Posted: August 22, 2014
												The year is 2006. Half Life 2 has recently come out, and as a result everyone wanted in on this whole "real time physics" thing. Dark Messiah went absolutely batshit with it. With the dedicated "kick" button, you can send foes into convenient spike walls, off of cliffs, into fire, and more, and I never grew tired of it. In addition there are objects littered about that you can throw (or kick) and a lot of fun toys to play with like the many different spells and a rope bow. The big downside is the oft wonky melee combat. Turning off the headbobbing helped me out, and the cursor isn't very reliable with some strikes. That being said it is very enjoyable if you get the hang of it, and what you're left with is a silly, overly dramatic fanstasy romp that is funny when it shouldn't be.

Posted: March 12, 2014
												I kicked a guard in the crotch and sent him flying towards a firey death. 10/10.Okay, seriously tho, Dark Messiah is a game that wants me to hate it: The combat is repetitive and dull early on (not to mention some of the very frustrating enemy mechanics), the story is very predictable, the environment design can sometimes be really confusing and, to top it all off, the game is riddled with glitches (but considering this is a Source based game, I think that’s to be expected).But yet, I can’t dislike this game, no matter how hard I try: It’s incredibly immersive; it has an amazing atmosphere and succeeds at making you feel like some sort of almighty jack-of-all-trades warrior. The level design can be confusing, yes, but it’s creative and entertaining. The combat does get a lot quicker and more intense as the game goes on, and the huge “bosses” you have to fight through the game are all epic and nerve-wrecking.Overall, this game is a recommend for me, but only to people who are willing to overlook some pretty major flaws in order to find a very entertaining and unique adventure. Fully action-based FPSRPGs are hard to find, and Dark Messiah finds that niche nicely. If nothing else, give the demo a shot. It gives you a pretty good idea of what you’re in for.

Posted: March 29, 2011
												GREAT storyline that let me feel like my actions fit the storyline my character was a part of, and other characters within the storyline act wonderfully and in meangful ways.  Graphics are decent and the game engine (Source) works as expected, environments are in general pleasant but can be confusing.Now to the best parts -- The combat WORKS.  Slashes have noticeable impact upon your foes, magic / archery / stealth all work well in addition to the standard melee fighting.  Environmental hazards abound and are a joy to use, as are the various special strikes and methods of dispatching your foes.Another good part -- The platforming WORKS.  See those knee-high barrier walls and neck height ledges you just can't seem to scale in other games?  You can in this one!  A big climbing mechanic in the Rope Bow allows for great platforming and exploring element which the game fully realizes and rewards the player for.This is a Fantasy FPS-Melee game DONE WELL.

Posted: July 30, 2015
												I bought this game almost on Day 1 back in 2006 - Steam seemed to have reset my progress during an update, so I gave it another run-though.This is a great game, very underrated and immensely fun - albeit flawed in a few areas.The graphics are amazing for 2006 standards, Source is used very well, the environments are beautiful, the atmosphere great and the models are also decent. The game is BRUTAL, finisher moves, burning corpses, beheadings, turn limbs etc.The gameplay... oh dear, how do I even describe this. "Might&Magic" is about right, I'd say. On my first playthrough, I decided to go full-on Warrior (usually I'd go for a mix, paladin-ish thing), and it was IMMENSELY fun, the combat is great once you get the hang of it, although I'm sorry I didn't play it on hard, because once you get beefed up a little, slaying enemies is a bit too unchallenging. I think I died maybe twice the whole campagin during combat. When you get the Lightning Shield and the Dragonborn sword, well, it just gets ridiculous.On my second playthrough, I chose a full-on Mage (combat mage, staff and all) and while I was a bit whimpy at first, by the end, I was even MORE powerful than a Warrior. Mana-sucking staff and Sanctuary=god mode, basically. I wasn't new to the game though, so that helped, but still, if you're going for a narrow, "one-trick-pony" build, perhaps play on Hard right off the bat, otherwise you might wade through enemies like dust.The reason why I said "Might and Magic is about right" is that I tried doing the whole Stealth/Thief thing, and more often times than not, it falls a bit flat. It's either too easy (really obvious ledges and rafters to avoid enemies) or too hard (open areas where you can't really be sneaky at all), and the inconsistent Stealth meter doesn't help - you can be "invisible" in plain torchlight or completely visible in total darkness; go figure.  The story is... alright, it has a few twists, and the game has 4 endings, depending on which woman you choose to leave alive and what you do at the very end. It's alright, but to me, it was really corny, though it wasn't necessarily the bad kind of corny either. Oh, and the voice acting is pretty cringe-worthy, it's just soooo emPHATIC and exaggerated to death. Nothing like the subtle delivery of Half-Life's Alyx or Barney, hell, even Dr. Mossman wasn't as annoying as most of the characters in this game. Not driving an Orc Cleaver through Leanna's face requires some serious self-control, believe me.One more (rather major) gripe: it does have a tendency to glitch/crash at times. The Rope Bow close to flat surfaces is a classic example, then there are random crashes, overall, it's not the most stable of games, so save often.All in all, it's Skyrim/Oblivion without the overbearing world and clunky combat system. It's a non-stealthy Thief. It deserves your attention and at the very LEAST, two playthroughs.

Posted: August 22, 2014
												The year is 2006. Half Life 2 has recently come out, and as a result everyone wanted in on this whole "real time physics" thing. Dark Messiah went absolutely batshit with it. With the dedicated "kick" button, you can send foes into convenient spike walls, off of cliffs, into fire, and more, and I never grew tired of it. In addition there are objects littered about that you can throw (or kick) and a lot of fun toys to play with like the many different spells and a rope bow. The big downside is the oft wonky melee combat. Turning off the headbobbing helped me out, and the cursor isn't very reliable with some strikes. That being said it is very enjoyable if you get the hang of it, and what you're left with is a silly, overly dramatic fanstasy romp that is funny when it shouldn't be.

												This is literally the best Multiplayer RPG I've ever played. It has distinct classes and the sorceress could use a nerf to her bramble + stone skin build, but it's not going to happen at this point.Just to make it short, it's a PvP first person fighting game where you choose a role and evolve as you complete objectives. Warriors are melee beasts, archers have powerful long range attacks, mages focus on area damage, assassins can backstab and instakill anyone, sorceresses heal and debuff enemies... And you get to choose the path you want to follow for each class. It's a pity the game's dead because it's one of the best multiplayer PvPs I've ever played.

Posted: July 25, 2015
												The game shows the signs of age, but nonetheless a good remark about some aspects that RPGs usually don't take into account.Pros:+ Good gameplay, with a wide range of possible strategies to afford enemies;+ Environment can (must) be used; also, good stealth mechanism;+ Multiple endings: now we're all used to it, but back in the time it must have been awesome and it's right to give it the right credit.Cons:- Lack of secondary quests and lore - set aside the choices for the endings, the storyline is straightforward;- Few customization options for the character's skills;- Poor enemy IA, counterbalanced by high damage output - no way to be tank;- The story is nothing new under the sun.There might be other pros and cons, but the main ones are here. Recommended, for the nostalgic or the "collector" who wants to see with his eyes an RPG which gives importance to the environment (I'm both).

Posted: July 14, 2011
												This is a forgotten gem. A first-person perspective action/adventure/RPG game set in the world of Heroes of MIght and Magic, it plays very similar to the old Thief classics. Combat is very difficult and you often have to use the environment to your advantage to survive a battle against more than one enemy. You get skill points for reaching objectives in the game, and you can spend them on combat skills, magic skills or "general" skills (thief, plus stat increases). You to combine powers to create many fun character builds.If I can find something to criticize it is the 2d female characters. You have one ♥♥♥♥♥♥ temptress, and one saintly good girl, and you get to choose between them. That's it. The level design is fantastic though. Chasing a fleeing thief across rooftops of a city, moving across crumbling orc huts precariously put at the side of a great mountain. Areas all look great and are fun to explore, and are filled to the brim with secrets.

Posted: July 1, 2016
												If you can play this game, it is FAN-TASTIC. i almost immediately got addicted for a number of reasons. first and foremost, the M&M franchise to me is one that has spanned across my whole life. as a little child my first and fondest memories of the franchise was in M&M mandate of heaven where being the little cheating bugger i was, i used a cheat to get the apocalypse spell and constantly ruin everyone in the starting towns day. after that it was the first 3 Heroes of M&M for me, the turn based strategy games that kept it alive.Im 21 now, the days of the old Heroes of M&M games are behind me as its difficult to get them to work properly. i played Mandate of heaven again and actually made headway ( albiet difficultly) and then stopped. until i found this game. . .Now I will start off by saying this, I NEVER heard of this little gem until recently. and i honest to god wish i had. The reasoni said " if you can play this game" the big word being "IF" is this, the game suffers from a plethora of bugs a majority of which consist of ones preventing you from playing or starting the game. it seems to be a bug that has hundreds of symptoms and no 3 people have the same lol. ive encountered bugs like this before, but for OS not video games. and i honestly dont know what made my game start working after 2 weeks of trying but it did and oh, my god...You play as a young man named Saref. (sareth? sarif?) and are tasked by your master with getting an item known as the Shantiri crystal. he then sends you on your way to a city to enlist the help of a powerful mage. but not before giving you a sexy lady friend companion to live in your head. The combat is refreshingly different and you wont find anything like it in another M&M game. since it runs off source you KNOW physics are involved and used in the best ways. there are many different ways to kill an orc lol. for example, there may be spike boards laid against a wall, just position that orc between you and the board and KICK THE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ BACK TO HELL! or if thats not good enough for you, you can kick them off a cliff and have them fall a thousand feet down. really give them time to think about where they ♥♥♥♥ed up before they die! there are also numerous traps, such as unstable platforms with various heavy breakable objects that you can knock down onto your enemies! seriously the choice is yours! kill away!now, dont be thinking that you'll get rich in this game and buy the greatest gear ever before your final boss encounter.there is no money, no shop system at all. you gotta survive on the potions you either find, or grab up that healing spell quick because you will need it. as for the weapons, ive only just made it to the giant worm and only now do i have an enchanter weapon im in love with. ( souldrinker ftw) but if youre looking for powerful weapons, you better be ready to go above and beyond level exploration. i mean it, its crazy where some of these secret areas are! and while im on the subject easily in my list of top 3 greatest things in this game is the rope bow. which allows you to shoot an arrow at a wooden object, (often in the ceiling or jutting out of the wall) and it will make a rope that you can climb with. got a tough fight ahead and not enough potions to heal with? running is a good option, but creating a matrix of ropes along the walls and ceiling like some medieval spiderman? EVEN BETTER! just climb the ropes and jump the unrealistically long distance between them to escape your would be killers!i could go on and on about how great this little known gem of a game is. but the bottom line will always be this, if you can play it GET IT.

Posted: June 18, 2015
TL;DR:Combat is great, decent story but forgettable characters, and has HD support. Plus it has a demo to try it out. Multiplayer's dead so get it for single player experience.PROS: Combat Mechanics are great. Melee, magic or ranged, they all feel satisfying to use. Specially melee combat, thanks to the addition of an execution bar (one hit kill when it's filled). The environment also can be used as a weapon, which adds a little strategy into the game. Quicksaves: There are some points where the game have unskippable cutscenes. Fortunately you can quicksave anywhere so that problem gets fixed fast. Different approaches: You can go sneaking or go full rambo and kill everyone. I recommend the latter to test combat Difficulty is well balanced, but can get challenging after having 5+ enemies on screen. Decent story: It's obvious and cliché, but somewhat well told. You don't need to know anything from previous Might and Magic games to understand what's going on.CONS: Crashing: I experienced around 4 crashes and some random framerate drop during my entire playthrough. Fortunately most of them were after an autosave. Oddly enough, my game also crashes everytime I quit the game, but I wanted to leave it anyways during those times so I don't really mind. Ally AI is dumb: Like really, really dumb. Only pro of the ally is that she can heal you, and that you can get her to stand up and do nothing else. If you let her attack them, get ready to either hit her or watch her get killed for going kamikaze on them. Forgettable characters. Not even the main character is saved from this. Some of the edges in the levels aren't well placed, and you can see the empty white void like in any source game. But that's me being nitpicky. Overall, this game feels like a less polished dishonored, which is good. If you want a somewhat similiar experience to Arkane's most popular game for a cheaper price, I recommend checking this one out.

Posted: July 5, 2015
												This is a deep action RPG with a heavy emphasis on a variety of combat choices, and one of the few games I've seen that does "character builds" properly. Except for the occasional unmodeled wall, the game looks good, and has great level design for what is really quite a linear experience.Really, the main focus is on the combat, which it does spectacularly, thanks to the best usage of the Source engine that I think I've ever seen, but the actual execution of the engine is where the game shows its two biggest faults, aside from my computer's language being changed to French every time I play the game.- Visual effects can often crowd the screen to the point that vision is annoyingly obstructed.- Enemies can sometimes get stuck on certain objects, making them cheap, easy targets.That's it. That's all I disliked. Everything else is golden.Last minute note: The multiplayer is kind of dead, unless you don't mind looking for private servers.

Posted: June 28, 2015
												Advertised as the first ever First Person Slasher, the game is a mix of RPG and FPS elements that is surprisingly fun, but a little cluncky. I really like the atmosphere and some aspects of the art design, and the three skill trees you can pursue offer distinctly different styles of play. That and different endings avaliable offer a degree of replayability. If you want to go on an adventure in the world of Might & Magic (specifically Ashan) slashing, shooting and/or casting spells on fantastical creatures like orcs, ogres, cyclopses, skeletons, zombies etc. this is the game for you. The game also has a multiplayer mode, but even soon after the premiere I had difficulty finding other people to play, so I can't recommend it for people who mainly play online.

Posted: April 28, 2016
												I was gonna write a long review but this is all you need to know: This game is basically Deus Ex in a medieval fantasy setting and with good first person combat. The level design is set up such that they are basically linear, but made so that you can complete them in any number of different ways depending on how your character is set up. The game is full of secret rooms and optional puzzles you can solve for loot and experience.This is one of the most pure gaming experiences you can have, they cut out all the boring ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that RPGs are known for and left in only things that were absolutely necessary (it's design is more reminscent of old school shooters than western RPGs). What you end up with is a game that is all business from start to finish that has consistently excellent level design while offering unique combat mechanics that still have not been matched to this day.

Posted: April 26, 2016
												A personal anecdote from yours truly.I was a young'un during the heyday of EverQuest, and later WoW.  Too young to muster the resources to see those games in action, let alone play them.  (Yes, that means videos too -- dialup, motherf**ker, have you used it?)  So I was left to simply imagine the majesty of these virtual worlds.  Mind you, I wasnt raised on Dungeons & Dragons, frankly I found Tolkienesque fantasy a tired premise before I even knew the name 'Tolkien'.  But gaming was the new frontier of entertainment, and the idea of entering a bona fide fantasy realm set my little mind ablaze with possiblity.Maybe I 'missed the wave' with MMORPGs.  Or maybe my years with Counter-Strike took the sheen off multiplayer gaming.  But by the time I finally saw WoW for myself, I couldn't care less.  I'll gladly take five minutes of deathmatch over a month of MMO banality.But then I randomly found this game, Dark Messiah.  And I was amazed at how it looked and played exactly like the MMO fantasy I had imagined all those years.  Combat wasnt just a mathematical abstraction, the level design looked like a coherent living world (even though, ultimately, its a linear FPS affair) and the art direction made the most out of everything to immerse you into it's world.  This was the fantasy adventure I wanted, but didnt get, from MMORPGs.The only thing missing is the multiplayer, but thats a fair trade IMO.  Pubbies ruin everything anyway...

Posted: July 14, 2015
												When I first got this game, I found it in the local GAME store when I was younger I decided it looked cool and bought it. Then this game became one of my best old-school fantasy experiences I've ever had when I was younger and stupider, This game changed my viewing of other games with me learning about the story and experiencing the immense abilities the game has to offer instead of just playing the game for the sake of it. This game gave me creative ways in which to eliminate my foes which was one of the best things about the combat within the game. The atmosphere of the game is astonishing and realistic, also fitting for the settings and multiple locations of the Game. And the interesting story is easy to follow just by listening to Cutscenes in the game. Dark Messiah is although a game which has set paths in which you HAVE to take to progress within the game, it still has many areas which allow you to drive away from just the objective and get better items. Since this game had so many oppurtunities in it, I have played this game's singleplayer more than usual about 15 times or more, the first 3 times I played and completed this game was the story choices (Bad, Good.), class selection (Theif, Mage, Warrior) And the rest was for the whole nostalgia effect and just to see how fast I can complete the game or just play-through it to just have a nice old-school experience. I would reccommend people to buy this game and keep the game in their libary just to have it as a side-game to play it for bordeom or story choices, despite it being an Old Game. Great Game 10/10

Posted: July 22, 2016
A first person action-heavy RPG set in the Might & Magic universe, which I've never played any of the games of. The game's generally linear but there are plenty of areas to walk around to for secret areas with useful items and a few possible optional objectives with a few that can determine the ending. The RPG part plays in with having a skill progression system and finding items & equipment from wherever, like on enemies and treasure. Skill points are acquired through story progression and doing optional objectives. You've got a small skill tree in the inventory to look at for deciding preferred skills, which there aren't actually many of. Most varying equipment in the game will tell you in the description that they require you to have a certain amount of skill points invested in a certain skill before you can equip them, which can be a decent incentive on picking what skill you want to put points in. There's not a whole lot of variety in equipment and the possible stats & effects they give off either.You don't sell & buy things and your inventory's relatively limited so you'd just be dropping stuff that won't serve any use most of the time.Throughout the game you can use magic, stealth, and general melee. Unless you're pretty well invested in the stealth area via skills and equipment, you'd just be engaging baddies with melee weapons & trap-setting magic more often, which can be a lot more reliable & fun.When you do have decent points in stealth though you can practically bypass most fights and eavesdrop on more silly dialogue. It could also make the game far too easy; when you start using the best stealth armor you're practically invisible when stepping on even a speck of darkness like in the Thief series, which the game sometimes references. Even the climbing mechanic is practically like Thief's. You can be a foot away facing someone in the dark with full stealth and they won't see you. With that you can just as easily circle them for a stealth kill backstab.Fascinatingly you can do a backstab against someone from 5 feet away so long as you're behind them since you're supposed to be quickly grabbing their neck and stabbing & slitting their throat but prior to the brutality it just looks like you telekinetically moved the enemy to you. You can only do backstabs on common humanoid enemies that are capable of speech.Magic's pretty fun when you get the chance to use them whether they be from natural MP usage or one-use magic scrolls. The traps and telekenisis ones are probably the most enjoyable due to their usefulness and the way they show how silly the physics of the game get.Although it costs loads of MP to cast spells and there are loads of of those one-use magic scrolls laying around so unless I wanted to use magic a little bit more often than I already am, it's not entirely beneficial to put too many points in the magic area as opposed to something more helpful for the long run like passive stat-raising skills.As you start investing skill points into the melee combat focused skills you get more features and other cool stuff you can do with melee combat which they seem to have put a lot of thought for. For example, if an enemy's down and they're still alive you get a chance to perform a down impalement for serious damage, though it usually kills 'em instantly. If you and an enemy attack at the same time with a charged attack you clash weapons and the loser gets stunned for a bit. You can block most melee attacks with most weapons by themselves and you can block most any attack with a shield once you're able to use 'em though almost all shields in the game have durability to look out for. In the beginning it's simply just making use of normal attacks and charged attacks with whatever stick you can whack someone with. Down the line you'll be able to acquire and do the abilities to do cooler stuff. There's some archery but it's as simple as it gets; only one archery specific skill that can be upgraded twice more and it doesn't bring a whole lot new to the bow & arrow usage outside of the usual aim & shoot stuff.Something fascinating thing about the combat in general in this game; you can pick up virtually anything sensible and throw it at an enemy and it'd stun 'em a bit. If it's something like a barrel or a pumpkin sized rock they'll likely ragdoll right then & there. There are also plenty of conveniently placed natural traps for you to make use of such as ropes that holds hanging chandeliers, fragile cielings that hold heavy objects to drop on baddies, wall spikes, and other nifty stuff.And then there's the infamous kicking mechanic. The game uses the Source engine so they decided to use the stamina mechanic here for sprinting and kicking. Kicking's meant for a quick stun against an enemy, especially when they have a shield, and knocking them into or off of things. Kicking pointlessly eats up stamina if it's not used properly. The best thing about this mechanic though is that if a large enough fall, wall of spikes, some raging fire, or whatever else hazardous is sandwiching an enemy then your kick instantly turns 'em into a ragdoll and launches 'em forward to the hazard whether or not they actually reach the designated target.The levels and their design are great, even if the Main Point A to Main Point B is linear. Most objective locations aren't obvious which does encourage one to look around a bit and there's often more than one way to reach 'em. They're typically made so that you usually have to do some Half-Life-esque platforming (small platforms and such) to get to where you want, at least in places like caves, catacombs, and especially secret areas.The only serious problems I have with this game are the loads of bugs and glitches included. The game crashes pretty frequently for whatever reason, strong focus on physics in a 3D environment typically means frequently buggy physics & this is no exception, shield durability can reach negative numbers which for whatever reason means that you can't drop it thus leading to inventory space being wasted for the rest of the playthrough, if your climbing is a bit off then the climb can keep failing until you're positioned properly. There are plenty more that can even impede story progression. The only saving factor of that is that you can save almost any time, even during the non-pre-rendered cutscenes.When it comes to the difficulty settings it's pretty unbalanced. On Normal it's too easy but on Hard & Hardcore most anything kills you in only a few hits and they themselves take ages to kill if you don't launch 'em to a pitfall or spikes or something of the like that can immediately kill 'em. Some attacks are I think so glitched that you can die from what seems like one attack. An example of that would be one of the zombie's arm swings. One swing is supposed to take half your health but if your positioning is a bit bad then the one attack can count as two thus killing you instantly. They're a bit slow but they can catch you off guard in multiple ways such as them spawning right behind you and not seeing them because they were in an extremely dark spot.There are 4 different endings to see that are hardly different from one another and you can always start a new game with a different build so there's definitely some potential replay value. It's a slightly dated game in terms of graphics and just how the engine's used sometimes but getting past all that it's real fun.

Posted: December 31, 2015
Dark Messiah of Might and Magic ReviewAhh such a classic game. I remember playing this on the xbox and spending countless hours finding different ways to kill enemies! Without further a due lets jump in shall we? Ill split this review into the following categories: gameplay, graphics, audio, and story.Gameplay/CombatProbably the most entertaining aspect of this game is the gameplay. It's first person with a very fluid feel to it. You play the game by picking from the skill trees (or putting points into multiple trees effectiely becoming a hybrid) and using weapons that correlate to that tree. Warriors use shields and sword, mages use staff, rogues use bows and daggers, etc. I played through the game as a rogue/warrior hybrid and gotta say it was fun as hell. The physics engine is hilarious, theres nothing like spartan kicking a ghoul over the castle walls. The game is not all that long which is fine because for what the game is trying to achieve the length was perfect. I could go on forever explaining the combos, power attacks, etc you can use but ill just use a bulleted list to give the highlights.  great physics fun traps to use against enemies simple skill system diverse ways to kill enemies=never bored short-medium length game. hidden areas to discover which give good weapons and some additional skill points. AudioHonestly not a whole lot to say here. The audio isnt anything special. Sound effects sound appropriate and the background tracks/combat music aren't especially exciting or annoying. For this part i'd just say "meh".GraphicsDecent graphics, some models and enemies looked a little neglected to some of the other characters but I suppose thats to be expected when you don't spend much time looking at them as you do punting them into a wall of spikes.If you want to know what I mean look at the cyclops and goblins in the game. Compared to orcs and humans they look lackluster but again im not going to sit here and rag on it like its a big deal this game is FUN.StoryOk so this part, in my opinion, was very well thoughtout. I won't spoil the main plot of the game as that would ruin some of the fun but do know you can essentially choose to be good or evil. Because of this "choice" system (there arent that many choices as say, dragon age) there are multiple endings which may add some replay value on top of the desire to want to play through again as a different class. It starts out simple and adds enough throughout the game to keep you interested. Its not AMAZING but it was cool and had a nice twist to it, albeit one that probably a lot of people will see coming. All in all, pretty good.Additional Notes-I did encounter some minor bugs here and there but nothing game breaking. Of particular annoyance was a sound bug in which the sound effect of flys near dead bodies would "follow" you around regardless of how far you got away from the body. A simple reload will solve this.-I played through two times to get the endings and i recommend your first time through just to play without much worry about secret areas and hidden items, then on your second playthough take the time to looks for the secret areas so you get cooler weapons/armor and more skill points.-SECRET AREAS ARE "NOT" required. You can easily beat this game with the weapons that drop from enemies/you find in your path way and youll have plenty of skill points to make your character into a decent hybrid or a focused badass.Id rate this game a 8.5/10. Plenty of fun and defintely worth the money if on sale!

Posted: January 10, 2015
												I don't have much time into this game as of writing this review, but overall it seems like an interesting game. The combat feels good, and I enjoy the world that the game is set in. Another nice thing is that if you decide to walk into places you're not supposed to be, such as someone's house or a pub's kitchen, people actually get mad and guards will come by and attempt to remove you, unlike in many AAA RPGs. The only big downside is that the stealth and the way enemies detect sound is a little bit wonky, and there is no option to set crouch to toggle. All in all, I recommend this game with the limited amount of time I have put into it.

Posted: January 1, 2015
												I have been aquainted with this game long ago, when I was actually reading gaming magazines.(lacking internet around that time) One thing that stuck to me recently is the sandbox combat that spices some situations, although the physics of of some situations makes it a bit awkward and sometimes it looks just too forced to even seem realistic. Melee combat, however, is truly impressive. Making use of the smooth character movement(strafing, jumping, power strikes), you can perform effective combat manouvers and unpexpected turnouts makes it even more spectacular.( ex. that moment when you use a power strike on an Orc charging you and both of you cross swords, making it a click masher before it gets decieded who is disarmed). The magic system could have used a bit more adaptability to the already flexible character tree that you can develop up to the epilogue of the game. However, magic itself serves as a very useful tool in some situations.( ex. unlocking the cells of prisoners with telekinesis so that the Necromancer doesn't see you and goes Darth Vader on your neck)All in all, the game has quite decent a storyline, mood and visuals( especially for it's age) and I can honestly say that I have encountered only a few glitches. It may not cater to some modern gamers but those of you who are more old school will find this game quite pleasant and memorable experience.

Posted: May 30, 2013
												Kicking Orcs Off Ledges Simulator 2006 still stands up today as the ultimate kicking things off ledges experience. There is more to it than just kicking, however. It plays sort of like Deus Ex in a fantasy world where a fragile coexistance between magic and the protagonist's omnipotent legs is begining to fray because of, like, some Necromancers or something. I forget. It doesn't really matter, does it? You don't buy simulators for rich storytelling, after all. Anyway, the game gives you free reign to explore levels full of creatures to kick and things to kick them off of or into. Along the way you'll get some skill points to distribute. So, you'll get the opportunity to learn different types of magical spells, become an expert archer, or simply finish a BA in Orc Studies from the University of Ledges. You can shrink goblins and step on them, freeze surfaces and watch orcs slide off ledges without dirtying your boots,  or immerse yourself in the best first person swordplay out there.However, this stuff is all secondary to the amazing power of the protagonist's legs. You could kick down the fourth wall and become demon emperor of the universe with those bad boys.

												GREAT storyline that let me feel like my actions fit the storyline my character was a part of, and other characters within the storyline act wonderfully and in meangful ways.  Graphics are decent and the game engine (Source) works as expected, environments are in general pleasant but can be confusing.Now to the best parts -- The combat WORKS.  Slashes have noticeable impact upon your foes, magic / archery / stealth all work well in addition to the standard melee fighting.  Environmental hazards abound and are a joy to use, as are the various special strikes and methods of dispatching your foes.Another good part -- The platforming WORKS.  See those knee-high barrier walls and neck height ledges you just can't seem to scale in other games?  You can in this one!  A big climbing mechanic in the Rope Bow allows for great platforming and exploring element which the game fully realizes and rewards the player for.This is a Fantasy FPS-Melee game DONE WELL.
